We are France’s leading multi-brand food service franchising platform, renowned for our diverse and strategically curated portfolio of market-leading restaurant brands. Our portfolio encompasses a variety of eight wellpositioned distinct restaurant brands that cater to a wide range of attractive food service market segments, from QSR to casual dining formats, addressing all-day consumption occasions, as illustrated in the graphic below. We own six out of the eight restaurant brands in our portfolio (Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon, Volfoni, Pitaya and Jôyô), while we are the master franchisee in France for the remaining two brands (Burger King and Itsu). Our network spans over 1,000 restaurants across attractive locations throughout France, partnering with 423 franchisees, who together operated 83% of our restaurant network as of December 31, 2023. The remaining 17% of our restaurant network was comprised of directly-operated company restaurants (the “Company

Subsection Title: Restaurants”). For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated €1,016.8 million in Pro Forma Run-
Subsubsection Text: Rate franchise sales and revenues and €318.8 million of Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate Normalized EBITDA reflecting a 31.4% Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate EBITDA margin. Our portfolio is diversified across cuisine styles and occasions and is operated mostly under a highly attractive franchise model through an efficient and synergistic platform. Our strength in identifying and responding to consumer preferences for cuisine, price point, format and channel through our various restaurant brand concepts has established us as a dominant player in the French food service industry. We have successfully scaled and grown our presence exponentially from 116 points of sale in 2010 to over 1,000 points of sale in 2023. In line with our continued growth, we have increased our SWS by a 12% CAGR over the 2019 to March 31, 2024 period. Our pace of growth is consistent, with between approximately 80 to 110 new restaurant openings every year over the 2019 to 2023 period and a strong pipeline of additional restaurant openings in the future. In recent years, our growth has been driven by the rapid expansion of our franchisee network through the opening of new franchise restaurants under both existing and newly developed or acquired brand concepts. We have namely experienced continued and steady growth with Burger King France (excluding Quick), the second largest QSR chain in France and for which we are the exclusive French master franchisee, representing approximately 51% of our restaurant network. As a result, we increased our total points of sale from 708 as of 1 ----- December 31, 2019 to 1,059 as of March 31, 2024, a large proportion of which was driven by growth in our franchised restaurants, increasing the total franchised portion of our restaurant network from 71% in 2019 to 83% on March 31. 2024. This growth had a strong corresponding impact on our _Pro Forma SWS, which increased from €1.7 billion for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €2.8 billion for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our Pro Forma Adjusted Normalized EBITDA also increased from approximately €254 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, according to management estimates, to €307.4 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We believe our brand portfolio approach provides significant scale and synergies across brands, allowing us to capitalize on our market-leading capabilities, as illustrated by the successful roll-out of the Burger King brand in France to improve the performance of Bertrand Casual Foods’ current and future restaurant brands. Our operational model is well-established, historically successful and designed to be replicable across our existing and future restaurant brands. We facilitate a platform driven approach by leveraging our know-how and a synergistic approach to enhance brand operations and performance across all areas and stages of development. We have a historically proven ability to execute rapid roll-out and expansion through our in-house dedicated restaurant network development team, as well as to implement in-house processes for newcomer brands, which involves upgrading operations to meet our group-wide standards, transitioning into the franchised model, diversifying cuisine offerings and redefining brand concepts to resonate with current market preferences that we know well. These strategic initiatives were implemented to improve the financial performance and brand positioning of our existing brands allowing us to grow the proportion of franchised restaurants. This transition into our franchise operational model generates more profitability per restaurant, increasing the average restaurant sales (“ARS”) generated by each brand. For example, as part of Léon’s recent conversion into Léon Fish Brasserie, we redefined its concept and food offering to appeal to a younger and broader customer base, revamped its digital loyalty program to increase customer engagement, and accelerated restaurant openings under the franchise model. Together, these efforts contributed to an increase in ARS, evidenced by a 42% difference between the ARS of €1.2 million generated by Léon restaurants that are not yet converted and €1.7 million generated by the converted Léon Fish Brasserie restaurants, in each case for the year ended December 31, 2023. At the core of our success is our franchise model, which is strategically crafted to be both asset-light and cash generative. We have two principal types of franchise arrangements: Franchise with Lease Management, our franchise model through which we generate additional revenues from real estate lease fees from our franchisees, and Pure Franchise. By focusing the majority of our network on franchising rather than direct restaurant operations, we limit our exposure to the day-to-day fixed costs and investments typically associated with running food service establishments. Instead, these capital expenditure responsibilities are supported by our franchisees, who invest in the assets and infrastructure necessary to operate their locations. This approach allows us to concentrate on providing unparalleled franchisee support, brand stewardship and strategic growth initiatives. Our franchisees benefit from a proven business model that offers the potential for robust returns, while we capitalize on stable and predictable revenue streams through royalty fees, advertising fees and, in the case of Franchise with Lease Management, leasing fees. In turn, our franchisees are contractually required to adhere to the meticulously crafted brand standards for the restaurants they operate, the absence of which can result in termination of our contracts with them. Our model ensures a mutually beneficial partnership that drives collective success across our network of brands. We continue to strategically maintain and operate a limited number of selected directly-owned Company Restaurants, which represented 17% of our restaurant network as of the year ended December 31, 2023. This approach provides us with a platform to pilot new marketing, menu and omni-channel innovations before rolling them out across our franchise network. It also allows us to establish a benchmark of operational success through exemplary models for our franchisees to emulate, showcasing best practices in management, customer service and quality product. While operating a limited number of Company Restaurants will remain a key strategic part of our portfolio for these reasons, we expect the proportion of Company Restaurants in our restaurant network to decrease over time.

Subsubsection Title: Attractive market in France with steady growth characteristics, under penetrated by brands and franchises
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the French food service market benefits from strong and sustainable growth characteristics, demonstrating resilience through business cycles and the COVID-19 pandemic. With a market size valued at €49.6 billion in 2023, the French food service market has historically experienced a steady growth rate, and we believe that it has significant untapped potential, particularly for restaurant chains and franchise businesses. Notably, the share of meals eaten outside the home in France remains significantly below that of more mature markets (such as the United Kingdom). With the growing shift in consumer preferences in France favoring more frequent outof-home meals, we believe this supports France’s market potential and room for growth. The French consumer food service market historically grew at a CAGR of approximately 2% per year in the pre-COVID era between the years 2016 and 2019, growing from approximately €50.3 billion in 2016 to approximately €52.9 billion in 2019. Following a brief decline in market growth in 2020, whereby the market briefly contracted to approximately €30.8 billion in 2020 due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the French food service market has since shown a strong recovery path, continuing to grow at an upward trajectory, reaching almost pre-COVID-19 levels. This recovery highlights the market’s resilience and the sector’s ability to adapt to changing market and consumer preferences, projecting a positive future growth trajectory. In the French food service industry, chains have historically been under-represented compared to independent establishments. However, this trend has accelerated in recent years, with the market share of foodservice chains increasing by over 9 percentage points, from 34% in 2019 to 43% in 2023. This evolution is driven by consumers’ growing preferences for the consistency, quality and diverse culinary experiences that chains are uniquely positioned to offer. The momentum behind chain restaurants is a reflection of deeper changes in consumer behavior and expectations, which we believe points towards continued growth and increased market penetration. Against this backdrop, we believe our food service franchising platform is uniquely positioned to capitalize on this momentum. Our business model, characterized by a diverse portfolio of well-established brands and a demonstrated operational framework that has historically expanded the brands that join our portfolio, positions us as a key player ready to seize the untapped potential within the evolving market. The demand for franchising, in particular, continues to grow, driven by entrepreneurs seeking to align with reputable brands that offer operational excellence, market agility, and strategic support. For example, the number of franchisees in France across various industries has grown by a CAGR of 5% from 1995 through 2023 to approximately 92,000 franchises overall. Further, we believe that there is room for growth in the number of franchisees in the food service sector, with 13% of the French food service sector represented by franchises as of 2023 (compared to 37% of the French grocery retail sector). We have already demonstrated our capacity to meet this demand, with an average annual growth of approximately 110 new franchise restaurants joining our network over the past three years. This significant growth potential for franchisors in the French food industry is underpinned by structural market trends and evolving consumer preferences, which we believe our portfolio brands effectively address. In particular, consumer trends have shown a shift in consumption habits, driven by a focus on convenient food options due to decreasing time available for cooking, a desire for new consumption occasions (from breakfast to dinner) across multiple channels (such as delivery), an increasing share of income allocated to out-of-home food purchases, and the generalization of company-subsidized lunch vouchers, which drive external food consumption. In addition, consumer tastes have evolved toward diverse and global cuisines, which include options for healthy food and gourmet products. Our portfolio responds to these evolving trends, encompassing a variety of eight wellpositioned distinct restaurant brands that cater to a wide range of attractive food service market segments, from QSR to casual dining eateries and addressing all-day consumption occasions across various channels. With the repositioning and modernizing of certain brands that joined our portfolio, such as Hippopotamus or Léon (see “— _Overview”), and the development of new products to meet consumer preference, such as the expanded veggie_ range of menu options for our Burger King brand, we have also demonstrated our ability to adapt our existing brands to evolving consumer needs.

Subsubsection Title: Leading multi-brand food service franchisor with a diverse portfolio of leading brands
Subsubsection Text: With 1,059 restaurants in our network as of March 31, 2024, we are the largest multi-brand restaurant franchising platform in France, with approximately twice the number of restaurants in our network as compared to our closest French multi-brand restaurant group competitor in 2023. We are distinguished not only by the number of 3 ----- restaurants in our network, but also by the unparalleled diversity of our portfolio. With eight distinct restaurant brands in our portfolio, each catering to different customer preferences and dining occasions, our platform offers a variety of culinary experiences that stands out in France. This diverse portfolio enables us to effectively address a broad spectrum of consumer preferences and dining needs, ranging from QSR to casual dining establishments. Anchoring our portfolio is the iconic global QSR brand, Burger King, which represents the largest restaurant brand within our network and the second-largest QSR player in France, with 18-20% market share in the chained burger QSR segment in 2023. We are Burger King’s master franchisee in France and are well positioned to leverage the scale and marketing of one of the most recognized brands in the restaurant industry worldwide. Our Burger King brand is the preferred QSR brand in the French market, with a market-leading net promoter score reflecting 96% brand awareness and digital presence. Since the reintroduction of Burger King in France in 2013, our outstanding performance has positioned France as the second-largest market for the Burger King brand globally, second only to the United States. This remarkable achievement was acknowledged with the “Franchisee of the Year” award at the Burger King World Convention in the fourth quarter of 2023. Our Burger King brand operations are best-in-class, with a robust franchising organization, local supply chain and omni-channel positioning. With a focus on building strong customer engagement through viral targeted marketing and a strong social media and mobile presence, we have significantly grown our presence in the digital market, and thus strengthened our market share, to include over 6 million Burger King active mobile app users globally as of March 31, 2024 and almost two million followers on social media across Instagram, TikTok, Facebook and X. The historical and continued success of Burger King within our portfolio underscores our significant presence in the competitive QSR market. Despite our current market leadership, there remains substantial whitespace for us to expand, particularly within the QSR segment. Compared to other countries, France remains a comparatively fragmented QSR market, with a lower number of QSR points of sale per 100,000 inhabitants as of 2023 compared, for example, to Spain, the United Kingdom and the United States, indicating a significant opportunity for growth for restaurant chains to further consolidate and grow their share of the market. We aim to capitalize on untapped market segments and further strengthen Burger King’s position in the French QSR landscape. Specifically, we believe we are well positioned to reduce the total network size gap between Burger King and its primary competitor, McDonald’s, which currently maintains a larger store network, thereby presenting compelling growth potential. Our strategic focus on expanding our footprint, coupled with the existing market dynamics, positions us favorably to capture a larger share of the market and drive sustained growth. Our robust portfolio includes seven other unique brands, presented below (see “—Highly-replicable business _model with proven capacity to integrate and develop acquired brands”), each with its own distinct concept,_ contributing to our overall market strength and diversity. Our strong brand portfolio includes Au Bureau, one of the largest brasserie/pub brands in France with 79-81% of market share in the branded café-bars market, Hippopotamus, one of the largest networks of steakhouses in prime locations, Léon, one of the leading fish and seafood brands in France and Pitaya, a fast-casual restaurant chain with a strong network with international presence and 31-33% of market share. We strive to operate with a mix of brands that include well-known historic brands, new organically developed brands and international well-known brands debuting in France. These complementary brands span a variety of food service segments, including Asian QSR, Italian casual dining, pubs and brasseries, and seafood restaurants, among others. This multiplicity of brands not only enriches our offering but also enhances our resilience by diversifying our revenue streams and reducing dependency on a single market segment. The success of these brands, alongside Burger King, exemplifies our proven ability to develop, manage, and grow a wide range of restaurant concepts. Together, they form a robust foundation for our continued expansion and reinforce our position as a leader in the French restaurant franchising industry.

Subsubsection Title: Best-in-class operations supported by proven synergistic operational platform
Subsubsection Text: We believe our brand portfolio approach provides significant scale and synergies across brands, allowing us to capitalize on our market-leading capabilities to improve the performance of our current and future restaurant brands. The collective strength of our brands, underpinned by a shared operational framework, ensures efficiency, consistency, and innovation at every level of the franchising experience. We provide our franchisees with food service industry expertise throughout their relationship with us to enhance their success, from site selection of a 4 ----- new restaurant through continued operational support. Our franchisees also benefit from the ability to diversity cuisine formats and models across our brand portfolio, with the ability to cover a specific geographical area with different brands. One of the cornerstone capabilities of our platform is our strategic approach to network roll-out and site sourcing. We boast an in-house dedicated market-leading property team, with over 20 years of experience and deep local knowledge of the areas in which we wish to grow our operations. Leveraging advanced proprietary sourcing and market insights, we identify prime locations that promise high foot traffic and optimal visibility for our franchisees. In partnership with prime institutional real estate investors and with a robust development team consisting of approximately 60 full-time employees with national coverage, we are able to access some of the most attractive locations as tenant of choice to quickly and efficiently open new restaurants for any of the brands in our portfolio. As a result of our efficient methodology, we have opened 103 new restaurants on average from 2016 through 2023, which we believe reflects one of the largest roll-out plans of other key food service peers in Europe. In the realm of brand management, our expertise ensures that each brand maintains its unique identity while benefiting from cross-brand strategies to increase customer brand awareness and engagement. With decades of expertise running restaurants driven by an entrepreneurial management team, we provide an innovative approach to brand management to sync the dining experience of each of our brands with the distinct customer preferences that each brand is tailored to. We aim to modernize the historic brands in our portfolio, with a focus on product and customer experience, to upgrade their brand image and sync the dining experience with our knowledge of what customers seek. In the context of a rapidly evolving food service landscape, we have strategically positioned our restaurant brand franchise network at the forefront of digital innovation and delivery partnerships. Recognizing the growing consumer demand for convenience and speed, we have invested heavily in developing a robust digital infrastructure that encompasses user-friendly online ordering platforms, mobile apps with intuitive interfaces, and integrated loyalty programs. In 2023, approximately 88% of our restaurants offered delivery services, with approximately €210 million in SWS generated across our portfolio over the same period from delivery sales. This digital ecosystem is designed to enhance the customer experience, making it seamless for patrons to engage with our brands, place orders, and receive their favorite meals wherever they are. Furthermore, our advanced delivery capabilities, supported by partnerships with leading delivery services, ensure that we can meet the high expectations for promptness and quality. This comprehensive approach to digital and delivery services not only drives additional revenue streams but also strengthens the competitive edge of our franchise network, ensuring that our brands remain relevant and preferred in a market that increasingly values digital convenience and reliable delivery options.

Subsubsection Title: Highly compelling proposition for strong pool of vetted franchisees
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, we partnered with over 420 franchisees across our restaurant brand network. Our franchise revenue model is based on the royalties and fees that we generate from our franchisees, which in turn are calculated on the basis of a percentage of their total SWS. As a result, our financial performance is inherently 5 ----- correlated to the sales performance of our franchisees and we engage in a meticulous new franchisee selection process to ensure that each franchisee in our network can uphold brand standards and deliver high-quality customer experience. For our Burger King brand, for example, we receive a high number of applications that we evaluate, with only about 7% of applications received ultimately approved to join our network. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 47% of our franchisee network operated more than one restaurant site. Based on precedent from our Burger King brand, we believe there is capacity to increase the number of restaurants per franchisee to more than 3 restaurants on average, providing growth potential for both new and existing franchisees. The largest franchisee within our network operates 12 restaurants, and we do not anticipate franchisees generally exceeding this level, ensuring a balanced and competitive franchise structure. Franchisees joining our network gain access to extensive benefits and expert support from a leading franchise system, positioning them for success from the outset of their franchise journey. At the core of these benefits is our commitment to providing best-in-class support, ensuring that every franchisee is well-equipped to thrive in the competitive food service industry. At the restaurant opening stage, franchisees benefit from up to six months of intensive training, laying a solid foundation for operational success. Our complete training support extends across each brand within the network, drawing on years of proven expertise in restaurant management. Additionally, franchisees gain access to financing partners with whom we have established historical relationships and are confident in our network’s robust operating track record. This comprehensive support system is designed to minimize the hurdles of starting a new business, ensuring franchisees are thoroughly equipped to meet market demands. Once operational, our restaurants have historically displayed attractive unit economics and rapid payback periods. Franchisees experience a rapid ramp-up on new openings (with a ramp-up period of less than a month for our Burger King brands and within three to six months for the other restaurant brands in our portfolio), thanks to our efficient operational model and the strong brand recognition of the brands in our portfolio. The network’s attractive cash management model enables franchisees to achieve rapid payback on their initial investment. Historically, franchisees have achieved payback for Burger King brand restaurants within three to four years, while franchisees for the rest of the brands in our portfolio (excluding Itsu and Pitaya) have achieved payback within four and a half to six years. Further, our Burger King brand restaurants typically generate approximately €3.8 million in ARS on average, while the other restaurants brands in our portfolio typically generate between approximately €0.8 million to €2.1 million in ARS, based on the same period. These attractive economics are bolstered by the attractive, adapted and flexible franchise terms that we offer franchisees under our different restaurant brands. We offer our franchisees two principal types of franchise arrangements: Franchise with Lease Management, our preferred franchise model for our Burger King brand, through which we generate additional revenues from real estate lease fees from our franchisees, and Pure Franchise, our preferred franchise model for the rest of the brands in our portfolio. Under the latter model, franchisees are able to own the business asset rights over the business. Each of our different brands also demand a different up-front equity investment, with Burger King brand requiring €250,000 up-front (of which €50,000 are entry fees) and the remainder of our brands requiring between €100,000 to €350,000 up-front, depending on the 6 ----- brand (of which €50,000 to €60,000 are entry fees). This flexibility allows franchisees to choose the brand and franchise model that best suits their business goals and financial abilities.

Subsubsection Title: Asset-light business model with high cash conversion and limited exposure to restaurant operations
Subsubsection Text: Our successful franchise-based business model, supported by a robust network of committed franchise partners, generates recurring and predictable revenues with high EBITDA margin, with 15% of revenues from franchisees as a percentage of SWS and 28% Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin for the year ended December 31, 2023. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 83% of our network was represented by Franchise Restaurants, while approximately 17% was represented by Company Restaurants. As a large majority of our restaurants are Franchise Restaurants, we operate with a strategic advantage by being largely insulated from the day-to-day operational costs associated with running a restaurant. This arrangement, where individual franchisees are responsible for the direct expenses of their establishments, allows us to focus on overarching brand development, marketing strategies, and network expansion without the financial burden and complexities of daily restaurant management. Consequently, our financial model is characterized by reduced operational risk and a streamlined cost structure, enhancing our ability to invest in long-term growth initiatives and support our franchisees from a strategic vantage point. The table below demonstrates the key features of each of our restaurant models: Company Restaurants, Franchise with Lease Management and Pure Franchise. (1) Advertising contribution from franchisees is entirely spent in marketing campaigns to promote the brands nationally. (2) Under Franchise with Lease Management contracts, we pay occupancy costs for the ownership of the business asset rights. (3) MFA royalties are paid for brands that we do not directly owned (i.e., between 3.5 and 4.5% of SWS for Burger King and approximately 3% of SWS for Itsu). Our focus on building and expanding our franchise network centers around an asset-light approach, pursuant to which we do not own the land, building or physical assets of the restaurants within our network. We derive the benefits of this asset-light model under both types of our franchise arrangements. This asset-light model allows for higher cash conversion and reduces or eliminates for locations with third-party landlord agreements our capital 7 ----- expenditures for such franchise openings. We have a strong cash conversion (measured as pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA minus our capital expenditures divided by pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA) of over 80%. In the case of Franchise with Lease Management restaurants, we partner with a diverse base of real estate investor partners who own the land and buildings where our restaurants operate. These properties are then leased to us, following which we sub-lease the land to our franchisees under our Franchise with Lease Management Model, allowing us to retain ownership of the business goodwill. As such, we are able to generate lease management fees while reducing our capital burden. Our franchisees are thereafter responsible for ongoing capital expenditures related to equipment, kitchen, furniture and fixtures. We generally incur no capital expenditure for two-thirds of our openings under the Lease Management Model. Indeed, in 2023, 30 out of 44 Burger King France openings were executed using the asset-light Pure Franchise model. Our franchisees under our Pure Franchise model lease their restaurant locations directly from third-party landlords. They directly invest in the physical assets required to establish and operate their individual locations, bearing responsibility for all capital expenditures, including building and development. We incur no opening capital expenditure under the Pure Franchise model. The table below demonstrates our enhanced cash conversion shown by the Burger King Group between 2019 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, as a result of the growth in our franchise network. The table below summarizes our asset-light network development model. In addition, our franchise-based model allows us to retain strong control over our network through our standard agreements with our franchisees, which govern various aspects of our relationship, including the royalties and fees due by them to us. We believe that our franchise model offers us favorable upsides as well as an attractive contractual protection and that our emphasis on growing this model in the future will continue to drive high cash conversion.

Subsubsection Title: Highly-replicable business model with proven capacity to integrate and develop acquired brands
Subsubsection Text: Our strategic growth lies in our highly replicable business franchise model, which has demonstrated a proven capacity for integrating and developing a diverse array of brands. Since 2010, we have successfully acquired, integrated and developed a number of successful brands, with demonstrated substantial performance improvement. This model is built on a foundation of meticulous sourcing of potential acquisitions. Our experienced in-house M&A team has a demonstrated capacity to identify some of the most compelling concepts for consumers and 8 ----- franchisees that show promise in terms of market fit and growth potential, backed by a privileged access to deal flow thanks to our market positioning and reputation as the “buyer of choice.” Once a brand is incorporated into our portfolio, we apply our playbook for successful integration by implementing our in-house best practices and processes. With over 20 years of experience in network development, we work with newly acquired restaurant brands to upgrade their operational processes, such as reporting and analytics. We also plug them into our network of resource pooling, leveraging on existing support functions. This ensures that each brand is seamlessly integrated into our network, benefiting from our wealth of experience and established systems for operational excellence. Our approach is also committed to redefining brand concepts to ensure they resonate with current market trends and consumer preferences. This involves a thorough analysis of the brand's core identity and offerings, followed by strategic adjustments that enhance its appeal without losing its unique character. Our goal is to elevate each brand to its fullest potential in alignment with our brand standards by updating menu items, revamping marketing strategies, redesigning the customer experience or enhancing the omni-channel distribution offering to customers. Developing the franchise network is the final piece of our model. With the brand concept refined and best practices in place, we focus on expanding the franchise network through targeted recruitment of franchisees in line with our recruitment criteria. Our support for franchisees is comprehensive, encompassing training, marketing, supply chain logistics, and ongoing operational guidance. This ensures not only the rapid expansion of the franchise network but also the sustainability of each franchise under our umbrella.

Subsubsection Title: Seasoned management team with a proven track-record supported by shareholders experienced in our industry
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from the experience and industry know-how of our senior management team, backed by our visionary founder, Olivier Bertrand. Olivier Bertrand, our board chairman, founded Groupe Bertrand in 1997 and has since been closely associated with our image, development and operations. Under his guidance, the Group has significantly transformed the franchise restaurant industry in France by developing existing brands and tremendously increasing their presence throughout the entire French territory. Our senior management team is led by our Chief Executive Officer, Christophe Gaschin, who joined the Group in 2016 and previously worked as a business lawyer with the Paris Bar for almost 17 years as a partner at major international law firms. Our Chief Financial Officer, Xavier Cottineau, joined the Group in September 2016 after serving as Chief Financial Officer at Financière Louis, as Finance Vice President at EuroDisney and senior financial auditor at PricewaterhouseCoopers. Our experienced management team has a long and successful history with a proven track record of developing, integrating and operating in the QSR and casual dining segment and has managed to lead our Group through evolutions to its business model, support our Group's growing network (including its franchise growth trajectory) and execute M&A transactions to further our business strategies. Our management team has also successfully managed our business through challenges that accompanied evolving government regulations and customer behavior in the face of the COVID-19 crisis, and guided the recovery of our operations to strong levels following the easing of COVID-19 related restaurant closure measures.
We believe that we benefit from the following key strengths: 2 -----

Subsubsection Title: Expand our brand portfolio and franchise restaurant network to profitably increase our market share
Subsubsection Text: We believe there is significant untapped demand for franchised brands across France and internationally in Europe, supporting the potential to continue our successful expansion strategy. We plan to employ a dynamic strategy to expand the number of brands in our portfolio that can be franchised, leveraging both acquisitions and organic brand development as pivotal growth drivers. Through targeted M&A activities, we plan to strategically acquire brands that complement our existing portfolio, offering new concepts that respond to local consumer demand or enhancing our geographical footprint through increased network density. This approach allows us to rapidly scale our network, bringing in established brands with loyal customer bases and proven business models. Concurrently, we plan to continue to invest in the organic development of new brands, nurturing innovative 9 ----- concepts from the ground up to address emerging market trends and consumer demands. This dual strategy of external growth through acquisitions and internal growth through brand innovation ensures a continuous pipeline of fresh and diverse offerings within our franchise network. We also plan to further expand our restaurant network in collaboration with current and new franchisees to continue to increase our market share in France. We expect that a higher density of restaurants will further contribute to brand awareness, support customer loyalty and increase traffic in our existing restaurants, while our new restaurants will benefit from existing strong brands, reputation and know-how. We have a rigorous approach to expansion and expect to promote new restaurant growth primarily through opening Franchise with Lease Management restaurants for our Burger King brand, allowing us to maintain significant control over our network with limited capital expenditure. For the other brands in our network, we will focus on opening predominantly Pure Franchise restaurants, which further reduce our capital expenditures. With regard to Company Restaurants, these require significantly higher capital expenditures and introduces additional leases and personnel costs to our cost structure compared to franchise arrangements; consequently, we intend to limit the number of new Company Restaurants.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to take advantage of attractive market fundamentals
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue leveraging our extensive and prime-location restaurant network and existing broad franchise network. We also seek to expand the product offerings in our existing restaurants to continue to tailor our offerings to evolving customer preferences by relying on our expertise in creating innovative, premium convenience food products that match customers’ demand, which we believe will be a key driver of our revenues. For example, we intend to continue to expand our healthy and nutritious product offering through the introduction of additional healthy options and preservative-free ingredients to further capture key markets, such as families, and anticipate market trends toward local sourcing, value-for-money products and healthy food options as well as meatless alternatives and products with no animal protein. We also plan to further strengthen our multi-channel approach through the enhancement of takeaway options and the development of new digital sales channels to further drive our growth. Finally, we intend to capitalize on increased consumption opportunities by the continued operation of our restaurants in the afternoon or late-night hours. We are also committed to continuing to capitalize on the inherent synergies within our diverse portfolio of brands. By leveraging shared resources, expertise, and operational efficiencies across our network, we aim to enhance the value proposition for our franchisees and deliver a superior experience to our customers. This includes optimizing our supply chain logistics, unifying marketing efforts to amplify brand visibility for each of the brands in our portfolio, and fostering innovation through the cross-pollination of ideas and best practices among our brands. Our commitment to harnessing these synergies not only drives operational excellence and cost savings but also positions us to respond more dynamically to market changes and consumer trends. We will remain focused on identifying and exploiting new opportunities for synergy, ensuring that our collective strength continues to be a cornerstone of our competitive advantage and growth strategy.

We intend to increase our market share of digital sales through the continued development and maintenance of our best-in-class multi-channel offering. We plan to continue to make improvements to our existing digital sales channels in order to maintain and increase our digital sales, while also developing additional innovative and convenient digital capabilities. While we have already successfully integrated the use of in-app orders and preorders, Click & Collect orders, in-store tablets that allow customers to skip the line and home delivery options with third-party aggregators for our Burger King brand, we also see opportunity in expanding our digital channels for the other brands in our network. Following the positive growth of these initiatives with the Burger King brand, we plan to replicate this model across our entire brand portfolio. Additionally, we have recently acquired The Original Food Court, a proprietary technology that enables customers to order seamlessly from all our brands, creating a “digital food court.” Our commitment to innovation in the omni-channel space positions our brands as industry leaders, providing convenience and accessibility to customers while promoting growth and profitability for our franchise partners. We believe that the current trends and growth observed in our digital sales, accelerated as a result of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, demonstrate a distribution channel that adapts to the changing preferences of our customers and is complementary to our in-restaurant dining channel. Further improving and 10 ----- increasing sales through our digital channel will enable us to capture an additional segment of the market by offering customers an easy and convenient dining option.

Subsubsection Title: Continue our commitment to sustainability and focus on improving our ESG performance
Subsubsection Text: Improving our ESG initiatives and growing our network while prioritizing sustainability initiatives is central to our business. Our key strategic ESG pillars include: (i) adapting our product offering to address future global challenges, (ii) promoting the well-being of our teams and (iii) limiting our environmental impact. With respect to our product offering, we intend to continue to promote local and quality product sourcing, innovate our offer to provide healthy and responsible food options (for example, for our Burger King brand, through a full permanent range of plant-based burgers, wraps, salads and sandwiches without animal protein) and apply stringent safety standards to our operations. In promoting the well-being of our teams, our goal is to create an inclusive workplace with frequent staff trainings and an emphasis on fighting against harassment. We are also focused on limiting our environmental impact through waste management initiatives, continued improvement of our logistics services and responsible growth of our business.

Subsubsection Title: Focus on cost control and economies of scale
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to improve our gross margin and profitable expansion through leveraging our Bertrand Franchise platform to generate cost optimization, particularly for our supply chain and marketing. By streamlining these critical areas, we aim to achieve significant efficiencies and cost reductions that directly benefit our bottom line and enhance the profitability of our franchise network. While franchisees bear the food and logistic costs for their restaurants, we organize and negotiate the sourcing for both Company Restaurants and Franchise Restaurants through pre-approved suppliers and relationships with certain third-party logistics providers. Our food and logistics costs are significant, and we believe that we could drive restaurants’ gross margin through enhanced control of our logistics costs by exploiting economies of scale in line with the growth of our restaurant network, further developing local supplier networks and implementing cost control measures to reduce food waste. For example, we require all of our Burger King franchisees to source their raw materials from suppliers that BKC has previously approved and with whom we intend to continue to leverage our extensive restaurant network and economies of scale to obtain favorable commercial terms. In addition, suppliers have sought to invest in long-term partnerships with us, which has allowed us to reduce food costs and secure dedicated product lines to satisfy our needs. Apart from focusing on the optimization of our supply chain, we intend to further develop our communication and advertising campaigns to promote our brands, product offerings and commercial offers in order to reinforce awareness of our brands, build on their existing brand image and increase customer traffic, which we believe will also contribute to the improvement of our gross margin and profitable expansion. As a result of our continued growing network and presence in France, we believe we will have improved media buying conditions, allowing us to obtain a higher return on our marketing expenses.

Subsubsection Title: Drive EBITDA growth and cash generation to support deleveraging
Subsubsection Text: Our franchise model, combined with an asset-light approach for a significant share of new openings, is a pillar to our deleveraging strategy. We will continue to deploy this model through the continued expansion of Franchise Restaurants that permit us to actively manage our network, target specific whitespace and encourage the formation of denser clusters of restaurants, as well as to limit swings in our working capital. Where possible, in the case of Franchise with Lease Management restaurants, we will also favor third party landlord agreements allowing us to effectively reduce our new opening capex spend to nothing with new openings under the asset-light model lease management. In addition, we believe that tight cash control measures implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, coupled with the strong cash buffer built and maintained through the crisis, will allow us to continue focusing on deleveraging in the periods to come. 11 -----
Our objective is to grow our business and increase profitability by implementing the following strategies:

On October 31, 2023, the Parent acquired a number of subsidiaries previously separately held by Groupe Bertrand through a series of transactions (such transactions, together, the “2023 Reorganization”), with the aim to bring all the Groupe Bertrand franchise activities under a single entity. Pursuant to the 2023 Reorganization, the Parent acquired Groupe Flo, Miditsuco GB (the holding entity of the Itsu group), Holdco GB (the holding entity of the Pitaya group), Bertrand Franchise Services and United Lab (together, the “Acquired Subsidiaries”), which each held and operated the additional restaurant brands in our current portfolio. For a detailed description on the background of the 2023 Reorganization, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and _Results of Operations—Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Information Presented—First set of IFRS-compliant financial statements.”_

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer is directly owned by the Parent and does not own any material assets. In order to facilitate the Refinancing (as defined below) and immediately before the Refinancing, the Parent will contribute and sell all of its assets and liabilities to the Issuer (collectively, the “Reorganization

Subsection Title: Transactions”), so that, as a result of the Reorganization Transactions and effective as of the Issue Date, (A) the
Subsubsection Text: Parent’s only material asset will be the shares of the Issuer and (B) the Issuer will own, directly or indirectly, all the subsidiaries of the Group. For a detailed description of our corporate structure following the Reorganization Transactions, see “Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure.”

Throughout this Offering Memorandum, we collectively refer to the Offering and issuance of the Notes, the entering into of the New Revolving Credit Facility, the security documents creating security interests over the Issue Date Collateral and the Post-Closing Collateral contemplated by the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, and the application of proceeds from the issuance of the Notes as described under “Use of Proceeds” (the “Refinancing”). The gross proceeds from the Offering by the Issuer will be €1,150.0 million. The Issuer will use the gross proceeds from the issuance of the Notes primarily to (a) repay indebtedness of the Group, (b) pay make-whole amounts and other pre-payment costs and (c) pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Refinancing. For additional information, see “Use of Proceeds”, “Description of the Notes”, and “Management’s Discussion _and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Liquidity and Capital Resources of the Group”._ 12 -----

_This summary contains basic information about the Group and this Offering, and highlights information contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum about the Offering and our business, financial performance and prospects. This summary does not contain all of the information that may be important to you in deciding to invest in the Notes to be acquired through them and it is qualified in its entirety by the more detailed information and financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. You should read the entire Offering Memorandum, including the section entitled “Risk Factors” and the financial information and related notes contained in this Offering Memorandum before making an investment decision._

The chart below depicts a simplified summary of our corporate and financing structure after giving effect to the Refinancing and the Reorganization Transactions. All entities shown below are 100% owned unless otherwise indicated. The chart does not include all entities in our group or all of the debt obligations thereof. For more information, see “Summary—The Refinancing”, “Use of Proceeds”, “Capitalization” and “Principal Shareholders _and Related Party Transactions”. For a summary of the material financing arrangements identified in this diagram,_ see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes”. (1) As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Bertrand Franchise S.A.S. (the “Parent”) is directly owned by (a) Bertrand Franchise Corp. (holding 60.75% of share capital and 74.29% of voting rights), which in turn is held indirectly by Olivier Bertrand as majority shareholder, (b) BQ Participations (holding 21.25% of share capital and 25.71% of voting rights), which in turn is held by funds managed and advised by Bridgepoint S.A.S., and (c) United JVCO (holding 18.00% of share capital and no voting rights), which is in turn held by investment vehicles managed or advised by AlpInvest US Holdings LLC, AlpInvest Partners B.V. and Goldman Sachs Asset Management. See “Principal Shareholders and Related Party Transactions.” (2) As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Bertrand Franchise Finance S.A.S. (the “Issuer”) is directly owned by the Parent and does not own any material assets. In order to facilitate the Refinancing, and immediately prior to the Refinancing and the Issue Date, the Parent will contribute and sell all of its assets and liabilities to the Issuer (collectively, the “Reorganization Transactions”), so that, as a result of the Reorganization Transactions and effective as of the Issue Date, (A) the Parent’s only asset will be the shares of the Issuer and (B) the Issuer will own, directly or indirectly, all the subsidiaries of the Group. See “Summary—The Reorganization Transactions” and “Principal Shareholders and Related Party Transactions”. (3) The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer and will rank equal in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s existing and future senior indebtedness and will rank senior to all of the Issuer’s future indebtedness that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes. Within 60 days after the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by Midco GB, Burger King France, Burger King Restauration, Financière BKF, France BKR, Groupe Flo and BK Invest France (herein referred to and previously defined as the “Guarantors”). For the year ended December 31, 2023, the Issuer and the Guarantors generated 80.4% of the Group’s _Pro Forma EBITDA and, as of December 31, 2023, directly held 58.3% of the Group’s total assets, in each case net of intercompany eliminations. Subject to the Agreed Security Principles which are summarized in “Description of the Notes—Security”, (a) on the Issue Date, the Issuer’s obligations under the Indenture will be secured by the Issue Date Collateral on a first-ranking basis, which will include a firstranking pledge over the shares of the Issuer and certain other assets of the Issuer; and (b) within 60 days after the Issue Date, the 13 ----- Guarantors’ obligations under the Indenture will be secured by the Post-Closing Collateral on a first-ranking basis, which will include certain assets of the Guarantors (as defined above). See “Description of the Notes—Security”. The Collateral will also secure the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement substantially simultaneously with the same collateral granted to secure the obligations under the Notes on a super senior basis pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein). In the event of enforcement of the security interests over the Collateral or certain distressed sales, lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facility and counterparties to certain hedging obligations (if any) will be entitled to be repaid with the proceeds from enforcement or such distressed sales in priority to the Notes. The Guarantees and the security interests in the Collateral will be subject to contractual and legal limitations that may materially limit their enforceability, and the Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the _Guarantees and the Collateral” and “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral”._ (4) On or prior to the Issue Date, the Issuer will enter into the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to provide for a revolving credit facility in an amount of €165.0 million. The New Revolving Credit Facility will be made available for drawing as of the Issue Date to the Issuer and certain subsidiaries of the Issuer that may become borrowers under the New Revolving Credit Facility, for general corporate and working capital purposes. The New Revolving Credit Facility will be guaranteed within 60 days after the Issue Date by the Guarantors. The New Revolving Credit Facility will be secured substantially simultaneously with the same collateral granted to secure the obligations under the Notes. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facility.” Pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facility as well as certain hedging counterparties will receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral in priority to the holders of the Notes. See “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” for more information. We expect that the New Revolving Credit Facility will be undrawn on_ the Issue Date. (5) The Issuer will use the gross proceeds from the issuance of the Notes primarily to (a) repay indebtedness of the Group, (b) pay makewhole amounts and other pre-payment costs and (c) pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Refinancing. Proceeds from the Notes issuance may be subsequently lent to other subsidiaries of the Issuer. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Description _of the Notes— The Proceeds Loans.”_ (6) The Issuer holds majority interests in a number of non-guarantor operating entity subsidiaries. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the non-Guarantor subsidiaries of the Parent generated 19.1% of the Group’s Pro Forma EBITDA and, as of December 31, 2023, directly held 33.3% of the Group’s consolidated total assets, in each case net of intercompany eliminations. (7) The entities in the “Restricted Group” are subject to the covenants in the Indenture and the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. 14 -----

Hippo Gestion & Cie); - the shares (parts sociales) owned by Financière BKF in BK Invest France; 16 ----- - the shares (parts sociales) owned by France BKR SAS in BK Invest France; - the material bank accounts of each Guarantor located in France; and - all intragroup loan receivables owed to each Guarantor, Such assets and rights listed above are collectively referred to as the “Post-Closing Date Collateral” and, together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”. The Collateral will also secure the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (as defined herein) substantially simultaneously with the same collateral granted to secure the obligations under the Notes on a super senior basis pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein). In the event of enforcement of the security interests over the Collateral or certain distressed sales, lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (as defined herein) and counterparties to certain hedging obligations (if any) will be entitled to be repaid with the proceeds from enforcement or such distressed sale in priority to the Notes. The Guarantees and the security interests in the Collateral will be subject to contractual and legal limitations that may materially limit their enforceability, and the Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to _the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral” and “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral”._ Guarantors/ Guarantee ............** Within 60 days after the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed by the following subsidiaries, which, pursuant to the Reorganization Transactions, will be subsidiaries of the Issuer on or before the Issue Date: - Midco GB; - Burger King France; - Burger King Restauration; - Financière BKF; - France BKR; - Groupe Flo; and - BK Invest France. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the Issuer and the Guarantors generated 80.4% of the Group’s Pro Forma EBITDA and, as of December 31, 2023, directly held 58.3% of the Group’s total assets, in each case net of intercompany eliminations. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the nonGuarantor subsidiaries of the Parent generated 19.1% of the Group’s _Pro _Forma EBITDA and, as of December 31, 2023, directly held 33.3% of the_ Group’s consolidated total assets, in each case net of intercompany eliminations. Ranking of the Guarantees ......** The Guarantees of the Guarantors will: - be general senior secured obligations of such Guarantor; - rank equal in right of payment to all of such Guarantor’s existing and future senior indebtedness; 17 ----- - rank senior to all of such Guarantor’s future indebtedness that is subordinated in right of payment its Guarantee; and - will be secured by the Post-Closing Collateral and effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is secured by property or assets of such Guarantor that do not secure its Guarantee, to the extent of the value of such property or assets. The Guarantees will be subject to release under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—The Note Guarantees—Release of the Note _Guarantees”._ Intercreditor Agreement ..........** The Issuer, the Trustee, the Security Agent and the facility agent under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will enter into an Intercreditor Agreement to establish the relative rights, and the relative payment priorities, of their entitlement and certain other matters relating to the administration of security interests.

Subsection Title: Optional Redemption: Optional Redemption of the
Subsubsection Text: Floating Rate Notes ...............** At any time on or after     , 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Floating Rate Notes at the redemption prices specified in this Offering Memorandum. Prior to     , 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Floating Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Floating Rate Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date plus a “make-whole” premium, as described as described under “Description of the _Notes—Optional Redemption”._

Fixed Rate Notes....................** Prior to     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Fixed Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date plus a “make-whole” premium as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption”._ At any time on or after     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Fixed Rate Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum. Prior to     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem at its option, up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of Fixed Rate Notes (including the aggregate principal amount any additional Fixed Rate Notes issued) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption price specified in this Offering Memorandum. Prior to     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem during each twelve month period commencing with the Issue Date up to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes at its option, from time to time, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any.

Subsection Title: Change of Control .................... Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, each
Subsubsection Text: holder of the Notes may require the Issuer to repurchase all or a portion of its Notes at 101% of their principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any. See “Description of the Notes—Purchase of _Notes Upon a Change of Control”._ 18 -----

Subsection Title: Additional Amounts ................. Any payments made by or on behalf of the Issuer on the Notes or by any of
Subsubsection Text: the Guarantors with respect to the Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes unless such withholding or deduction is required by law. If withholding or deduction for such taxes is required to be made in any relevant taxing jurisdiction with respect to a payment on the Notes or with respect to the Guarantees, subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that would have been received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of the Notes—Additional _Amounts”._

Subsection Title: Tax Redemption ........................ The Issuer may redeem all of the relevant series of Notes upon the occurrence
Subsubsection Text: of certain changes in applicable tax law at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any. See “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption—Tax Redemption”._

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants .................... The Indenture governing the Notes, among other things, will restrict the
Subsubsection Text: ability of the Parent and its Restricted Subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - make certain asset sales; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to us; - merge or consolidate with other entities; and - enter into certain transactions with affiliates.

Subsection Title: Original Issue Discount ............ Either or both of the Floating Rate Notes and the Fixed Rate Notes may be
Subsubsection Text: issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes (“OID”). A holder of Notes issued with OID that is subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include the OID on such Notes in gross income (as ordinary income) as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such OID and regardless of such holder’s regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. See “Certain _Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations.”_ Transfer Restrictions ................** The Notes have not been, and will not be, registered under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transfer and may only be offered or sold in the United States in compliance with Rule 144A under the U.S. Securities Act and outside the United States to persons other than U.S. persons in reliance on Regulation S under the U.S. Securities Act. See “Transfer Restrictions” and “Plan of _Distribution”._

Notes .......................................** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, we 19 ----- cannot assure you that a liquid market for the Notes will develop or be maintained. Listing and Trading ..................** Application will be made for the Notes to be listed on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and to be admitted to trading on the Euro MTF Market. Trustee for the Notes ................** U.S. Bank Trustees Limited. Calculation Agent .....................** Elavon Financial Services DAC. Paying Agent .............................** Elavon Financial Services DAC. Security Agent ...........................** U.S. Bank Trustees Limited. Registrar ....................................** Elavon Financial Services DAC. Transfer Agent ..........................** Elavon Financial Services DAC. Listing Agent .............................** Walkers Listing Services Limited Use of Proceeds of the Notes ....** The Issuer will use the gross proceeds from the issuance of the Notes primarily to (a) repay indebtedness of the Group, (b) pay make-whole amounts and other pre-payment costs and (c) pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Refinancing. See “Use of Proceeds”.
and the Indenture ..................** New York.

Intercreditor Agreement ......** England and Wales. Risk Factors ..............................** Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider carefully all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors” section in this Offering Memorandum before making a decision whether to invest in the Notes. 20 -----

Subsection Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA Overview
Subsubsection Text: The following tables present selected historical consolidated financial information for (i) the Parent (a) as of and for the years ended December 31, 2023, including unaudited comparable information for the year ended December 31, 2022, derived from the Parent Annual Financial Statements, (b) as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2024 including unaudited and unreviewed comparable information for the three months ended March 31, 2023, derived from the Parent Interim Financial Statements; and (ii) Burger King France as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022, including comparable information for the year ended December 31, 2021, derived from the BK France Financial Statements. The Issuer, which is fully owned by the Parent and which will, as of the Issue Date, own all of the assets and liabilities currently owned by the Parent, does not produce consolidated financial statements. We present in this Offering Memorandum certain consolidated financial information for the Parent and its subsidiaries, as well as certain consolidated financial information for Burger King France S.A.S. and its subsidiaries. The Parent is as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, and will remain after the Issue Date, a holding company that conduct no business operations of its own and has no significant assets other than the equity interests and/or the intercompany receivables it hold in each of its direct and indirect subsidiaries. The material differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2024 of the Parent on a standalone basis under IFRS and the rest of the Group represents mainly (i) a standalone net current liabilities (excluding cash) of €2.8 million, (ii) cash and cash equivalents of €1.1 million, (iii) a positive standalone EBITDA equal to €0.2 million and (iv) a net financial income of €0.6 million. The material differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 of the Parent on a standalone basis under IFRS and the rest of the Group represents mainly (i) a standalone net current liabilities (excluding cash) of €3.1 million, (ii) cash and cash equivalents of €0.0 million, (iii) a positive standalone EBITDA for the Parent equal to €1.4 million and (iv) a net financial expenses of €(21.8) million. As a consequence of the above, we believe that the financial information presented in the tables below, in each case subject to the differences noted above, adequately reflect what the Issuer’s consolidated financial results and financial position would have been for the applicable periods, in all material respects. The summary consolidated financial information presented in the tables below has been derived from the Financial Statements, free English translations of which is included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. This section should be read in conjunction with the financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum as well as the disclosures provided under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting _the Comparability of the Financial Information Presented” and “Risk Factors—Risks related to our presentation of financial and other information”._ 21 -----

Subsection Title: Unaudited Pro Forma Consolidated Financial Information of the Parent
Subsubsection Text: _The unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information set out below has been prepared to illustrate the effect of the 2023 Reorganization on the consolidated income statement of the Parent as if the related transactions took place on January 1, 2023. The Pro Forma Financial Information is presented for illustrative purposes and presents a situation hypothetical in nature. As a result, the hypothetical data included in this Pro Forma Financial Information may differ from the actual results of the Parent. The Pro Forma Financial Information reflects pro forma adjustments based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe to be reasonable. The assumptions and estimates underlying the Pro Forma Financial Information are described in the accompanying notes thereto, which should be read together with the Pro Forma Financial Information. The Pro Forma Financial Information should not be considered indicative of the actual position that would have been achieved had the 2023 Reorganization been consummated on the date indicated nor is it meant to be indicative of the Parent’s future financial position. Neither the assumptions underlying the preparation of the Pro Forma Financial Information, nor the resulting Pro Forma Financial Information have been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. The pro forma adjustments are based on the information available at the time of the preparation of this Offering Memorandum. The Pro Forma Financial Information has been prepared in a manner consistent with the accounting policies that have been applied to the Parent Annual Financial Statements. The Pro Forma Financial Information has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act, the Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. Neither the assumptions underlying the pro forma adjustments, nor the resulting Pro Forma Financial Information have been audited or reviewed. This section should be read in conjunction with the financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum as well as the disclosures provided under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Information Presented”, and “Unaudited Pro Forma Consolidated Financial Information of the Parent” and “Risk Factors—Risks related to our presentation of financial and other information”._ 26 -----

We calculate Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate Normalized EBITDA in the following manner: (a) Represents adjustments to reflect the normalization of energy costs resulting from the increase in energy prices since 2022. (b) Represents the restaurant EBITDA of the Burger King restaurants that were either opened or converted during a twelve-month period, and which generated an EBITDA during the year ended December 31, 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, respectively. (c) Represents the restaurant EBITDA of the Burger King restaurants that were opened or converted during the twelve-month period as if they were operational during the period. To do so, we calculate a case-by-case estimate of the sales that would have been generated in a twelve-month period for each restaurant. We then apply this ARS to the restaurants in the sample by applying a cost margin or EBITDA margin, as applicable, to the estimated ARS based on the type of restaurant included in the sample, as follows:
