Subsubsection Text: The Issuer and its subsidiaries are organized outside the United States, and the Group’s business is conducted entirely outside the United States. Most of the members of the board of directors, supervisory board and all of the senior management of the Issuer and the Group are non-residents of the United States. Although the Parent, the Issuer and the Guarantors will submit to the jurisdiction of certain New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws, you may be unable to effect service of process within the United States on its or its subsidiaries’ directors and executive officers. In addition, as the assets of the Parent, the Issuer and its subsidiaries and those of their respective directors and executive officers are generally located outside of the United States, you may be unable to enforce judgments obtained in the U.S. courts against them. Moreover, in light of recent decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court, actions of the Issuer may not be subject to the civil liability provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States. The United States is not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards, rendered in civil and commercial matters with France. There is, therefore, doubt as to the enforceability of civil liabilities based upon U.S. federal securities laws in an action to enforce a U.S. judgment in France. In addition, the enforcement in France of any judgment obtained in a U.S. court based on civil liabilities, whether or not predicated solely upon U.S. federal securities laws, will be subject to certain conditions. There is also doubt that a court in France would have the requisite power or authority to grant remedies sought in an original action brought in France on the basis of U.S. federal securities laws violations. For further information, see “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities”. 83 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time.
Subsubsection Text: One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed herein and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes. One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed herein and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: Many of the covenants contained in the Indenture will be suspended if the Notes are rated investment grade.
Subsubsection Text: Many of the covenants in the Indenture governing the Notes will be suspended if the Notes are rated BBB- or better by at least two rating agencies provided that at such time no default under the Indenture has occurred and is continuing. These covenants will restrict, among other things, the Issuer’s ability to pay dividends, to incur debt and to enter into certain other transactions. There can be no assurance that the Notes will ever be rated investment grade, or that if they are rated investment grade, that the Notes will maintain such ratings. Suspension of these covenants, however, would allow the Issuer to engage in certain transactions that would not be permitted while these covenants were in force, including incurring additional debt, paying dividends and making investments which may conflict with, or otherwise be adverse to, the interests of the holders of the Notes. See “Description of _the Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Certain Covenants when Notes Rated Investment Grade”._

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: The transfer of the Notes is restricted, which may adversely affect their liquidity and the price at which they may be sold.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes are being offered and sold pursuant to an exemption from registration under the U.S. Securities Act and applicable state securities laws of the United States. The Notes have not been and will not be registered under the U.S. Securities Act or any state securities laws. Therefore, you may not transfer or sell the Notes in the United States except pursuant to an exemption from, or a refinancing not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and applicable state securities laws, or pursuant to an effective registration statement, and you may be required to bear the risk of your investment in the Notes for an indefinite period of time. The Indenture contains provisions that restrict the Notes from being offered, sold or otherwise transferred except pursuant to the exemptions available pursuant to Rule 144A and Regulation S under the U.S. Securities Act, or other exemptions under the U.S. Securities Act. In addition, by acceptance of delivery of any Notes, the holder thereof agrees on its own behalf and on behalf of any investor accounts for which it has purchased the Notes that it shall not transfer the Notes in an aggregate principal amount of less than €100,000. Furthermore, the Issuer has not registered the Notes under any other country’s securities laws and do not have any intention to do so. It is your obligation to ensure that your offers and sales of the Notes within the United States and other countries comply with applicable securities laws. See “Notice to Investors”. 84 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will initially only be issued in global certificated form and held through Euroclear and Clearstream. Interests in the global Notes will trade in book-entry form only, and Notes in definitive registered form, or definitive registered Notes, will be issued in exchange for book-entry interests only in very limited circumstances. Owners of book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of Notes. The common depositary, or its nominee, for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the global Notes representing the Notes. Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the global Notes representing the Notes will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, these payments will be credited to participants’ accounts that hold book-entry interests in the global Notes representing the Notes and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to the Paying Agent for onward payment to Euroclear and Clearstream, the Issuer will have no responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal or other amounts to the owners of book-entry interests. After payment to Euroclear and Clearstream, the Trustee and the Paying Agent will have no responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal or other amounts to the owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if investors own a book-entry interest, they must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream, and if investors are not participants in Euroclear and Clearstream, they must rely on the procedures of the participant through which they own their interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of Notes under the Indenture. Unlike the holders of the Notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon the Issuer’s solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes. Instead, if an investor owns a book-entry interest, it will be permitted to act only to the extent it has received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream. The procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies may not be sufficient to enable such investor to vote on a timely basis. Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until definitive registered Notes are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, if investors own book-entry interests, they will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. The procedures to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream may not be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Notes. See “Book-Entry, _Delivery and Form”._

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may not become, or may not remain, listed on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange.
Subsubsection Text: Although the Issuer intends to apply for the Notes to be admitted to the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and admitted to trading on its Euro MTF Market and to maintain such listing as long as the Notes are outstanding, the Issuer cannot assure you that the Notes will become or remain listed. If the Issuer cannot maintain the listing on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and the admission to trading on the Euro MTF Market or they determine that they will not maintain such listing, the Issuer may cease to make or maintain such listing on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange, _provided that they will use its commercially reasonable efforts to obtain and maintain the listing of the Notes on another recognized stock exchange, although there can be no assurance that the Issuer will be able to do so. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of listing on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange or another recognized listing exchange for comparable issuer in accordance with the Indenture, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting of the Notes from the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange or another listing exchange in accordance with the Indenture may have a material adverse effect on a holder’s ability to resell Notes in the secondary market.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: Either or both of the Floating Rate Notes and the Fixed Rate Notes may be issued with OID for U.S. federal income tax purposes. A holder of Notes issued with OID that is subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include the OID on such Notes in gross income (as ordinary income) as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such OID and regardless of such holder’s regular method of accounting for 85 ----- U.S. federal income tax purposes. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax _Considerations”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral
Subsubsection Title: You may face foreign currency exchange risks or other tax consequences as a result of investing in the Notes
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be denominated and payable in euro. If you are a U.S. investor, an investment in the Notes will entail foreign exchange-related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the euro relative to the U.S. dollar because of economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the U.S. dollar could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to U.S. investors on a U.S. dollar basis. Investing in the Notes by U.S. investors may have significant tax consequences with respect to exchange gain or loss. See “Certain _Tax _Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations.”_ 86 -----

An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. You should read and carefully consider the risks described below and the other information contained in this Offering Memorandum before making an investment in the Notes. Any of the following risks could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations and this, in turn, could adversely affect our ability to pay interest or principal on the Notes when due and cause you to lose all or part of your original investment. The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only ones we face. Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or that we currently deem to be immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. If any of those risks actually occurs, our business, financial condition and results of operations would suffer. This Offering Memorandum includes forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties and our actual results may differ substantially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. See “Forward-Looking Statements.”

On or prior to the Issue Date, the Issuer will enter into the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, which will provide for a New Revolving Credit Facility in the amount of €165.0 million. On the Issue Date, the New Revolving Credit Facility is expected to remain undrawn.

The Issuer, which is fully owned by the Parent and which will, as of the Issue Date, own all of the assets and liabilities currently owned by the Parent, does not produce consolidated financial statements. We present in this Offering Memorandum certain consolidated financial information for the Parent and its subsidiaries, as well as certain consolidated financial information for Burger King France S.A.S. and its subsidiaries. The Parent is as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, and will remain after the Issue Date, a holding company that conduct no business operations of its own and has no significant assets other than the equity interests and/or the intercompany receivables it hold in each of its direct and indirect subsidiaries. The material differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2024 of the Parent on a standalone basis under IFRS and the rest of the Group represents mainly (i) a standalone net current liabilities (excluding cash) of €2.8 million, (ii) cash and cash equivalents of €1.1 million, (iii) a positive standalone EBITDA equal to €0.2 million and (iv) a net financial income of €0.6 million. The material differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 of the Parent on a standalone basis under IFRS and the rest of the Group represents mainly (i) a standalone net current liabilities (excluding cash) of €3.1 million, (ii) cash and cash equivalents of €0.0 million, (iii) a positive standalone EBITDA for the Parent equal to €1.4 million and (iv) a net financial expenses of €(21.8) million. Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF THE PARENT
Subsubsection Text: Bertrand Franchise was created by Groupe Bertrand (founded and owned by Olivier Bertrand) in July 2023 to become the number one food service franchising platform in France with 7 brands (Burger King France, Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon, Pitaya, Volfoni and Itsu). During the second half of 2023, Groupe Bertrand sought to reinforce its growth strategy by improving the transparency and coherence of its various activities. To do so, Groupe Bertrand has reorganized its activities in order to distinguish two distinct and autonomous divisions: - Bertrand Hospitality, with exceptional places with unique know-how around 6 professions: Parisian restaurants & brasseries, tea rooms, luxury hotels, grocery stores & retail, events catering and an agritourism property located in Seine-et-Marne; - Bertrand Franchise, with strong brands that are developing as franchises around two positions: the fastfood industry with the master franchise Burger King for mainland France and La Réunion island and theme catering (Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon, Volfoni, Pitaya and the Itsu master franchise for France). 96 ----- To do so, Groupe Bertrand carried out the following legal reorganization: - On July 3, 2023, crossed contributions of assets took place between the parent company of Groupe Flo and the parent company of the Bertrand Restauration group (now Bertrand Hospitality). Following this reorganization, Groupe Flo owns a number of franchises, namely Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon and Volfoni. - On October 31, 2023, TopCo GB, of which Groupe Bertrand owned 60% and Bridgepoint the remaining 40% on that date, became head of the Group through acquisitions and contributions of 100% of the shares of Groupe Flo, United Lab, Miditsuco GB (the holding entity of the Itsu group), Holdco GB (the holding entity of the Pitaya group) and Bertrand Franchise Services (the holding entity of Bertrand Franchise Logistics), together with other controlled entities by Groupe Bertrand “Bertrand Casual Food”, which resulted in the issuance of 380,730 ordinary shares and 19,783 series A preferred shares. TopCo GB was renamed Bertrand Franchise (the “Parent”). - Prior to these contributions of shares, Groupe Flo had decided to divest the restaurants of its “Léon de Bruxelles” activity that did not fit into the makeover plan of the new “Léon fish brasserie” concept. In September 2023, the management of Bertrand Franchise confirmed its intention to divest this portion of its activities. Upon the acquisition of Groupe Flo, the Group recognized this activity as an activity acquired exclusively with a view to its subsequent disposal, in accordance with IFRS 5. - At the same time, as part of the development of the Parent, Groupe Bertrand, together with Bridgepoint, joined forces with landmark international partners. Groupe Bertrand and Bridgepoint welcomed two landmark international partners: AlpInvest and Goldman Sachs Asset Management (together referred to in this section as “United JVCO ltd”) to support the Parent’s next growth chapter. On October 31, 2023, United JVCO ltd subscribed preferred shares of the Parent for an amount of €458 million, which resulted in the issuance of 302,052 series B preferred shares. The cash inflows have been used to finance part of the group’s reorganization, as well as to repay in advance its convertible bonds subscribed by Bridgepoint. All of these entities and activities were and remain controlled by Groupe Bertrand, carried out by the head company of Groupe Bertrand’s Holding (“BH”). Alongside with the overall reorganization of the Group, on June 16, 2023, the Burger King France group purchased a majority share in the Burger King activity on the Island of Réunion (“BK la Réunion”), carried out by the companies S2FOI (which directly owns and operates 17 restaurants on the Island) and DISTRIFOOD.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF THE PARENT
Subsection Title: Context of preparation of an Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: As part of its operations of reorganization, The Parent wishes to carry out a global refinancing of the debts of the Burger King group and Groupe Flo. This operation would allow the Parent to facilitate the development of all its franchise activities but also to optimize the management of financial flows between the different Bertrand Franchise entities and brands. As described above, the reorganization was completed as of October 31, 2023. Consequently, the consolidated statements of financial position as of December 31, 2023, already reflects the full effect of the reorganization. Thus, the unaudited consolidated pro forma income statements have only been prepared for the following periods: - for the year ended December 31, 2023, see “-Pro Forma Consolidated Income Statement Data for the _year ended March 31, 2024”;_ 97 ----- - for the 3 months ended March 31, 2023, see “-Pro Forma Consolidated Income Statement Data for the _three months ended March 31, 2023”;_ - for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, see “-Pro Forma Consolidated Income Statement Data for _the twelve months ended March 31, 2024”;_ (the “Unaudited Pro Forma Income Statements”, and together with the related notes and basis of preparation, the “Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information”). The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information presented herein illustrates the reorganization of the Bertrand Franchise perimeter, assuming that all of the related operations took place on January 1, 2023. The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is presented for illustrative purposes and presents a situation by hypothetical nature. As a result, the hypothetical data included in the Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information may differ from the actual results of the Parent. The Unaudited Pro Forma Income Statements do not reflect any anticipated synergies, operating efficiencies, cost savings that may be achieved or any integration costs that may be incurred.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF THE PARENT
Subsubsection Text: The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is prepared on a voluntary basis in connection with a private placement and is not to be considered as prepared in accordance with or compliant with (i) Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 June 2017 on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading on a regulated market, and repealing Directive 2003/71/EC (the “Prospectus Regulation”) and (ii) Regulation S-X Article 11, Pro Forma Financial Information, as amended by the final rule, “Amendments to Financial Disclosures About Acquired and Disposed Businesses,” as adopted by the SEC on May 21, 2020 (“Article 11”). The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information is prepared on the basis of the accounting principles used for the audited consolidated financial statements of the Parent for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF THE PARENT
Subsubsection Text: The Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information was prepared using the following items: - the consolidated income statement of the Parent, prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted in the European Union; and - the IFRS contribution of Bertrand Casual Food and BK la Réunion (together referred as “the Acquired

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF THE PARENT
Subsection Title: Entities”, each entity of the Acquired Entities being individually an “Acquired Entity”) for the period
Subsubsection Title: IFRS contribution of Bertrand Casual Food and BK la Réunion
Subsubsection Text: The columns “IFRS contribution of Bertrand Casual Food” and “IFRS contribution of BK la Réunion” aim to reflect the contribution to the income statement for the period not included in the consolidated income statement of the Parent. 98 ----- The contribution of these entities is calculated as: - the IFRS contribution of the Acquired Entities for the entire period; - less the IFRS contribution of these Acquired Entities already included in the consolidated income statements of the Parent since the acquisition date (if any). None of the Acquired Entities have prepared consolidated financial statements that reflect all, or part of the scope of the reorganization. More specifically, because of the reorganization in July 2023 leading to crossed contributions of assets between Groupe Flo and Bertrand Restauration group, none of the consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2023, prepared by these sub-groups reflected the scope of the Acquired Entities. Consequently, statutory financial information for Acquired Entities was used as the basis of information (prepared under the generally accepted accounting principles in France (“French GAAP”)). Starting from this information, several adjustments to the statutory financial information have been compiled to form the IFRS contribution: _Mapping adjustments_ These adjustments have been performed to align all statutory financial information with the Parent consolidated income statement format. Statutory income statements are prepared using a classification by nature, whereas the Parent prepares a consolidated income statement using a classification by function. The mapping between these two formats has been performed using the nature of the account and the cost centers. _IFRS adjustments_ All statutory financial information being prepared in accordance with French GAAP, differences between French GAAP and IFRS have been adjusted, based on IFRS accounting rules and methods the Parent used for the preparation of its audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2023. Main IFRS adjustments are the followings: - leases: in accordance with IFRS 16, rental expenses recognized in statutory financial statements are restated, and a depreciation expenses on right-of use assets and interest expenses on lease liabilities are recognized. The interest expenses have been computed using the discount rate determined by the Parent at the acquisition date; - franchisee’s upfront fee: in French GAAP, the upfront fees paid for network access are fully recognized at the contract inception. In accordance with IFRS 15, network access is not distinct from the right to use the brand and know-how provided by the Group and therefore, upfront fees are spread over the duration of the franchise agreement; and - deferred tax: given that no deferred taxes are recognized in the statutory financial information, deferred taxes are hence recognized on temporary differences in accordance with IAS 12, using an effective tax rate of 25.82% for the financial year ended December 31, 2023. The deferred tax assets have been recognized only when the Group has determined that it is probable that future profit will be available, in accordance with the accounting policies and estimates used to prepare the consolidated financial statements of the Parent as of December 31, 2023. The tax consolidation scopes are aligned with the ones used in the consolidated financial statements, and no potential future tax consolidation reorganization has been reflected in this Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information. 99 ----- _Consolidation adjustments_ The entities having intercompany transactions over the entire period, consolidation adjustments were required. These aim to neutralize reciprocal operations between entities as well as any other internal operation (such as depreciation of securities or current accounts, internal profits, etc.), as if the actual scope (as described in the audited consolidated financial statements of the Parent) had existed on January 1, 2023. _Carve-out adjustments_ Among Groupe Bertrand and prior to the reorganization of Groupe Flo and the Bertrand Restauration group in July 2023, some entities included in these perimeters may have incurred costs and revenue that should be allocated to Bertrand Franchise business or to Bertrand Hospitality business. These entities are the following: Groupe Flo, Flo Gestion, Flo Formation, Concept restauration and OBH. An analysis has been performed in order to properly allocate the costs and revenue clearly applicable to the franchise business. Thus, the carve-out adjustments are the following: - the statutory financial statements of Groupe Flo for the period ended December 31, 2023 include the gain on disposal of the entities contributed to Bertrand Hospitality. As this gain is not related to the Parent business, it has been removed from the historical data; and - prior to the reorganization of Groupe Flo and the Bertrand Restauration group in July 2023, a Group Flo subsidiary, namely AGO, directly operated the “Brasserie des Champs” restaurant which has been transferred to the hospitality-related perimeter at the reorganization date. Therefore, all incomes and costs related to the “Brasserie des Champs” restaurant before the reorganization have been removed to reflect as if this carve-out had happened on January 1, 2023. The tax impact related to these carve-out adjustments has also been recognized. _IFRS 5 reclassification_ As described above and in the notes to the audited consolidated financial statements of the Parent for the year ended December 31, 2023, the Group recognized the restaurants of its “Léon de Bruxelles” activity that do not fit into the makeover plan of the new “Léon Fish brasserie” concept as an activity acquired exclusively with a view to its subsequent disposal, in accordance with IFRS 5. Therefore, the profit or loss related to these restaurants is presented separately from continuing activities on a dedicated line of the Unaudited Pro Forma Income Statements. Based on that information, reclassifications have been posted to reflect the result for these activities held for sale for the entire 12-month period.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF THE PARENT
Subsection Title: Entities”, each entity of the Acquired Entities being individually an “Acquired Entity”) for the period
Subsubsection Text: _Pro forma adjustments related to business combination_ The transactions related to the Acquired Entities have been accounted for using the acquisition method, in accordance with IFRS 3 - Business combinations, under which the Parent has been identified as the acquirer. The identifiable assets acquired, and liabilities assumed in the context of the business combination with the Acquired Entities have been recognized in the consolidated financial statements of the Parent as of October 31, 2023 at their fair value, being reminded that the allocation of the purchase price is considered provisional. 100 ----- All related depreciation and amortization are adjusted to reflect the incremental depreciation and amortization due to fair value adjustment as if the reorganization had happened on January 1, 2023. The additional depreciation and amortization expenses relate to franchisee agreements. The assumptions are aligned with those used for the consolidated financial statements. _Pro forma adjustments related to financing and related costs Adjustments related to the Bertrand Franchise convertible bond repayment_ As explained above, as part of the structuration of the Parent, United JVCO has subscribed preferred shares in an amount of €458 million that have been used to repay the convertible bond issued to Bridgepoint. The financial interests related to this convertible bond recognized in the historical consolidated financial statements have been restated as if the repayment had occurred on January 1, 2023. _Adjustments related to the financing of BK la Réunion acquisition_ In the context of the acquisition of BK La Réunion, financing through notes for an amount of €45 million subscribed in June 2023. The financial interests related to this debt have been calculated as if the notes had been issued on January 1, 2023. _Adjustments related to debt refinancing related to Groupe Flo and other subsidiaries_ In the context of the first reorganization step of Groupe Bertrand performed in July 2023, Groupe Bertrand has renegotiated the debts carried by Groupe Flo and the Bertrand Restauration group. As part of the first reorganization step performed in July 2023, the Groupe Flo state-guaranteed loans and EURO PP loans have been renegotiated under new terms and conditions. The adjustment consists in applying these new terms and conditions as if the renegotiation occurred as of January 1, 2023. Following the acquisition and the carve out of the entities formerly hold by Bertrand Restauration and OBH, some intragroup loans were transferred to Groupe Flo in July 2023. Similarly, in the context of the contribution of Groupe Flo shares to the Parent in October 2023, Groupe Bertrand also transferred the loans granted to Groupe Flo to the Parent. Prior to these transfers, the financial interests recognized in the income statement of the subsidiaries were recognized in the historical IFRS contribution as a transaction with a related party. The adjustment consists in assuming that these loans became intercompany transactions as of January 1, 2023, and in cancelling the related financial expenses. Lastly, in the context of the reorganization, Bertrand Corp granted a new loan to the Parent for an amount of €3.6 million in October 2023. The adjustment consists in assuming that this loan was implemented as of January 1, 2023, and in recognizing the related financial expenses. The financial interests have been adjusted as follows: - when the renegotiation implied a refinancing, the financial expenses related to the new financing agreement were recognized as if it was implemented as of January 1, 2023 and the financial expenses related to the previous financing agreements recognized in the historical financial statements were cancelled. When the new financing was based on a floating-rate, the interest expense was computed using the underlying floating-rate (but with the margin included in the financing agreement). 101 ----- - when the renegotiation resulted in a repayment without external refinancing (for instance, in case of intercompany loans with the Parent), the financial expenses related to the previous financing agreements recognized in the historical financial statements were cancelled. _Pro forma adjustments related to management fees with prior owners_ Before their acquisition by BK La Réunion, both Distrifood and SF2OI had contractual arrangements related to management fees with the prior owners. Since June 1, 2023, the management fees agreements with prior owners have been revised: a new management fees agreement has been concluded between BK la Réunion and the Parent, and the previous management fees agreement with the prior owners has been revised. The management fees expenses have been adjusted as if the renegotiation occurred as of January 1, 2023. _Adjustments related to tax impact_ The tax effects related to these adjustments are recognized in the Unaudited Pro Forma Income Statements using the effective tax rate. However, an analysis has been performed to identify whether the pro forma adjustment may affect the tax rate of the underlying entity. In particular, when the underlying entity is a loss-making entity for which no tax-loss carryforward has been recognized in the consolidated financial statements, the unrecognized tax-credit for the period is taken into account only if the tax adjustment requires an additional tax expense.

Subsubsection Text: For the purpose of reconciling _Pro Forma Financial Information in this section, EBITDA is defined as the operating profit/(loss) for this period, excluding the following income and costs: - other non-recurring income and expenses: they consist of unusual, abnormal, and infrequent items in the event that a major event occurring during the period is likely to distort the reading of performance. They may include, for example, restructuring costs, acquisition costs, charges to provisions in the context of lawsuits other than commercial and labor disputes, net income or losses on the disposal of intangible and tangible fixed assets related to the closure of restaurants, and impairment tests; and - depreciation and amortization (restaurants and corporate center).

Subsubsection Text: The Group uses alternative performance measures such as EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA to assess its operating performance, which facilitate the comparison of fundamental operating results from one period to another by eliminating the impact of its capital structure, asset base, and tax consequences. EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are non-IFRS measures; therefore, these measures and ratios may not be comparable to those used by other companies under similar names.
