Subsubsection Text: _The unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information set out below has been prepared to illustrate the effect of the 2023 Reorganization on the consolidated income statement of the Parent as if the related transactions took place on January 1, 2023. The Pro Forma Financial Information is presented for illustrative purposes and presents a situation hypothetical in nature. As a result, the hypothetical data included in this Pro Forma Financial Information may differ from the actual results of the Parent. The Pro Forma Financial Information reflects pro forma adjustments based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe to be reasonable. The assumptions and estimates underlying the Pro Forma Financial Information are described in the accompanying notes thereto, which should be read together with the Pro Forma Financial Information. The Pro Forma Financial Information should not be considered indicative of the actual position that would have been achieved had the 2023 Reorganization been consummated on the date indicated nor is it meant to be indicative of the Parent’s future financial position. Neither the assumptions underlying the preparation of the Pro Forma Financial Information, nor the resulting Pro Forma Financial Information have been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. The pro forma adjustments are based on the information available at the time of the preparation of this Offering Memorandum. The Pro Forma Financial Information has been prepared in a manner consistent with the accounting policies that have been applied to the Parent Annual Financial Statements. The Pro Forma Financial Information has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act, the Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. Neither the assumptions underlying the pro forma adjustments, nor the resulting Pro Forma Financial Information have been audited or reviewed. This section should be read in conjunction with the financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum as well as the disclosures provided under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Information Presented” and “Risk Factors—Risks related to our presentation of financial and other information”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are France’s leading multi-brand food service franchising platform, renowned for our diverse and strategically curated portfolio of market-leading restaurant brands. Our portfolio encompasses a variety of eight wellpositioned distinct restaurant brands that cater to a wide range of attractive food service market segments, from QSR to casual dining formats, addressing all-day consumption occasions, as illustrated in the graphic below. We own six out of the eight restaurant brands in our portfolio (Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon, Volfoni, Pitaya and Jôyô), while we are the master franchisee in France for the remaining two brands (Burger King and Itsu). Our network spans over 1,000 restaurants across attractive locations throughout France, partnering with 423 franchisees, who together operated 83% of our restaurant network as of December 31, 2023. The remaining 17% of our restaurant network was comprised of directly-operated company restaurants (the “Company

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Restaurants”). For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated €1,016.8 million in Pro Forma Run-
Subsubsection Text: Rate franchise sales and revenues and €318.8 million of Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate Normalized EBITDA reflecting a 31.4% Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate EBITDA margin. Our portfolio is diversified across cuisine styles and occasions and is operated mostly under a highly attractive franchise model through an efficient and synergistic platform. Our strength in identifying and responding to consumer preferences for cuisine, price point, format and channel through our various restaurant brand concepts has established us as a dominant player in the French food service industry. 110 ----- We have successfully scaled and grown our presence exponentially from 116 points of sale in 2010 to over 1,000 points of sale in 2023. In line with our continued growth, we have increased our SWS by a 12% CAGR over the 2019 to March 31, 2024 period. Our pace of growth is consistent, with between approximately 80 to 110 new restaurant openings every year over the 2019 to 2023 period and a strong pipeline of additional restaurant openings in the future. In recent years, our growth has been driven by the rapid expansion of our franchisee network through the opening of new franchise restaurants under both existing and newly developed or acquired brand concepts. We have namely experienced continued and steady growth with Burger King France (excluding Quick), the second largest QSR chain in France and for which we are the exclusive French master franchisee, representing approximately 51% of our restaurant network. As a result, we increased our total points of sale from 708 as of December 31, 2019 to 1,059 as of March 31, 2024, a large proportion of which was driven by growth in our franchised restaurants, increasing the total franchised portion of our restaurant network from 71% in 2019 to 83% on March 31. 2024. This growth had a strong corresponding impact on our _Pro Forma SWS, which increased from €1.7 billion for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €2.8 billion for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our Pro Forma Adjusted Normalized EBITDA also increased from approximately €254 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, according to management estimates, to €307.4 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We believe our brand portfolio approach provides significant scale and synergies across brands, allowing us to capitalize on our market-leading capabilities, as illustrated by the successful roll-out of the Burger King brand in France to improve the performance of Bertrand Casual Foods’ current and future restaurant brands. Our operational model is well-established, historically successful and designed to be replicable across our existing and future restaurant brands. We facilitate a platform driven approach by leveraging our know-how and a synergistic approach to enhance brand operations and performance across all areas and stages of development. We have a historically proven ability to execute rapid roll-out and expansion through our in-house dedicated restaurant network development team, as well as to implement in-house processes for newcomer brands, which involves upgrading operations to meet our group-wide standards, transitioning into the franchised model, diversifying cuisine offerings and redefining brand concepts to resonate with current market preferences that we know well. These strategic initiatives were implemented to improve the financial performance and brand positioning of our existing brands allowing us to grow the proportion of franchised restaurants. This transition into our franchise operational model generates more profitability per restaurant, increasing the average restaurant sales (“ARS”) generated by each brand. For example, as part of Léon’s recent conversion into Léon Fish Brasserie, we redefined its concept and food offering to appeal to a younger and broader customer base, revamped its digital loyalty program to increase customer engagement, and accelerated restaurant openings under the franchise model. Together, these efforts contributed to an increase in ARS, evidenced by a 42% difference between the ARS of €1.2 million generated by Léon restaurants that are not yet converted and €1.7 million generated by the converted Léon Fish Brasserie restaurants, in each case for the year ended December 31, 2023. At the core of our success is our franchise model, which is strategically crafted to be both asset-light and cash generative. We have two principal types of franchise arrangements: Franchise with Lease Management, our franchise model through which we generate additional revenues from real estate lease fees from our franchisees, and Pure Franchise. By focusing the majority of our network on franchising rather than direct restaurant operations, we limit our exposure to the day-to-day fixed costs and investments typically associated with running 111 ----- food service establishments. Instead, these capital expenditure responsibilities are supported by our franchisees, who invest in the assets and infrastructure necessary to operate their locations. This approach allows us to concentrate on providing unparalleled franchisee support, brand stewardship and strategic growth initiatives. Our franchisees benefit from a proven business model that offers the potential for robust returns, while we capitalize on stable and predictable revenue streams through royalty fees, advertising fees and, in the case of Franchise with Lease Management, leasing fees. In turn, our franchisees are contractually required to adhere to the meticulously crafted brand standards for the restaurants they operate, the absence of which can result in termination of our contracts with them. Our model ensures a mutually beneficial partnership that drives collective success across our network of brands. We continue to strategically maintain and operate a limited number of selected directly-owned Company Restaurants, which represented 17% of our restaurant network as of the year ended December 31, 2023. This approach provides us with a platform to pilot new marketing, menu and omni-channel innovations before rolling them out across our franchise network. It also allows us to establish a benchmark of operational success through exemplary models for our franchisees to emulate, showcasing best practices in management, customer service and quality product. While operating a limited number of Company Restaurants will remain a key strategic part of our portfolio for these reasons, we expect the proportion of Company Restaurants in our restaurant network to decrease over time.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Presentation of Financial and Other Information
Subsubsection Text: We present certain financial information herein with respect to our operating segments. In accordance with IFRS 8 – Operating Segments, our business is organized according to the following reporting segments: - Our _Burger King Group segment, which includes our Burger King brand, reflecting the Burger QSR operations in our portfolio; and - Our _Bertrand Casual Food segment, which includes our Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon, Volfoni, Pitaya, Jôyô and Itsu restaurant brands, reflecting our other casual dining operations in our portfolio that have similar characteristics.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Presentation of Financial and Other Information
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer, which is fully owned by the Parent and which will, as of the Issue Date, own all of the assets and liabilities currently owned by the Parent, does not produce consolidated financial statements. We present in this Offering Memorandum certain consolidated financial information for the Parent and its subsidiaries, as well as certain consolidated financial information for Burger King France S.A.S. and its subsidiaries. The Parent is as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, and will remain after the Issue Date, a holding company that conduct no business operations of its own and has no significant assets other than the equity interests and/or the intercompany receivables it hold in each of its direct and indirect subsidiaries. The material differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2024 of the Parent on a standalone basis under IFRS and the rest of the Group represents mainly (i) a standalone net current liabilities (excluding cash) of €2.8 million, (ii) cash and cash equivalents of €1.1 million, (iii) a positive standalone EBITDA equal to €0.2 million and (iv) a net financial income of €0.6 million. The material differences between the consolidated financial position and results of operations as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 of the Parent on a standalone basis under IFRS and the rest of the Group represents mainly (i) a standalone net current liabilities (excluding cash) of €3.1 million, (ii) cash and cash equivalents of €0.0 million, (iii) a positive standalone EBITDA for the Parent equal to €1.4 million and (iv) a net financial expenses of €(21.8) million. As a consequence, we believe that (A) the Parent’s consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2024 and (B) Burger King France’s consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2022, in each case subject to the differences noted above, adequately reflect what the Issuer’s consolidated financial results and financial position would have been for the applicable periods, in all material respects. The Parent will be the reporting entity under the covenants pursuant to the Indenture and the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. For further information, see “Description of the Notes.” 112 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Information Presented
Subsubsection Title: First set of IFRS-compliant financial statements
Subsubsection Text: The Bertrand Franchise Annual Financial Statements (including financial information for the year ended December 31, 2023, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2022) are the first consolidated financial statements that Bertrand Franchise has prepared, within the meaning of IFRS 1 – First-time Adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards. Such Bertrand Franchise Annual Financial Statements have been prepared on the basis of a date of first application as of January 1, 2022. On October 31, 2023, Bertrand Franchise acquired a number of subsidiaries previously held directly by Bertrand Franchise Corp. through a series of transactions (such transactions, together, the “2023 Reorganization”), with the aim to bring all franchise activities under a single entity. Prior to the legal reorganization, Bertrand Franchise (formerly Topco GB) acted as the parent company of Burger King France, while the remainder of the restaurant brands currently within the Bertrand Franchise perimeter were owned by Bertrand Franchise Corp. Pursuant to the 2023 Reorganization, on October 31, 2023, Bertrand Franchise (formerly Topco GB) expanded its ownership to acquire shares in Groupe Flo, Miditsuco GB, Holdco GB, Bertrand Franchise Services, United Lab and other entities controlled by Bertrand Franchise Corp. (together, the “Acquired Subsidiaries”), which held and operated the additional restaurant brands in our current portfolio. Bertrand Franchise thus became a platform for multisegment franchised restaurant brands. As a result of the 2023 Reorganization, the different entities acquired by Bertrand Franchise have been fully consolidated in the Parent Annual Financial Statements from October 31, 2023, reflecting a 2-month IFRS income statement contribution. As a result of the foregoing, the period-over-period comparisons included in the Betrand Franchise Annual Financial Statements are not comparable. The Parent Annual Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2022 reflect the contributions of Bertrand Franchise, Midco GB and Burger King France, which themselves reflect solely the financial performance of the Burger King France brand over such period. The Parent Annual Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2023 reflect the foregoing contributions, as well as the 7month contribution of BK La Réunion following its acquisition in June 2023 and the 2-month contribution of the Acquired Subsidiaries following their acquisition on October 31, 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Information Presented
Subsubsection Text: Set forth below are certain factors that affect the comparability of the financial information presented in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We generate revenue from our Franchise Restaurants through a structured franchise royalty and fee system, including brand royalties, entry fees, advertising fees and lease payments from lease management arrangements, which contributed significantly to our results of operations during the periods under review. Our franchisees are independent entrepreneurs who remunerate us by paying one-off entry fees upon the opening or conversion of their restaurants and through the payment of a certain percentage of their SWS as brand royalties. In the case of Burger King brand restaurants, we pay part of these brand royalties in turn to BK Europe. Moreover, for Franchise with Lease Management Restaurants, we also receive lease payments as a percentage of sales. As a result of our franchise arrangements, our results of operations and our profitability are significantly affected in a positive way when our franchisees are performing well. During the periods under review, our franchisor network grew in line with the further development and growth of the restaurant brands within our network. For more information on our franchise arrangements and royalties collected, see “Business—Our Operating Models—Franchise Restaurants”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Consumer preferences and societal trends, general economic conditions and consumer sentiment
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations during the periods under review have been, and in the future may continue to be, affected by changes in consumer preferences and societal trends. Among the most significant trends that have affected our results of operations is the increased prevalence of eating away from home as the habits of the French population begin to exhibit greater convergence with other Northern European countries. As a result, the restaurant industry has grown in line with this increase in out-of-home dining. Demographic, social and economic trends underlying this decline include profound shifts in the way people live, work and eat in recent decades that have accelerated with economic and technological changes. More people are living alone, which means that people are eating out alone, stopping to eat while in transit or getting together to eat outside the home as a social activity. In addition, more French households with children have dual incomes, meaning both parents are working and more likely to be on the go during the week and pressed for time on the weekends. Moreover, more French young people are working while pursuing their studies and therefore have comparatively more spending power than prior generations. These demographic, social and economic changes support the segment in which we operate, including the QSR and casual dining segments, as the price points are accessible, customer service delivery is geared towards efficiency and the portion sizes can be generous. Our results of operations are also influenced by changes in consumer preferences and trends regarding taste, packaging, ordering and customer service. To the extent we are able to maintain a fresh brand image, healthy and environmentally-conscious menu options and good reputation among consumers for products that appeal to them, our results of operations will be positively affected. Conversely, if we are unable to anticipate, identify and respond to such changes by evolving our product offering, menu customization options, portion sizing, pricing and other aspects of our business operations adequately and in a timely fashion, our results of operations may be adversely affected. We are constantly seeking to stay at the vanguard of consumer preferences through product offering and customer service, and have begun initiatives to better satisfy customer needs, for example through the improvements to our omni-channel offerings for our restaurant brands, including mobile apps, which facilitate the ordering of Click & Collect options, as well as customer loyalty programs. In addition, our results of operations are also affected to a degree by global economic conditions and specific local economic conditions in the markets and geographic areas in which we operate. Such conditions include levels of employment, disposable income, consumer confidence and consumer willingness to spend, which are influenced by a variety of factors, including gross domestic product and interest and inflation rates. During the periods under review, our results of operations were affected by the state of the French economy. According to INSEE, French GDP grew by 6.4% in 2021 (reflecting a rebound from the significant decrease in GDP in 2020 as a result of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic), 2.5% in 2022 and 0.9% in 2023. During periods of economic growth, consumers tend to eat outside the home more frequently, young people (an important demographic, particularly for the QSR sector), tend to have more disposable income and consumers generally tend to travel more often for work or leisure, all of which can lead to greater traffic in our restaurants and contribute to System-wide sales (“SWS”) generation. Conversely, during periods with unfavorable economic conditions characterized by stagnant or negative GDP growth and/or a decrease in disposable income, consumers may reduce the frequency with which 114 ----- they dine out or choose more inexpensive restaurants when dining away from home. Unfavorable changes in general economic conditions, therefore, can reduce customer traffic, as consumers may prefer to prepare food at home, or comparison shop for the best promotional deals from restaurants, which can reduce our total sales. Nevertheless, we believe that our positioning in the QSR segment with good value-for-money products mitigates the impact of potential changes in general and local economic conditions as this sector has historically been relatively resilient. In addition, customer traffic is a product of, among other things, consumer sentiment which can be affected by significant global or national events. Large-scale sporting or cultural events can encourage additional travel to certain regions by domestic and international tourists, which can drive traffic at certain restaurant locations where the event is held or on routes to such locations. Conversely, events such as terrorist attacks or civil disturbances such as prolonged labor strikes can negatively affect our results of operations and discourage customers from dining out, particularly if transportation networks are disrupted.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: One of the drivers of our results of operations is the size and evolution of our restaurant network. We have historically expanded our restaurant network through the conversion of restaurants operating under the existing Burger QSR brand, Quick, which we acquired in December 2015 and through the opening of new restaurants (both Company Restaurants and Franchise Restaurants) under the Burger King brand. Our historical strategy of converting acquired Quick restaurants into Burger King brand restaurants permitted us to accelerate our development of the Burger King brand in France, allowing us to convert a total of 226 restaurants into Burger King brand restaurants as of December 31, 2023. As of December 31, 2023, we no longer operate any Quick brand restaurants, while 2 remaining Quick brand restaurants are under conversion to Burger King brand restaurants (as compared to December 31, 2021, when we operated eight remaining Quick brand restaurants). Prior to the 2023 Reorganization, we organized our business in accordance with two segments: the Burger King brand and Quick brand. For further information, see the BK France Financial Statements, and the accompanying notes thereto, an English translation of which is included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. During the period under review, we continued to expand our restaurant network through the targeted expansion of our Burger King brand restaurants, including by the acquisition of 17 new Burger King brand restaurants located in La Réunion on June 16, 2023, upon the completion of the acquisition of 70% of the shares of Burger King La Réunion. In addition, during the period under review, the 2023 Reorganization was completed, whereby the Parent acquired a number of subsidiaries previously held by Bertrand Franchise Corp. These subsidiaries currently represent the Bertrand Casual Food reporting segment. Following the integration of additional restaurants into our perimeter as a result of the 2023 Reorganization, as of December 31, 2023, our perimeter included six additional restaurant brands, comprising 519 additional restaurants (including 98 Company Restaurants and 421 Franchise Restaurants). For further information, see “—Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Information _Presented—First set of IFRS-compliant financial statements.”_ As a result of the aforementioned changes, our network of restaurants expanded from 441 as of December 31, 2021 to 1,055 as of December 31, 2023. See “Business—Our Networks—Restaurant and Franchise Portfolio.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Mix of Company Restaurants and Franchise Restaurants in our network
Subsubsection Text: Our results and our margins are affected by the evolution of the mix between Company Restaurants and Franchise Restaurants in our network. Directly operating Company Restaurants adds additional costs to our structure, such as personnel costs and lease costs that we cannot ultimately recuperate, as compared to our Franchise Restaurants (notably with our Franchise with Lease Management restaurants, which allow us to charge our franchisees a lease management fee), generally resulting in a lower margin of SWS when compared to Franchise Restaurants. In addition, we generally incur capital expenditures and pre-opening costs with each new Company Restaurant, whereas due to franchise arrangements, the cash flow impact on the Group for adding a new Franchise Restaurant 115 ----- is more limited and the sales and margin impact may be significant. Additionally, the cost of converting a Franchise Restaurant is also more limited in terms of investment than opening a Company Restaurant, though the return in terms of additional royalties is significant. For the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2024 we opened 44, 44, 54 and 18 restaurants, respectively, of which one, three, seven and one were Company Restaurants. Over the same periods, we also converted a limited number of Quick brand restaurants into Burger King brand restaurants in 2021 and 2023. In 2021 we converted 20 Quick brand restaurants (of which only one was a Company Restaurant, while the other 19 restaurants were Franchise Restaurants), while in 2024 we only converted one Quick brand restaurant into a Burger King Franchise Restaurant. We generally record pre-opening or preconversion costs corresponding to costs incurred prior to the opening or conversion of a new restaurant, including, where applicable, staff costs, recruitment costs and training costs. During years with a high number of Company Restaurant openings, such costs may be unevenly distributed and disproportionally recorded during certain quarters before the sales uplift is experienced. This necessary network growth may affect certain cost items in our consolidated income statement as well as our cash flow related to investing activities in our consolidated cash flow statement. We expect this opening effect to continue to be recorded, though the mix of Company Restaurants opened will likely diminish over time as network expansion stabilizes. In addition, QSR and casual dining restaurant locations generally require a certain level of renovation and refurbishment roughly every seven to nine years, in order to maintain customer traffic. The following discusses the main trends discernable when examining the evolution of our network during the periods under review that affected our results of operations. The “novelty effect”, which we use to describe the strong sales performance experienced by newly-opened restaurants, which record high average restaurant sales (“ARS”) in their first few months of operations that are significantly higher than the ARS of other restaurants within our network. For example, this has historically been the case of our newly-opened or converted Burger King restaurants. We believe the novelty effect results from the strong brand equity that Burger King enjoys in the French market as a relatively newly-arrived challenger in a market long dominated by McDonald’s. Also contributing to this effect is Burger King’s strong value proposition characterized by good quality ingredients and great taste at accessible prices, which resonates with customers. As a result, Burger King restaurants register minimal ramp up time as the first month’s ARS has historically typically exceeded that of the entire Group perimeter. Factors that can affect the intensity and duration of the novelty effect include, among other things: - the number of restaurants in the catchment area (generally the novelty effect is more pronounced for the first restaurant); - the distance to competitor’s restaurants; - the demographics of the catchment area; and - the characteristics of the restaurant (i.e., city center, suburban area, shopping mall or drive-through location). The pace of the growth of our network has depended, and in the future will likely depend, on a combination of factors, including, among other things, the prioritization of certain clusters to achieve better network density in our restaurant network and decreased logistics costs, receipt of necessary permits and landlord consents, securing financing in the case of franchisees (as applicable) and discussions with franchisees. As a result, the restaurants opened or converted during the periods under review represent a mix of locations, categories and sizes, thereby producing non-uniform effects on our results of operations depending on the circumstances. 116 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our cost base is comprised of a mixture of variable, semi-variable and fixed costs. Variable costs primarily include food and logistics costs and selling costs. Operating and occupancy costs (comprising (i) costs incurred for the ordinary course operations of a restaurant, such as, for example, utilities, standard maintenance and repairs or security and (ii) rental costs and property taxes), as well as general & administrative expenses are mainly fixed costs, while personnel costs have both a fixed and semi-variable component. Personnel costs related to staff in Company Restaurants are semi-variable whereas personnel costs in connection with headquarters and Company Restaurants’ management are generally fixed. In the event of a decrease in SWS, we may not be able to reduce our cost base in a timely manner, in particular as it relates to our fixed costs, which could adversely impact our margins. However, in the event of an increase in SWS, we benefit from a strong operational leverage as SWS growth allows favorable scale effects. The following sections discuss the main factors affecting the principal items of our cost base. _Food and logistics costs_ Franchise Restaurants within our network are responsible for their own food and logistics costs as our franchise model is based on the outsourcing of food purchases and logistics services. Our franchisees work with a certain limited number of pre-approved suppliers that we have pre-approved for each brand, which allows us to retain a certain degree of consistent quality control across our brands as approval of suppliers is subject to our internal due diligence process. Our franchisees then are able to order raw materials and supplies independently and directly from our approved suppliers or logistics platform. In certain cases, they are able to order products directly from wholesalers or other suppliers. Our Burger King brand currently operates under its own separate pre-existing supply chain and procurement platform. Pursuant to our franchise agreements, Burger King operations are required to source raw materials from BKC-approved suppliers. As a result, all Burger King restaurants independently purchase supplies for their needs from approved suppliers. These purchases include food products and the paper and packaging materials for the sale of our products, as well as cleaning supplies and other products for the maintenance of equipment. We also have a certain number of separate pre-approved suppliers from which the rest of the brands in our network make purchases. In preceding years, we have developed a significant French network of approved suppliers, which has helped to control our logistics costs as a percentage of revenues as we no longer need to heavily rely on imports of raw materials and semi-finished goods from approved suppliers in neighboring European countries, such as Germany, the United Kingdom and Austria. We have also worked to capitalize on synergies for our existing brands to narrow down the pool of pre-existing suppliers (lowered from 19 to 9) and to standardize purchase prices across our brands (with the exception of Burger King which, as described above, operates under its own separate pre-existing supply chain and procurement platform). We have further managed our supply costs by implementing a purchasing strategy for raw materials which allows us to obtain price commitments from suppliers by giving them mid- to long-term visibility on volumes and growth in France. Moreover, we have entered into forward buying contracts with our suppliers, except for beef, which limit our exposure to any short term fluctuations in food prices. A typical forward buying contract provides for fixed prices for at least six months. In addition, we entered into mid- to long-term contracts with our strategic suppliers for beef, French fries, buns, chicken and beverages. This strategy allows us to have pricing visibility and minimize the impact of fluctuations in food and supply prices on our operations for the duration of these contracts. However, despite the above strategies to manage our supply costs, many of the principal ingredients that our restaurant brands use in preparing food are commodities and are subject to price volatility, notably beef. For our Burger King brand, we purchase all of our beef from suppliers that are strictly required to purchase beef only from the European Union, with a limited number of countries of origin (France, Germany and Austria). For our Burger King brand restaurants, nearly 50% of our beef came from France in 2023. As of March 31, 2024, 59% of our beef came from France. European beef prices are driven by the interplay of supply and demand dynamics. 117 ----- In addition, we seek to optimize spending on our logistics activity, which we manage through third parties. For the Burger King brand, procurement and logistics activities are outsourced and handled by QSL-STEF, a joint venture of QSL and STEF dedicated to the QSR sector. QSL-STEF purchases our food supplies and other raw materials from various suppliers. We contractually set certain targets and goals with QSL-STEF, which monitors our inventories and packaging in addition to ensuring that goods and materials reach our restaurants from their point of origin at an optimal cost and service level. Franchisees order their raw materials and supplies directly from QSL-STEF as an approved vendor. As we rely on QSL-STEF for coordinating logistics for all of our restaurants, we are able to negotiate favorable terms as a block and provide our Franchise Restaurants with the ability to achieve preferential price points, improving their overall results of operations. For the other restaurant brands in our portfolio, our logistics of key products are managed predominantly through third parties Transgourmet and Sysco. Where we can, we aim to centralize our product supply and logistics platform to streamline operational efficiency and manage costs. We expect food and logistics costs to decrease as the network grows and becomes more dense, as already historically demonstrated by the reduction in total number of suppliers for our brands and ability to lower and standardize costs through our network, further supporting our and our franchisees’ ability to meet customer demand with efficiency and reliability. Enhanced buying power owing to the growth of our network has helped, and potentially in the future can help, us to attain high standards of product quality and more competitive pricing. These factors can have positive effects on our customer proposition and the profit margins of our Company Restaurants, though we expect that they will not affect our franchise revenues since our royalties and lease payments are calculated as a percentage of their sales. An ancillary benefit of our cost reduction initiatives is that franchisees may have greater financial means to invest more quickly in a second or third restaurant. The effectiveness of our supply and logistics chain can also impact our costs of sales and administration expenses. See “Business—Operational Synergies of our Multi-Brand Franchise Model—Supply Chain and Procurement _Platform” for more information. Leasehold and occupancy costs_ We currently rent almost all of our Company Restaurants and our Franchise with Lease Management Restaurants through commercial or ground leases (as compared to restaurants operated as Pure Franchise where we do not incur any rent or rental costs). We are the tenant of record for both types of restaurants, though pursuant to our Franchise with Lease Management arrangements, the franchisee pays us a percentage of sales for rent, generally with a fixed minimum. Franchise with Lease Management arrangements, discussed in more detail under “Business—Our Operating Models—Franchise Restaurants” require us to be liable for the rent payment. However, not only do they provide us with control over the real estate, but the percentage of sales paid by the franchisee compensates us for our ownership and management of the business assets rights (fonds de commerce) and covers the underlying leasehold costs. Franchise with Lease Management restaurants represented approximately 47% of our Franchise Restaurants as of December 31, 2023. Our Franchise Restaurants operating under Franchise with Lease Management arrangements pay us for the use of the real estate through a lease management fee based on a percentage of SWS, typically subject to a minimum yearly rent that coincides with our fixed costs under the relevant lease. As a result, when such restaurants perform well, our leasehold costs improve as a percentage of our revenues, which grow from higher fees as a percentage of franchisee SWS. Our leases generally contain an annual increase pursuant to an indexation clause that is based on, among other things, inflation. The agreed index must have some connection with the activity carried out by one of the parties or to the purpose of the lease. The majority of our leases are based on the Commercial Rent Index (ILC) (indice _des loyers commerciaux) published by l’Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques (INSEE), the_ French public statistics institute. See “Business—Real Estate”. Increases in our leasehold and occupancy costs occur when we open new Company Restaurants and Franchise with Lease Management restaurants. Opening new restaurants also has the effect of increasing restaurant overhead more broadly with additional rent, fixtures, insurance and other costs. Certain restaurant locations, particularly in transportation locations and at large shopping malls, may have a variable rent set at a percentage of sales, typically with a certain minimum rent. To manage leasehold and occupancy costs, we focus on site selection, the right-sizing of the restaurant, and the negotiation of leases that are realistic in terms of the sales that such location can generate. In this process, we are 118 ----- informed by the data from our other restaurants and we are guided by conservative guidelines for rent as a percentage of sales. We rely on the extensive experience of our in-house development team, which has developed a standardized network development and roll-out process for site sourcing, development and construction. Over the course of the periods presented, we managed 483 restaurant openings between 2019 to 2023 across several restaurant brands. See “Business—Restaurant Development”. We recognize our leasehold and occupancy costs pursuant to the accounting rules under IFRS 16, which primarily affect the accounting for our operating leases. IFRS 16 (Leases), which the IASB published on January 13, 2016 and which have applied from its mandatory adoption date of January 1, 2019, eliminates the distinction between operating and finance leases, and requires almost all leases to be recognized on the balance sheet. Under this standard, an asset (the right to use the leased asset) and a financial liability, measured as the net present value of future lease payments, are recognized. Under IFRS 16, we as lessee recognize assets corresponding to the right to use the underlying leased asset for the estimated term of the lease, as well as liabilities corresponding to the discounted obligation to make lease payments for substantially all leases. _Labor costs_ In addition to the cost of our headquarters staff and management, we hire employees directly for our Company Restaurants, while franchisees are responsible for their own labor costs. Labor costs primarily comprise the salaries of team members employed in individual restaurants plus managers and restaurant directors. The QSR and casual dining categories are labor-intensive, which is compounded by the fact that pursuant to French law and applicable collective bargaining agreements, our ability to make use of part-time work and require overtime is limited to certain prescribed thresholds. Though labor costs are largely fixed, restaurants directors and managers receive a variable component of their compensation based on ARS and other performance indicators such as profitability and respect of brand standards (e.g., quality and service). During the periods under review, as our restaurant network expanded, we regularly made new hires for new Company Restaurants and for our general & administrative structure to gear for growth, and our results of operations reflect the integration of such employees into our cost structure, although labor costs as a percentage of total Company Revenue slightly decreased in December 31, 2023 as a result of lower levels of labor costs in the new Company Restaurants that we acquired in La Réunion. Additionally, a portion of pre-opening costs generally includes employee wages as staff must complete training prior to the opening of the relevant Company Restaurant. The QSR and casual dining segments generally have a high turnover among team members, which can increase training costs and reduce productivity, but gives us some flexibility to adapt the staffing level to the level of sales through attrition when sales decrease. We seek to manage labor costs based on right sizing the staff for each Company Restaurant according to restaurant size and the expected footfall informed by similarly situated restaurants. For our Burger King brand restaurants, we also focus a portion of our new restaurant development efforts on originating drive-through locations which tend to be more efficient from a labor-cost point of view because of the higher traffic that easily absorbs the additional staff cost. For new restaurant openings, applicable collective bargaining agreements for the fast food sector allow us to use short-term contracts and part-time work, which helps us to accommodate the higher footfall trends during the novelty effect period and also ensure the correct staffing level for the particular restaurant. We also manage team members on short-term contracts by attrition, given the high turnover in the QSR segment. We focus on internal promotion of restaurant managers from the ranks of team members.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our sales and margins can be impacted by the relative success of new products launched. The success of new menu items launched in our restaurant brands is attributable to a variety of factors, including the attractiveness and taste of the product, suitability of the product to changing consumer preferences, perceived product quality, alignment of new menu initiatives with brand image and customer expectations and competition from other comparable products launched by our competitors. Launch of a successful new product or an in-demand limited time offer can result in a sales uplift by encouraging additional orders from our customers. Conversely, a lack of new product offerings, an unsuccessful product or an incomplete roll-out of a new product can decrease sales if customers are not satisfied. Examples of new products during the period under review are the launch of our veggie range for the Burger King brand. 119 ----- Brand recognition is another factor that can affect results of operations for the restaurants operating under our various brands. Positive associations regarding product quality, service and value for money, among other factors, can help consumers make a decision regarding which restaurant to patronize. We centralize our brand management to a dedicated internal team that seeks to reinforce brand differentiation by clearly defining brand concepts to allow for consistent messaging and quality across each of our brands, enhancing brand recognition and awareness. When we integrate a new restaurant brand in our portfolio, we focus on improving its brand concept by aligning its menu, products and pricing architecture to our assessment of its target market. This process has historically generated improvement in our newcomer brands.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: In order to spread awareness of the restaurant brands in our portfolio, we use three levels of advertising: (i) systemwide advertising, which is coordinated and centralized in our headquarters outside of Paris; (ii) digital and social media advertising; and (iii) local advertising, which franchisees handle with materials we create or approve. We invest annually in innovative and creative multimedia advertising campaigns. Our advertising expenses are partly financed by our franchisees, who are required under the terms of their franchise agreements to contribute a percentage of sales (between 1.0% to 3.5% of SWS annually depending on the brand and franchise arrangement) as advertising fees, which we then use to market, advertise and promote initiatives and programs for the brands they are part of. Restaurants’ SWS and results of operations can be significantly affected by the frequency and effectiveness of our advertising and promotional programs. During the periods under review, we prioritized the development and consistent presence of social media, targeted digital marketing and efficiency loyalty programs. We have focused on creating videos for sharing on social media outlets such as YouTube, Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat, Twitter and Facebook, which we believe are the most effective ways to reach our customers as well as engage in influencer marketing. We closely monitor the marketing spending and frequency of our competitors’ advertising and promotion campaigns and endeavor to maintain a relatively constant investment in order to maintain an appropriate communication presence.

Subsubsection Text: Set forth below are certain key factors that historically have affected our results of operations, and which may impact our results of operations in the future. 113 -----

Subsubsection Text: The number of restaurants consists of the total restaurants open at the relevant date, including both Company Restaurants and Franchise Restaurants. The number of restaurants is a good indicator of market penetration, the density of our network and our ability to successfully expand our network. 120 ----- The following table presents the number of restaurants in our network by brand and type of restaurant as of December 31, 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In assessing the performance of our business, we consider a variety of performance and financial measures. The key measures for determining how our business is performing are the number and type of restaurants in our network, Average Restaurant Sales (“ARS”) and Adjusted Run-rate EBITDA performance. Such indicators are either purely operational in nature, include financial information not derived from the Group’s accounting system (i.e., SWS includes sales recorded by franchisees and not revenues received by the Group) and/or are not recognized measurements of financial performance under IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and Other _Information—Non-IFRS Financial Information”._

Subsubsection Text: Average Restaurant Sales (“ARS”) refers to the annualized monthly average sales (excluding VAT) recorded per restaurant for the given sample size calculated by: (i) adding all monthly sales generated for the restaurant sample, but excluding (a) the month in which the opening of any restaurant occurred (as applicable) or (b) the month in which any restaurant has closed for more than seven days; (ii) dividing by the number of restaurant months to attain the ARS per month; and (iii) multiplying the ARS per month by 12 to annualize it. ARS is largely driven by footfall, which is in turn generated by a variety of factors, including but not limited to, location of the restaurants, product attractiveness, brand equity, consumer preferences, societal trends, general economic conditions, consumer sentiment, weather, opening hours, marketing, digital presence and promotional activity and limited time offers. See “—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations”. We use ARS to assess and compare the performance of restaurants by type and brand across periods. ARS is also used as a benchmark to compute the variable compensation component for restaurant directors, restaurant 121 ----- managers and team leaders if the relevant Company Restaurant out-performs. We track ARS as a key performance indicator for the Burger King network and to reduce the impact of the novelty effect in our internal reporting. Management believes that ARS is the most useful indicator to assess the sales generation of the Burger King network. The table below sets forth the ARS evolution for the periods indicated.

Subsubsection Text: We define the Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate Normalized EBITDA as the _Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, as adjusted for the full-period effect of Burger King Group and Bertrand Casual Food restaurants newly opened, converted or temporarily closed for conversion during the relevant period as if they had been operational during the entire twelve-month period. Neither Adjusted EBITDA nor Adjusted Run-Rate Normalized EBITDA is a recognized measure of financial performance or liquidity under IFRS. Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted Run-Rate Normalized EBITDA are not indicative of our historical operating results, nor are they meant to be predictive of potential future results. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We calculate Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate Normalized EBITDA in the following manner: (a) Represents adjustments to reflect the normalization of energy costs resulting from the increase in energy prices since 2022. (b) Represents the restaurant EBITDA of the Burger King restaurants that were either opened or converted during a twelve-month period, and which generated an EBITDA during the year ended December 31, 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, respectively. (c) Represents the restaurant EBITDA of the Burger King restaurants that were opened or converted during the twelve-month period as if they were operational during the period. To do so, we calculate a case-by-case estimate of the sales that would have been generated in a twelve-month period for each restaurant. We then apply this ARS to the restaurants in the sample by applying a cost margin or EBITDA margin, as applicable, to the estimated ARS based on the type of restaurant included in the sample, as follows:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Company Restaurants: for the six new Burger King Company Restaurants opened or converted in the sample, we apply a
Subsubsection Text: cost margin to the estimated ARS, calculated on the basis of the actual restaurant costs of the entire Burger King Company Restaurant network; and

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Franchise Restaurants: for the 38 new Burger King Franchise Restaurants opened or converted in the sample, we apply an
Subsubsection Text: EBITDA margin to the estimated ARS, calculated on the basis of the underlying franchise arrangement of each model, i.e., brand royalties for Pure Franchise Restaurants (representing the net amount collected after BK Europe’s royalties); and brand royalties and lease and business asset fees for Franchise with Lease Management Restaurants. (d) Represents the restaurant EBITDA of former Quick restaurants that were either converted into Burger King restaurants, definitively closed or disposed as of December 31, 2023, and March 31, 2024, respectively, and which generated EBITDA during the year ended December 31, 2023, and the twelve-month period ended March 31, 2024, respectively. (e) Represents the restaurant EBITDA of any restaurants that changed their operating model during a twelve-month period, and then estimate their restaurant EBITDA as if they had their new operating model during a twelve-month period. The new EBITDA restaurant estimations are calculated on the basis of the assumptions underlying the EBITDA estimations for each operating model described under the third step above. Based on the changes to their operating models during the period, we applied these calculations to one Burger King Company Restaurant which transferred into a Franchise Restaurant under Lease Management and two Burger King Franchise Restaurants which transferred into Company Restaurants over the year ended December 31, 2023. (f) Represents, in order to account for contractual changes in lease management rates for our Franchise Restaurants (i.e., as a result of progressive rates applied according to the year of openings), the amount of franchise revenues generated by the lease management rate of these franchise restaurants with changed lease management rates during the year ended December 31, 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, respectively, and then apply the lease management rates under the current franchise agreements as of December 31, 2023, and March 31, 2024, respectively. (g) Represents run-rate adjustments (using the same methodology as presented in paragraphs (b) to (f) above) applicable to Bertrand Casual Food, as well as the run-rate effect (based on the same methodology as presented in paragraphs (b) to (f) above) applicable to Bertrand Casual Food of revenues generated by our commercial cooperation agreements with third-party brands such as beverage brands.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: IFRS consolidated financial statements require management to make estimates based on assumptions that may have an impact on the value of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and income of the period. For further information about such estimates and assumptions, see the full consolidated Financial Statements and the notes thereto prepared in accordance with IFRS, free English translations of which are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Franchise sales and revenues comprise: (i) sales of products and services through Company Restaurants; (ii) brand royalties and other income billed to franchisees; (iii) sales of goods and equipment to franchisees; (iv) entry fees and other sales, corresponding to network access and entry fees invoiced to franchisees, as well as certain services 123 ----- invoiced to third party partners, notably under property development contracts; (v) impacts on revenues from customer loyalty programs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Franchise royalties include: (i) brand royalties in respect of operating rights for the brands in our portfolio; (ii) advertising royalties received for franchisees’ contribution to each respective brand’s advertising budget; and (iii) lease management fees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Consumer sales comprise revenue from sales of food products sold in Company Restaurants and related food catering services.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Title: Sales of goods and equipment to franchisees
Subsubsection Text: Sales of goods and equipment to franchisees comprises revenue from sales of goods and equipment to franchisees, recognized when control of the goods is transferred to the franchisees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Entry fees are fees invoiced to franchisees in return for the transfer of know-how, use of restaurant brands, territorial exclusivity and associates with opening restaurants. Other sales mainly comprise revenues from ongoing real estate development projects recognized and supplier listing services (mainly in connection with QSL and STEF providers, the procurement and logistics providers for our Burger King brand).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Loyalty programs include the loyalty points awarded to consumers in proportion to their restaurant purchases. These points create a right to receive goods or services at a later date at a reduced price or free of charge.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales comprises (i) the cost of supplies and goods (including the cost of raw materials and goods required to manufacture finished products sold to customers; the cost of raw materials, goods and equipment sold by us to franchisees; the cost of materials and services required to manufacture services sold to third party partners; and other costs corresponding mainly to property development contracts); (ii) restaurant staff costs (including costs corresponding to payroll costs, employer charges and benefits paid to employees); and (iii) costs of other sales to non-franchisee partners.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Title: Operating and occupancy costs (excluding depreciation and amortization)
Subsubsection Text: Operating and occupancy costs (excluding depreciation and amortization) include primarily energy costs, maintenance costs and taxes (including property taxes). 124 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation and amortization (restaurants) correspond to the depreciation of fixed assets linked to Company Restaurants, as well as rights to use operational leases where we act as lessee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Selling costs consists mainly of advertising and marketing costs incurred for Company Restaurants, as well as the contribution of sites operated under franchise agreements through national advertising fees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Brand royalties consist of payments (i) made to BK Europe for our own account with respect to Burger King brand Company Restaurants pursuant to the Company Franchise Agreement, or collected from franchisees pursuant to the Master Franchise Agreement, and, in each case, are based on a percentage of sales from Burger King brand restaurants and (ii) made to Itsu Limited in connection with restaurants operating under the Itsu brand.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Pre-opening costs consists of costs incurred prior to the opening of a new restaurant, including staff costs during the training period, staff recruitment costs, any rental costs paid to lessors, advertising costs incurred for the opening of the establishment and the initial allocation of small non-depreciable items of equipment necessary for the smooth running of the establishment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Other operating income and expenses mainly include (i) capital gains or losses on disposals of fixed assets in connection with franchises or real estate transactions and (ii) charges to / reversals of expected impairment losses on trade receivables.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Title: General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization)
Subsubsection Text: General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization) consist of headquarters related costs, including headquarters’ salaries, costs of our training program, travel expenses, external services, insurance and rent for our headquarters’ premises.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation and amortization (corporate center) consist of regular depreciation on headquarter-related equipment (in particular, furniture, fixture and IT equipment), facilities and IT intangible assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Other corporate income/(expenses) consists primarily of damage and work injury insurance costs. 125 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Other non recurring income and expenses consists of all exceptional income and expenses, including (i) exit indemnities or disposals following the definitive closure of a restaurant and other closure related costs, (ii) risks and charges provisions allowances, (iii) assets impairment test provisions, allowances or reversals, as well as (iv) conversion costs not capitalized. Impairment tests are realized on a site by site basis based on the current year performance and on the anticipated results and carried out at three levels: (1) at the level of each cash generating unit (i.e., each individual restaurant, whether operated as a Company Restaurant or Franchise Restaurant), (2) at the level of brands (by way of annual test) and franchise contracts (in the event of a loss of value index) and (3) at the level of each cash generating unit group corresponding to each of our business segments. In addition, writeoffs in connection with restaurants’ definitive closures or conversions are booked under this line item. There can be no assurance that items we have identified as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Financial expense mainly consists of debt interest expenses and amortized financing costs. Financial income consists of income from investments and cash deposits.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Bertrand Franchise
Subsubsection Text: Income tax include both corporate income taxes and the _Cotisation sur la valeur ajoutée_ _des entreprises (or CVAE) related costs. Income tax also includes current and deferred taxes, including the impact of changes in tax rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Burger King France
Subsubsection Text: Sales and franchise revenues consists of Company Restaurant revenues, Franchise revenues and other revenues.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Burger King France
Subsubsection Text: Company Restaurant revenues consists of sales, net of rebates, discounts and VAT and other sales taxes, generated by Company Restaurants.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Burger King France
Subsubsection Text: Franchise revenues are based on a percentage of sales reported by Franchise Restaurants and consists of (i) royalty fees for franchisees under both Pure Franchise and Franchise with Lease Management agreements, (ii) lease and business assets rights (fonds de commerce) fees paid to us by franchisees pursuant to Franchise with Lease Management arrangements and (iii) fees paid to us for national marketing by Franchise Restaurants. 126 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Burger King France
Subsubsection Text: Other revenues consists of (i) other revenues invoiced to franchisees (predominantly entry fees); (ii) accounting of our loyalty program; (iii) fees paid to us by third-party partners, in exchange for services rendered by our headquarters, mainly in relation to supply and logistics activities; (iv) logistics revenues invoiced to franchisees; and (v) beginning in 2020, revenues invoiced to various stakeholders in relation to our property development “Contrat de Promotion Immobilière” activity (“CPI”). This property development activity offers construction services for certain restaurant facilities to third-party lessors to be used to open new Burger King restaurants. The restaurants built pursuant to these services for third-party lessors are then subsequently rented by Burger King. Costs related to these property development revenues are booked in “Other costs”.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Burger King France

Subsubsection Text: Company Restaurant labor costs primarily consists of wages and salaries paid to Company Restaurants’ directors, managers and team members. In addition, personnel costs also cover social security charges as well as health insurance and other employee benefits. All tax reductions related to salaries are netted from labor costs.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Burger King France

Subsubsection Text: Depreciation and amortization (restaurants) consists of regular depreciation on equipment (in particular furniture, fixture and IT equipment in restaurants), as well as on buildings. Land is not amortized.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items for Burger King France
Subsubsection Text: Selling costs consists mainly of (i) national advertising campaigns, financed both by Franchise Restaurants and Company Restaurants through a fee based on SWS (recognized as “franchise revenues” where such costs were financed by Franchise Restaurants), (ii) local advertising expenses and (iii) the Group’s contributions to national advertising costs (when the fees collected from Company Restaurants and Franchise Restaurants do not entirely cover the related advertising costs incurred). 127 -----

Other operating income also includes capital gains or losses on disposals of fixed assets in connection with franchises or real estate transactions.
