Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: For the three months ended March 31, 2023** **2024** **change** **% change (€ in millions, except percentages)
Subsubsection Text: Burger King Group ............................................................... 431.7 482.7 51.0 11.8% Bertrand Casual Food ............................................................ — 206.5 206.5 — Franchise sales and revenues ........................................ 162.5 242.6 80.1 49.3% Cost of sales ................................................................. (53.5) (85.6) (32.2) 60.2% Other operating income and expenses .......................... 0.1 1.5 1.4 1400.0% Franchise royalties .......................................................... 81.5 100.3 18.8 23.1% Consumer sales ............................................................... 61.2 121.1 59.9 97.9% Sales of goods and equipment to franchisees .................. - 6.0 6.0 Entry fees and other sales ................................................ 19.9 15.5 (4.4) (22.1)% Loyalty programs ............................................................ - (0.3) (0.3) **Total Franchise sales and revenues ..............................** **162.5** **242.6** **80.1** **49.3% Franchise royalties increased by €18.8 million, or 23.1%, to €100.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €81.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase was mainly driven by the increase in sales under the Burger King brand, as well as the 2023 Reorganization. Consumer sales increased by €59.9 million, or 97.9%, to €121.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €61.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase was largely driven by the opening of nine new Burger King restaurants, the acquisition of Burger King La Réunion with 17 restaurants, the contribution of a 112 new restaurants operated by Bertrand Casual Food (of which 104 following the contribution of Groupe Flo dated October 31, 2023, and eight from restaurant openings). This increase was partially offset by four permanent closures of restaurants operated by Bertrand Casual Food and the transfer of operations to franchise partners of three restaurants belonging to the Burger King Group scope, and two restaurants belonging to the Bertrand Casual Food scope, all five previously operated directly by the Group. Entry fees and other sales decreased by €4.4 million, or 22.1%, to €15.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €19.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This decrease is mainly due to the number of Burger King restaurants finalized or under construction via real estate development contracts and the activity linked to Bertrand casual Food brought in at October 31, 2023. 130 ----- _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by €32.2 million, or 60.2%, to €85.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €53.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. The following table sets forth a breakdown of the cost of sales of the Group for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024. Cost of supplies and goods .................................................... (35.3) (45.6) (10.3) 29.2% Restaurant staff costs ............................................................. (18.1) (40.1) (22.0) 121.6% Cost of sales..........................................................................** **(53.5)** **(85.7)** (32.2) 60.2% Over the period, the increase in cost of suppliers and goods was mainly driven by (i) the reorganization on October 31, 2023, with the Bertrand Casual Food integration, (ii) the activity of restaurants operated directly by the Group and linked to consumer sales, and (iii) inflation in raw material costs in 2023. This increase is partially offset by lower costs for real estate development contracts, in connection with the slowdown in this activity in the three months ended March 31, 2024 (9.2 million euros in the first quarter of 2024 compared with 17.1 million euros in the first quarter of 2023 for the Burger King brand). _Operating and occupancy costs (excluding depreciation and amortization)_ Operating and occupancy costs increased by €8.4 million, or 62.7%, to €21.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €13.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly due to the increase in the number of restaurants within our perimeter following (i) the BK La Réunion acquisition which occurred in 2023 and (ii) the 2023 Reorganization. _Depreciation and amortization (restaurants)_ Depreciation and amortization (restaurants) increased by €11.5 million, or 57.5%, to €31.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €20.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly due to the increase in the number of restaurants within our perimeter following (i) the BK La Réunion acquisition which occurred in 2023 and (ii) the 2023 Reorganization. _Selling costs_ Selling costs increased by €5.6 million, or 42.1%, to €18.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €13.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly due to the increase in the number of restaurants within our perimeter following (i) the BK La Réunion acquisition which occurred in 2023 and (ii) the 2023 Reorganization. _Brand royalties_ Brand royalties increased by €2.4 million, or 12.2%, to €22.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €19.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly due to the increase in Burger King’s SWS. 131 ----- _Pre-opening costs_ Pre-opening costs remained stable at €0.5 million over the two periods. _Other operating income/(expense)_ Other operating income increased by €1.4 million to €1.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €0.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly due to a €1.3 million increase in disposal gains on assets, to €1.3 million for the three month period ended March 31, 2024, from nearly zero for the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. _General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization)_ General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization) increased by €13.8 million, or 109.5%, to €26.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €12.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly due to (i) the BK La Réunion acquisition which occurred in 2023 and (ii) the 2023 Reorganization, (iii) understaffing during the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 and (iv) the increase in activity triggered by the development of new projects, which led to higher external service costs. _Depreciation and amortization (corporate center)_ Depreciation and amortization (corporate center) increased by €0.3 million, or 21.4%, to €1.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €1.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly due to (i) the BK La Réunion acquisition which occurred in 2023 and (ii) the 2023 Reorganization. _Other corporate income and expenses_ Other corporate expenses increased by €1.8 million to €1.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from nil for the three months ended March 31, 2023. Other corporate expenses in the three months ended March 31, 2024 mainly relate to capital gains on disposals linked to restaurant network management operations. _Other non-recurring income and expenses_ Other non-recurring expenses increased by €1.5 million to €1.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €0.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly attributable to restaurant closing costs. _Net financial income/(expense)_ Net financial expense increased by €4.0 million, or 13.3%, to €34.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €30.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase is mainly due to: - the additional €45 million of Existing Senior Secured Notes, generating an increase in interest on bond debt in the fiscal year ended December 31, 2023. This additional amount has not been hedged by interest rate instruments. However, the Group benefited from higher investment income than in the previous year, offsetting the rise in interest expense in the fiscal year ended December 31, 2023; - the repayment of interest on the Parent’s convertible bonds, which took place on October 31, 2023 as part of the 2023 Reorganization; 132 ----- - interests on the bond and financial debt of the Groupe Flo and Pitaya business combinations from October 31, 2023; - the increase in interest on IFRS 16 debt explained by the business combinations of Groupe Flo and Pitaya; - the increase in IFRS 16 debt linked to the signing of new contracts and the opening of new restaurants over the period; and - and the increase in interest rates over the fiscal year ended December 31, 2023. _Income tax_ Income tax decreased by €1.3 million, or 43.3%, to €1.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €3.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This decrease is mainly due to the decrease in the effective corporate income tax rate between the two periods following the change in perimeter following the 2023 Reorganization. _Share of profit/(loss) of companies consolidated using the equity method_ Share of profit/(loss) of companies consolidated using the equity method remained stable at nearly zero over the two periods. _Net profit/(loss) for the period_ As a result of the foregoing factors, net loss for the period decreased by €4.1 million, or 83.7%, to €0.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024 from €4.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023.

This increase in network sales for the Burger King Group was predominantly driven by the opening of 44 new Burger King brand restaurants (38 of which were Franchise Restaurants), enhanced by the acquisition of 17 new Burger King brand restaurants located on La Réunion island, targeted price increases as a result of a high inflationary environment and the development of new offers and successful marketing campaigns. In addition, the increase in SWS over the periods was also partly due to the French government phasing out the requirement for the COVID-19 related sanitary pass, which was compulsory to dine-in restaurants until March 2022. 133 ----- _Results of operations_ The following table sets forth the consolidated results of operations of the Group for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023. Subsubsection Text: _Franchise sales and revenues_ Franchise sales and revenues increased by €174.6 million, or 29.4%, to €769.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, from €594.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The following table sets forth a breakdown of our franchise sales and revenues of the Group for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Over the period, the increase in total franchise sales and revenues was largely driven by the increase of restaurant brands within the Bertrand Franchise perimeter following the 2023 Reorganization, which added 519 additional restaurants as of October 31, 2023 (including 104 Company Restaurants and 415 Franchise Restaurants) to the 134 ----- perimeter through the Acquired Subsidiaries. In addition, the increase was driven by other changes to our network, including the opening of 44 new Burger King brand restaurants, five Au Bureau brand restaurants, one Hippopotamus brand restaurant, one Léon Seafood and Cocktail brand restaurant, one Volfoni brand restaurant and two Pitaya brand restaurants (38, five, one, zero, one and two of which were Franchise Restaurants, respectively) and the acquisition of 17 new Burger King brand restaurants located on La Réunion island. This increase was partially offset by 17 permanent closures of restaurants, of which one operated under the Burger King brand as a Franchise Restaurant, six operated under the Quick brand (of which four operated as Franchise Restaurants), one operated under the Au Bureau brand as a Franchise Restaurant, one operated under the Hippopotamus brand as a Franchise Restaurant, and eight operated under the Pitaya brand (of which three operated as Franchise Restaurants). Franchise royalties increased by €64.4 million, or 21.4%, to €365.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €301.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was largely driven by higher sales from restaurants operated under the Burger King brand, as a result of targeted price increases throughout 2023, both with respect to home delivery and in-store channels, as well as the development of new offers and successful marketing campaigns; and to a lesser extent, by franchise royalties from the brands acquired through the 2023 Reorganization. This increase was partially offset by changes to our network, as a result of which certain restaurants formerly operated as Franchise Restaurants were transferred to Company Restaurants. Consumer sales increased by €95.6 million, or 41.4%, to €326.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €230.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was largely driven by the aforementioned drivers which increased sales of restaurants operated under the Burger King brand, as well as the aforementioned Burger King restaurant openings throughout the year and, to a lesser extent, to the increase of brands within our perimeter driven by the 2023 Reorganization. Sales of goods and equipment to franchisees amounted to €4.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 and are the direct consequence of the 2023 Reorganization. With respect to our Pitaya brand restaurants, we act as central purchaser and provider of most raw materials and goods required to manufacture finished products sold to customers, which drove the amounts of sales of goods and equipment to franchisees over the period. This central purchasing activity does not exist for the Burger King brand restaurants, which are responsible for their own purchasing directly from suppliers (see “Business—Operational Synergies of our Multi-Brand Franchise Model— _Supply Chain & Procurement Platform”)._ Further, while our entry fees and other sales increased over the period to €73.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €63.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 as a result of an increase in revenues invoiced to various stakeholders in relation to our property development activity. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by €65.6 million, or 34.7%, to €254.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €189.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The following table sets forth a breakdown of the cost of sales of the Group for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to the year ended December 31, 2021 for Burger King France
Subsubsection Text: _SWS_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Over the period, the increase in cost of sales was largely driven by the increase of restaurant brands within the Bertrand Franchise perimeter following the 2023 Reorganization, which added 519 additional restaurants 135 ----- (including 104 Company Restaurants and 415 Franchise Restaurants) to the perimeter through the Acquired Subsidiaries as of October 31, 2023. The increase in cost of sales was also largely driven by an increase in the cost of supplies and merchandise related to increased activity by our Burger King and other brands Company Restaurants, as well as to the high inflationary environment in the year ended December 31, 2023. This increase was slightly offset by the price increases that we implemented in 2023 in order to manage inflation. In addition, over the period, we experienced higher costs in connection with our property development contracts. While we experienced an increase in staff costs overall, labor costs, as a percentage of our total Company Restaurant revenue, slightly decreased as a result of low levels of labor costs in our restaurants located in La Réunion. _Operating and occupancy costs (excluding depreciation and amortization)_ Operating and occupancy costs increased by €24.3 million, or 59.3%, to €65.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €41.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in operating and occupancy costs was largely driven by the increase in the number of restaurants within our perimeter, as well as a rise in energy costs as a result of a high inflationary environment over the course of 2023, despite our efforts to mitigate this increase through energy consumption reduction. _Depreciation and amortization (restaurants)_ Depreciation and amortization (restaurants) increased by €16.9 million, or 21.7%, to €94.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €78.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. _Selling costs_ Selling costs increased by €11.6 million, or 22.3%, to an expense of €63.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from an expense of €52.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase is primarily attributable to the growth of our perimeter and to the increase in Burger King’s SWS by €328.2 million, or 20.8%. _Brand royalties_ Brand royalties increased by €16.5 million, or 23.3%, to €87.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €70.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase is primarily attributable to the aforementioned increase of SWS for the Burger King brand between the two periods. _Pre-opening costs_ Pre-opening costs increased by €0.8 million, or 100.0%, to €1.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €0.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase is mainly attributable to six new restaurants opened as Company Restaurants (as compared to three in the year ended December 31, 2022). 136 ----- _Other operating income/(expense)_ Other operating income decreased by €1.3 million, or 32.5%, to an income of €2.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from an income of €4.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease is mainly attributable to the decrease by €0.7 million of disposal gains on the sale of asset between the two periods; and to the increase by €0.7 million to €1.2 million in the depreciation of trade receivables. _General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization)_ General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization) increased by €16.3 million, or 37.3%, to €60.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €43.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase is mainly due to increased staff in the year ended December 31, 2023 following the under-staffing observed during the year ended December 31, 2022, and to the increase in activity triggered by the development of new projects, which led to higher external service costs. As a percentage of revenues for the Burger King brand, general and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization) remained fairly stable over the two periods of comparison. _Depreciation and amortization (corporate center)_ Depreciation and amortization (corporate center) slightly increased by €0.4 million, or 6.7%, to €6.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 from €6.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. _Other corporate income and expenses_ Other corporate expenses increased by €4.1 million to an expense of €3.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, from an income of €0.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase is principally due to an increase in provisions for supplier liabilities. _Other non-recurring income and expenses_ Other non-recurring expenses decreased by €0.6 million to an expense of €1.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, from an expense of €2.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was mainly attributable to a reversal of impairment losses in the amount of €1.3 million, relating to the definitive closure of the remaining Quick restaurants, partially offset by transaction costs in June 2023 linked to the acquisition of 70% of shares in Burger King La Réunion. _Net financial income/(expense)_ Restated net financial expense increased by €11.6 million to an expense of €121.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, from an expense of €110.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. _Income tax_ Income tax increased by €18.7 million to an expense of €20.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, from an expense of €1.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase is principally due to the full activation of fiscal losses carried forward for a total amount of €10.2 million. 137 ----- _Share of profit/(loss) of companies consolidated using the equity method_ Share of profit/(loss) of companies consolidated using the equity method remained stable at nearly zero over the two periods. _Net profit/(loss) for the period_ As a result of the foregoing factors, net loss for the period decreased by €13.2 million to a net loss of €10.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, from net profit of €3.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Total SWS increased by €365.0 million, or 30.0%, to €1,581.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €1,216.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase in network sales was driven by several factors. This period witnessed the positive effects of loosening governmental restrictive measures implemented over the first half of 2021 to combat the impacts of COVID-19, including loosening lockdown measures and the compulsory implementation of a health pass for entry to restaurants between mid-2021 through early 2022. In addition, over the course of 2022, while our costs increased resulting from a high inflationary environment, we were able to pass on some of these costs to our customers through both our delivery and in-store channels. We also opened 44 new restaurants and developed new offers, both of which had a positive impact on our total SWS. This increase in SWS was partially offset by an overall high inflationary environment, due in part to the ongoing war in Ukraine, as we were not able to pass on some, but not all, resulting increased costs from inflation to customers. The increase in SWS was also offset by the definitive closing and disposal of 3 restaurants in the year ended December 31, 2022. _Results of operations_ The following table sets forth the consolidated results of operations of Burger King France for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Sales and franchise revenues_ Total sales and franchise revenues increased by €89.8 million, or 17.8%, to €594.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, from €504.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The following table sets forth a breakdown of the sales and franchise revenues of Burger King France for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Company Restaurant revenues increased by €26.2 million, or 12.8%, to €230.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €204.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was mainly due to (i) the positive effects of loosening governmental restrictive measures implemented over the first half of 2021 to combat the impacts of COVID-19, including loosening lockdown measures and the compulsory implementation of a health pass for entry to restaurants between mid-2021 through early 2022, (ii) price increases from passing on increased costs in the context of a high inflationary environment to our customers through both our delivery and in-store channels and (iii) the development new offers, combined with successful marketing campaigns. In addition, over the course of 2022, we opened three additional Burger King Company Restaurants Franchise revenues increased by €79.6 million, or 35.9%, to €301.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, from €221.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was largely attributable to the aforementioned drivers that impacted the growth of our Company Restaurant revenues and overall system-wide sales. In addition, over the course of 2022, we increased the number of overall restaurants operated as Franchise Restaurants by 47 restaurants, totaling 418 Franchise Restaurants at the end of December 2022 (of which 413 were operated under the Burger King brand and five operated under the Quick brand), as compared to 372 Franchise Restaurants at the end of December 2021. The total net change in restaurants over 2022 reflected 46 new Franchise Restaurants, of which 41 restaurants were new Burger King Franchise Restaurant openings and six Franchise Restaurants were formerly operated as Company Restaurants that were transferred to the franchise model. One Franchise Restaurant was definitively closed over the period. These positive growth drivers were 139 ----- slightly offset by the adverse international inflationary context in 2022, which we believe had an impact on consumer impact and spending overall. Other revenues decreased by €16.1 million, or 20.6%, to €62.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €78.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease is mainly attributable to a decrease in our property development activity as a result of projects that were aborted or postponed over the period; a decrease in conversion fees invoiced to franchisees upon the conversion of a Quick restaurant into a Burger King restaurant (no restaurants were converted in 2022, as compared to 20 restaurants converted during 2021); and the impact of implementing IFRS 15 for the first time in 2022 in connection with our loyalty program. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by €18.6 million, or 10.9%, to €189.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €170.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The following table sets forth a breakdown of the cost of sales of the Group for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Company Restaurant cost of sales increased by €18.6 million, or 10.9%, to €189.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €170.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was driven by (i) the increase in Company Restaurant food costs by €11.1 million, or 19.9%, to €67.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €55.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 and (ii) the increase in Company Restaurant labor costs by €12.0 million, or 20.8%, to €69.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €57.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. These increases were partially offset by the decrease in Other costs by €4.4 million, or 7.7%, to €52.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €56.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The overall increase in cost of sales over the period was largely attributable to higher raw material and personnel costs in line with increased inflation in 2022, as well as a reduction in social charges granted by the French government and booked in 2021 as part of COVID-19 related governmental relief measures, which explains our comparative higher labor charges in 2022. As a percentage of Company Restaurants revenues, food costs increased by 1.7 percentage point to 29.0% for the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to 27.3% for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase is mainly attributable to high levels of inflation in 2022, partially offset by price increases that we were able to implement to pass on costs to customers. As a percentage of Company Restaurant revenues, labor costs increased by 2.0 percentage points to 30.2% for the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared to 28.2% for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase over the periods is mostly due to the exemptions from social charges that we were granted in 2021. Other costs decreased by €4.4 million, or 7.7%, to €52.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, from €56.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was primarily attributable to the decrease in our property development activity as a result of development projects that were aborted or postponed. 140 ----- _Operating and occupancy costs (excluding depreciation and amortization)_ The following table shows our operating and occupancy costs (excluding depreciation and amortization) for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating and occupancy costs (excluding depreciation and amortization) increased by €4.1 million, or 11.1%, to €41.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €36.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was attributable to increases in utility costs, repair and maintenance costs and rental costs, which were partially offset by a slight decrease in other operating and occupancy costs. Utility costs increased over the period by €0.8 million, or 16.0%, to €5.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €5.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase reflects higher activity across our network in 2022 compared to 2021, coupled with a high inflationary environment, which further increased our utility costs. Repair and maintenance costs increased over the period by €1.7 million, or 19.8%, to €10.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €8.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, driven by higher activity across our network in 2022 compared to 2021. Rental costs increased over the period by €2.2 million, or 200.0%, to €3.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €1.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, driven by the net increase in the overall number of restaurants over the period, as well as the accounting of rebates granted by landlords in 2021 following COVID19 related negotiations. The foregoing cost increases were partially offset by a decrease in other operating and occupancy costs, which decreased over the period by €0.6 million, or 2.7%, to €21.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €22.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was driven by fewer home delivery fees invoiced by food delivery aggregators in 2022 as compared to 2021, as a portion of our dine-in areas were closed in the first half of 2021 in relation to the COVID-19 government restrictive measures, resulting in a higher volume of home delivery purchases. _Depreciation and amortization (restaurants)_ Depreciation and amortization (restaurants) increased by €3.7 million, or 5.0%, to €78.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €74.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, following the increase of the size our network. _Selling costs_ Selling costs increased by €12.3 million, or 31.0%, to an expense of €52.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from an expense of €39.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase is primarily attributable to the increase in Burger King’s SWS by €365.4 million over the period. Selling costs as a 141 ----- percentage of SWS remained fairly stable, representing 3.3% for both the year ended December 31, 2022 and 2021. _BK brand royalties_ BK brand royalties increased by €16.4 million, or 30.1%, to €70.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €54.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase is primarily attributable to the growth in our SWS over the period, including as a result of the additional SWS generated by the 44 new Burger King restaurants opened in 2022. _Pre-opening costs_ Pre-opening costs remained stable at €0.8 million between the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021. _Other operating income/(expense)_ Other operating income decreased by €1.1 million, or 21.6%, to an income of €4.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from an income of €5.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease is mainly due to reversal of provisions related to trade receivables in the fourth quarter of 2021, following an observed decrease in risk. _General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization)_ General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortization) increased by €4.4 million, or 11.1%, to €43.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €39.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was mainly due to an increase in activity as compared to 2021, when our activity was limited during the first half of 2021 as a result of COVID-19 related restrictive measures. _Depreciation and amortization (corporate center)_ Depreciation and amortization (corporate center) slightly decreased by €0.2 million, or 3.2%, to €6.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from €6.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Other corporate income and expenses_ Other corporate income decreased by €0.4 million, to an income of €0.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from an income of €1.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Other non-recurring income and expenses_ Other non-recurring expenses increased by €0.3 million to an expense of €2.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from an expense of €2.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase is mainly attributable to disposals of assets in 2022 linked to the definitive closure of two Company Restaurants in 2022. 142 ----- _Net financial income/(expense)_ Net financial expense decreased by €12.5 million, or 15.5%, to an expense of €67.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, from an expense of €80.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease is mainly attributable to a high level of financial charges in 2021, following the early repayment of the fixed tranche of then-outstanding bond debt, which induced (i) the payment of early repayment fees and (ii) the payment of the remaining refinancing fees of our former outstanding notes issued in 2017, which were fully paid on November 2, 2021. _Income tax_ Income tax decreased by €10.1 million to an expense of €2.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from an expense of €12.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease is principally due to the high level of income tax in 2021 as a result of the conclusion of our internal legal organization in the fourth quarter of 2021, including certain disposals related to our discontinued perimeter. _Share of profit/(loss) of companies consolidated using the equity method_ Share of profit/(loss) of companies consolidated using the equity method decreased by €0.1 million to an expense nearly equal to zero for the year ended December 31, 2022, from an income of €0.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Income from assets held for sale and discontinued operations_ Income from assets held for sales and discontinued operations decreased by €13.5 million to zero for the year ended December 31, 2022, from an income of €13.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This variation resulted from disposals of our discontinued Quick perimeter as of October 8, 2021. _Net profit/(loss) for the period_ As a result of the foregoing factors, net profit for the period increased by €37.6 million to net profit of €44.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from a net profit of €7.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources of the Group
Subsubsection Text: Our primary sources of liquidity consist of the following: 143 ----- - cash generated from our operating activities; - the proceeds from the Notes offered hereby; and - drawings under the New Revolving Credit Facility. On an as-adjusted basis for the Refinancing, the consolidated net debt of the Issuer as of March 31, 2024 would have been €1,970.4 million and we would have had cash and cash equivalents of €165.3 million (assuming the New Revolving Credit Facility was undrawn during the entire period). The Issuer is a holding company with no revenue-generating operations or assets of its own except for the equity interest it holds in its subsidiaries and any rights in intercompany receivables owed by its subsidiaries. As a result, the Issuer depends and will depend on the cash flow of its subsidiaries to meet its obligations, including its obligations under the Notes. The Indenture and the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will contain covenants that, among other things, limit our ability and the ability of our restricted subsidiaries to: incur additional indebtedness; pay dividends on or make distributions in respect of capital stock or make certain other restricted payments or investments; enter into agreements that restrict distributions from restricted subsidiaries; sell or otherwise dispose of assets, including capital stock of restricted subsidiaries; enter into transactions with affiliates; create or incur liens; and merge, consolidate or sell substantially all of our assets. These covenants are subject to important exceptions and qualifications. For more information regarding our indebtedness and cash service requirements on our indebtedness, see “Capitalization,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes—Certain _Covenants”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Cash generated/(used) by operating activities_ Cash generated/(used) by operating activities was recorded as an inflow of €52.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024, as compared to an inflow €43.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. For the three months ended March 31, 2024, the €52.3 million inflow was primarily attributable to inflow related to EBITDA, partially offset by a €(10.7) million working capital requirement impact and outflows for nonrecurring items. 144 ----- _Cash generated/(used) by investment activities_ Cash generated/(used) by investment activities for the three months ended March 31, 2024 was recorded as a cash outflow of €13.8 million as compared to a cash outflow of €7.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. The net cash outflow from investment activities for the three months ended March 31, 2024 was primarily due to acquisition of fixed assets. The net cash outflow from investment activities for the three months ended March 31, 2023 was primarily due to (i) investments in new restaurant openings, namely including the construction of two Burger King Company restaurants and leasehold rights acquisition of one future Burger King restaurant, (ii) cash outflows related to Burger King restaurants’ refurbishments and finally (iii) additional cash outflows related to maintenance and headquarters capital expenditures. _Cash generated/(used) by financing activities_ Cash generated/(used) by financing activities were recorded as a cash outflow of €42.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2024, as compared to a cash outflow of €30.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. The €42.6 million outflow for the three-month period ended March 31, 2024 was mainly related to €(2.7) million in loan repayments, €32.1 million on lease debt and interests and €(8.8) million in interest payments on financial debt, partially offset by €1.0 million in new loans. The €30.0 million cash outflow for the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 was mainly related to (i) €21.5 million of lease debt and interests, (ii) payment of €7.6 million of interests, consisting primarily of accrued interest on the Existing Senior Secured Notes and finally (iii) €0.9 million of borrowing redemption. _Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to the year ended December 31, 2022_ The following table sets forth the statement of consolidated cash flows of the Group as of and for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Cash generated/(used) by operating activities_ Cash generated/(used) by operating activities was recorded as an inflow of €189.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, as compared to an inflow €182.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the €189.5 million inflow was primarily attributable to inflow related to EBITDA, partly offset by (i) outflow from the change in working capital requirement, (ii) outflows for nonrecurring items and (iii) the French corporate tax Cotisation sur la valeur ajoutée des entreprises (or CVAE). _Cash generated/(used) by investment activities_ Cash generated/(used) by investment activities for the year ended December 31, 2023 was recorded as a cash outflow of €63.6 million as compared to a cash outflow of €14.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The net cash outflow from investment activities for the year ended December 31, 2023 was primarily due to (i) 145 ----- the acquisition of Burger King restaurants in La Réunion, (ii) investments in new restaurant openings, (iii) cash outflow related to restaurants’ refurbishments and maintenance and (iv) purchase of interest rate caps hedging instruments) as part of our hedging strategy. These effects were partly offset by asset disposals. The net cash outflow from investment activities for the year ended December 31, 2022 was primarily due to (i) investments in new restaurant openings; (ii) cash outflows related to refurbishments of Burger King restaurants; and (iii) cash outflows related to maintenance and network management activities. These effects were partially offset by (i) the redemption of a €5.0 million vendor loan from our discontinued perimeter in the second quarter of 2022, (ii) disposal gains mainly corresponding to the transfer of six restaurants from Company Restaurants to Franchise Restaurants and (iii) additional asset disposals. _Cash generated/(used) by financing activities_ Cash generated/(used) by financing activities were recorded as a cash outflow of €77.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, as compared to a cash outflow of €150.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The €77.6 million outflow for the twelve-month period ended December 31, 2023 was mainly related to: (i) €343.0 million of loan redemption (consisting primarily of the repayment of convertible bonds of Bertrand Franchise and of the related interests as of October 31 in line with the 2023 Reorganization), (ii) €97.8 million of lease debt and interests as a result of the application of IFRS 16, (iii) the payment of €78.4 million in interests, consisting primarily of interests on the Existing Senior Secured Notes, on the Existing PIK Notes and on other debts, (iv) a capital decrease of €41.8 million in line with the 2023 Reorganization and (v) €6.6 million of repurchase of noncontrolling interest. These outflows were partly offset by (i) €442.6 million capital increase following the 2023 Reorganization, and by (ii) €47.4 million in new borrowings, mostly related to the issuance of additional floating rate notes, the proceeds of which were used to fund the acquisition of Burger King restaurants in La Réunion and related expenses. The €150.4 million cash outflow for the twelve-month period ended December 31, 2022 was mainly related to (i) €77.7 million of lease debt and interests, as a result of the application of IFRS 16; (ii) €50.1 million in payment of interests, consisting primarily of interests on the Existing Senior Secured Notes, on the Existing PIK Notes and on other debts; (iii) €14.8 million corresponding to the acquisition of the remaining shares of four companies operating Burger King restaurants, following which such restaurants were wholly owned by us; and (iv) €7.9 million mainly corresponding to the redemption of one bilateral loan. _Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to the year ended December 31, 2021_ The following table sets forth the statement of consolidated cash flows of the Burger King France Group as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our primary source of trade receivables are (i) royalties and lease and business assets payments due from franchisees and (ii) payments due from lessors in connection with our CPI activity and (iii) as of the completion 147 ----- of the 2023 Reorganization, payments due from Pitaya franchisees in connection with our role as central purchaser and main supplier for the supply of raw materials and goods for restaurants operated under the Pitaya brand. On the other hand, our primary source of trade payables consisted of (i) investment-related payables (for restaurant openings and conversions), (ii) payables related to our CPI activity and (iii) food costs. Within food costs, we purchase raw materials and food products only for Company Restaurants (and for franchised restaurants under the Pitaya brand). Other elements of our operating working capital inflows consist of labor costs and, for the Burger King and the Itsu brands, payments due to BK Europe and Itsu France which are generally paid following the close of the applicable month. Cash outflows related to operating working capital include royalty payments due from franchisees and lease payments, the majority of which are pre-payable on a quarterly basis.

Subsubsection Text: _Cash generated/(used) by operating activities_ Cash generated/(used) by operating activities was recorded as an inflow of €180.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to €180.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The €180.6 million inflow recorded for the year ended December 31, 2022,was primarily attributable to inflow related to EBITDA, partly offset by (i) outflow from the change in working capital requirement, (ii) outflows for non-recurring items and (iii) the French corporate tax Cotisation sur la valeur ajoutée des entreprises (or CVAE). 146 ----- The €180.0 million inflow recorded for the year ended December 31, 2021, was primarily attributable to inflow (i) related to EBITDA and to (ii) inflow related to the change in working capital requirement, partly offset by (i) outflows for non-recurring items and (ii) the French corporate tax Cotisation sur la valeur ajoutée des entreprises” (or CVAE). _Cash generated/(used) by investment activities_ Cash generated/(used) by investment activities for the year ended December 31, 2022 was recorded as a cash outflow of €14.0 million as compared to a cash inflow of €182.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The net cash outflow from investment activities for the year ended December 31, 2022 was primarily due to (i) investments in new restaurant openings; (ii) cash outflows related to refurbishments of Burger King restaurants; and (iii) cash outflows related to maintenance and network management activities. These effects were partially offset by (i) the redemption of a €5.0 million vendor loan from our discontinued perimeter in the second quarter of 2022, (ii) disposal gains mainly corresponding to the transfer of six restaurants from Company Restaurants to Franchise Restaurants and (iii) additional asset disposals. The net cash inflow from investment activities for the twelve-month period ended December 31, 2021 was primarily due to (i) proceeds from the disposals of our discontinued Quick perimeter, net of cash occurring in the fourth quarter of 2021 and (ii) asset disposals. This inflow was partly offset by outflows linked to (i) investments for the completed conversion of 20 Quick restaurants to Burger King restaurants; (ii) investments in new restaurant openings; (iii) cash outflow related to restaurant refurbishments and (iv) additional cash outflows related to maintenance and network management activities. _Cash generated/(used) by financing activities_ Cash generated/(used) by financing activities was recorded as a cash outflow of €133.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to a cash outflow of €445.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The €133.0 million outflow for the twelve-month period ended December 31, 2022 was mainly related to (i) €77.6 million of lease debt and interests, which are the direct consequence of the application of IFRS 16; (ii) the payment of €30.9 million of interest, consisting primarily of accrued interests on our Floating Rate Senior Secured Note due 2026; (iii) the payment of €14.8 million corresponding to the acquisition of the remaining shares of four companies operating Burger King restaurants in order to hold them at 100%; (iv) €7.9 million of borrowing redemption costs, corresponding to the redemption of one bilateral loan and (v) the payment of €1.7 million of dividends to MidCo GB. The €445.7 million outflow for the twelve-month period ended December 31, 2021 was mainly related to (i) €743.8 million of borrowing redemption costs, mostly due to (a) the early redemption of our previously outstanding fixed and floating rate senior secured notes, which were refinanced in 2021 (b) the reimbursement of €20.0 million outstanding under our existing revolving credit facility in September 2021, (c) the state guaranteed loan for €80.0 million in October and (d) a bilateral loan of €10.6 million (in April 2021), (ii) €196.7 million related to the reverse acquisition of NewCo GB, (iii) €75.7 million of lease debt and interests, which are the direct consequence of the application of IFRS16, (iv) an outflow of €44.1 million related to the payment of interests (consisting primarily of interests following the early redemption of the former Senior Secured Notes and accrued interests), and finally (v) an outflow of €6.0 million corresponding to the restatement of minority interests’ acquisition from “cash used by investing activity” to “cash used by financing activity” in the third quarter of 2021. These outflows were partly offset by (i) an inflow of €619.6 million corresponding to the issuance of Floating Senior Secured Notes due 2026 and a new bilateral loan contracted in June 2021 and by (ii) €0.9 million related to a net capital increase in line with the reverse acquisition.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to various market risks in the normal course of business. _Commodity price risk_ Our restaurants are subject to commodity price risk related to food costs and related packaging, mostly correlated to underlying commodities such as beef, chicken and paper (for packaging). We are also indirectly exposed to grains and fuel prices as they are inputs for certain raw materials we purchase and an input in our logistics costs. In the case of Franchise with Lease Management restaurants, the foregoing risks are limited as they are borne directly by the franchisees. _Exchange rate risk_ We have no significant exposures to foreign exchange rate risk as the majority of our revenues, expenses and indebtedness are denominated in euro. _Interest rate risk_ We are subject to interest rate risks related to our indebtedness that are linked to EURIBOR plus certain margins. 148 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The following is a discussion and analysis of the financial condition and results of operations of the Group in the periods set forth below, based on data extracted from the Financial Statements, including: - the Parent Interim Financial Statements for the three months ended March 31, 2024, as compared to the three months ended March 31, 2023 (it being specified that the March 31, 2023 financial information has been subject to neither an audit nor a review); - the Parent Annual Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2023, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2022 (it being specified that the December 31, 2022 financial information has been subject to neither an audit nor a review); and - the BK France Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2021, as discussed under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information”. This discussion should be read together with the full consolidated Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS, free English translations of which are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The following discussion should also be read in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial and Other _Information,” and “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Data”. A summary of the_ Group’s critical accounting policies that have been applied to these financial statements is set out below under the caption “—Critical Accounting Policies”. The discussion in this section may contain forward-looking statements that reflect the Group’s plans, estimates and beliefs and involve risks and uncertainties. The Group’s actual results could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to these differences include, but are not limited to, those discussed below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, particularly under “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements”.

Subsubsection Title: Chains presence in the French consumer foodservice market
Subsubsection Text: According to Euromonitor, independent operators are the primary contributors to the French foodservice market, representing approximately 90% of the outlets in the country and collectively contributing 57% of the total market value in 2023. Despite representing only 10% of the outlets, foodservice chains in France have been gaining momentum in recent years, increasing their market share by nearly 10%, from 34% in 2019 to 43% in 2023. This increase illustrates the higher revenue per restaurant generated by foodservice chains compared to independent operators. _Source: Euromonitor_ 150 ----- The acceleration of foodservice chain penetration during the COVID-19 pandemic was driven by lockdowns and related restrictions, which reduced on-premise consumption and boosted take-away and home delivery services. Brands benefited from a number of advantages which supported their resilience, including: (i) good value for money, which appeals to consumers, (ii) quicker adaptation to the omni-channel shift, (iii) consistent quality across networks, which generates stronger customer trust, (iv) economies of scale for roll-outs of innovative solutions and offers, and (v) financial strength to support operators in a challenging market environment. Food service chains are also more prevalent in the QSR segment, which outperformed other market segments during the COVID-19 pandemic. A consistent pattern has been observed across international markets, with foodservice chains outperforming independent operators as a result of the range of advantages they present to consumers. These include affordability, quality and consistency for customers, as well as industrialization, cost efficiency and accelerated rollout for operators. From that standpoint, the French foodservice market appears to still be underpenetrated by brands compared to more mature markets such as the UK. _Source: Euromonitor_

Subsubsection Title: Development of the franchise model in France and in the foodservice market
Subsubsection Text: According to the Fédération Française de la Franchise, the contribution from franchise businesses to the French economy is one of the largest in Europe. In 2023, revenues generated by franchise businesses reached approximately €88.5 billion, increasing by more than 15% year-on-year, well above the 0.9% GDP growth. This expansion of franchised revenues in the country was supported by a 3% growth in the number of franchised networks and 9% growth in the number of franchise outlets since 2022. The demand for franchise business and outlets has been very resilient historically and has grown at an average CAGR of approximately 5% since 1995, boosted by individuals’ appeal for entrepreneurship: _Source: Fédération Française de la Franchise_ The penetration of the foodservice market by franchise networks remains comparatively lower than the one observed in other industries, which provides operators with significant room to develop their networks. For instance, franchise revenue accounts for 37% of the grocery retail sector, but only 13% of the foodservice sector, indicating a potential growth opportunity of 24%. This model is attractive to both franchisors and franchisees. For franchisors, it offers a fast and asset-light rollout with a margin-accretive development model. For franchisees, it provides turnkey concepts, well-known brands that generate footfall traffic from day one, strong operational support, including location, loans, procurement, training, staff, and robust economics with a short pay-back period. 151 ----- _Source: Fédération Française de la Franchise_

Subsubsection Title: Growth in the French consumer foodservice market
Subsubsection Text: The resilience of the consumer foodservice market in France and its historical growth have been underpinned by secular drivers, stimulating both demand and supply dynamics. These underlying trends have contributed to structural evolutions in consumers’ habits over time. We believe the following factors support the market in which we operate: _Decreasing time to cook driving need for convenience_ The increasing proportion of working parents, along with a greater average distance between home and workplace have gradually reduced the time available for the preparation and consumption of meals. Out-of-home consumption has emerged as a preferred option for consumers looking to optimize their working schedules and maximize their leisure time. _Increased out-of-home consumption as a result of the growing position of chain restaurants versus independent operators_ The increased density of chain restaurants has been one of the key factors behind the growth of the French consumer foodservice market. Foodservice chain restaurants facilitate consumers’ access to away-from-home dining by increasing the number of available locations and making the opening of new restaurants easier compared to the process for independent operators. Chain restaurants have the ability to leverage economies of scale and benefit from a logistical advantage to provide consumers with a varied menu of competitively priced meals with consistent quality throughout the network. The ability of chain restaurants to offer significant pricing discounts, combined with the significant financial resources they devote to marketing campaigns, contribute to their success. In addition, when traveling, consumers may prefer chain restaurants over independent operators due to the consistent level and standard of service throughout their extensive national network. _Growing share of non-traditional daypart consumption_ The foodservice market has historically generated the largest part of its revenues around lunchtime, and to a lesser extent during dinner. In recent years, the diversification of food offering and the expansion of menus into non-traditional dayparts, such as breakfast, coffee and snacks, have increased the propensity of individuals to consume out-of-home meals throughout the day, providing a substantial growth opportunity for market players to capture incremental demand. 152 ----- _Higher penetration of digital channels_ Digital channels and tools have steadily gained traction among consumers with evolving lifestyles and increasing acceptance of digital solutions. Digital revenues have become an important driver of growth providing both increased consumer convenience and an enhanced customer journey for on-premise consumption. This expansion of digital solutions also enables operators to leverage their network and achieve operating efficiency through the use of digital kiosks, tablets and mobile payments. Furthermore, the use of mobile applications and presence on third-party food delivery applications enables restaurant operators to build a direct relationship with customers, increase brand awareness through social media, and enhance customer lifetime value through loyalty programs. With 80% of consumers in France reported to be choosing which restaurant to visit based on information they find online, a strong digital presence has become a key success factor for industry players. _Off-premise consumption gaining momentum resulting in increasing importance of omni-channel distribution_ Restrictions regarding on-premise consumption during the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the digitalization of the foodservice sector, as consumers were either unable or unwilling to dine-in. Although the sector has now almost fully recovered from the effects of the pandemic, many customers continue to use take-away, drive-through or home delivery services, which became a common habit for consumers in France. According to Euromonitor, in 2023, these services accounted for nearly two-thirds of revenues in the QSR sector, and an even higher proportion in terms of number of transactions in the burger, pizza, and Asian QSR sub-segments. The development of off-premise consumption has been further driven by the increase in frequency of eating and consumers’ demand for more convenience. _Demand for healthy, quality eating and diverse cuisines_ In recent years, consumers have become increasingly health-conscious and mindful of the importance of a balanced and nutritious diet. This heightened awareness is partly due to ongoing health and wellness campaigns across Europe, promoting the benefits of organic food, vegetarian and vegan options with an emphasis on local, seasonal and natural ingredients. Consumers have become increasingly knowledgeable about specific diet-related health issues such as cardiovascular diseases and obesity, which has led to an increase in the demand for healthier food products including fish, vegetables and poultry. The globalization of consumers’ tastes and growing multiculturalism have fueled demand for variety and choice, driving individuals’ desire for diversified culinary experiences. Players in the foodservice industry have been able to quickly adapt to these new trends, with major restaurant chains now focusing on improving the nutritional quality of their offerings and communicating nutritional information on the packaging of their products. Market players are also committed to develop and expand their menus to incorporate more diverse and healthier alternatives (for example, plant-based meat alternatives, salad and fresh fruit), which appeals to a wider consumer base. _Ability to increase average ticket price_ Out-of-home spending has remained positively oriented in recent years in spite of the inflationary context which has constrained consumers’ purchasing power. According to Euromonitor, the French consumer foodservice market value has increased by 9% in 2023 supported by a moderate 4% growth in average ticket prices across market segments, including a 3% for full-service restaurants and a 5% for QSR. Despite the increase in selling prices, footfall traffic has remained robust, improving by 5% year-on-year which demonstrates the structural resilience of the sector in periods of economic downturns. 153 ----- The average ticket price for restaurants in the QSR segment increased at a faster rate than other categories primarily benefitting from the perception of affordability and a base effect compared to full-service restaurant, which are characterized by a higher average ticket price.

According to Euromonitor, the French consumer foodservice market is one of the largest markets in Europe, valued at approximately €50.0 billion in 2023. Out-of-home consumption in France is well-established but remains behind other European countries notably Spain, Italy or the UK, a disparity which presents significant opportunities for further expansion. _Source: Euromonitor_ The French foodservice market displayed strong stability and resilience historically. In 2020, COVID-19 related lockdowns and other restrictions led to an unprecedented decrease in market value, which decreased to approximately €30.8 billion. Since 2020, the French consumer foodservice market has now almost fully recovered from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, recording an increase of approximately 17% in value and 12% CAGR in terms of footfall traffic primarily due to positive supply and demand dynamics. Industry players have managed to rapidly adapt to the new landscape by accelerating the rollout of their omni-channel distribution platforms, a development which was largely facilitated by consumers’ increasing acceptance of digital tools. Off-premise consumption remains very popular with a large portion of customers opting for take-away, drive-through or home delivery services. 149 ----- _Source: Euromonitor_ The French consumer foodservice market can be split into five main segments: quick service restaurants (“QSR”), full-service restaurants, cafés and bars, self-service cafeterias and street stalls and kiosks. In 2023, quick service restaurants and full-service restaurants were the largest addressable segments, representing approximately 52% and 21% of total transactions and 41% and 46% of market value, respectively. The market value contribution of the QSR segment increased from approximately 30% in 2019 to 41% in 2023. This growth was driven by operators adapting their distribution model during the COVID-19 pandemic, a shift in demand towards digital channels and off-premise consumption, the success of their business concepts, and the relatively low average ticket prices of this category. The relative importance of full-service restaurants’ contribution to the overall market value, compared to their contribution in volume, is primarily due to their higher average ticket prices. _Source: Euromonitor_

The QSR market in France is characterized by the broad diversity of its offering, which addresses the country’s multiculturalism and its consumers’ increasing desire to explore new types of cuisines. The burger sub-segment is the largest food category in the QSR segment, recording approximately €9.1 billion of revenues in 2023 and representing 48% of total revenues. Chain restaurants play an important role in this category, with established operators like Burger King or McDonald’s leading the market with their extensive networks. _Source: Euromonitor_ The remaining QSR market is more fragmented. The bakery sub-segment is the second largest food offering category, accounting for 21% of the total QSR revenues in 2023. This sub-segment is characterized by its popular French-style sandwich shops, the vast majority of which are run by independent operators. Other notable sub-segments include the Middle-Eastern and Chicken sub-segments, representing 12% and 5% of the overall market value, respectively. In recent years, the increasing consumers’ desire for diversified forms of cuisine fueled the development of single-product QSR restaurants such as French tacos, salad bars or Asian QSR like Pitaya and Itsu. 154 -----

Subsubsection Title: Burger and Chicken QSR white space
Subsubsection Text: The Burger and Chicken QSR segments in France still offer a significant white space opportunity for operators when compared to other developed foodservice markets across the world. According to Euromonitor, in 2023, the number of Burger and Chicken QSR outlets per one hundred thousand inhabitants in the US was 28.9, against 8.0 in the UK, 5.3 in Spain and only 4.5 in France. Applying the US, UK or Spanish ratios of outlets per one hundred thousand inhabitants to the French population, additional potential outlets in France in Burger and Chicken QSR could range from approximately 500 restaurants up to more than 16,000. _Source: Euromonitor_

Subsubsection Title: Competitive landscape in the QSR segment
Subsubsection Text: According to Euromonitor, the QSR segment is primarily dominated by large chain networks, which accounted for 81% of the total market value in 2023. This dominance has been consistent historically and was slightly reinforced through the COVID-19 pandemic due to the continued network roll-out from leading players and increasing default rates for independent operators. _Source: Euromonitor_ In the chained Burger QSR segment, the leading brands are McDonald’s and Burger King, which, together, accounted for approximately 90% of the market value in 2023. As of December 31, 2023, McDonald’s and Burger King operated 1,560 and 534 (excluding two Quick restaurants) restaurants, respectively. Since 2018, Burger King has been the fastest growing player in this segment, increasing its market share by approximately 5 percentage points to 18-20% in 2023. _Source: Euromonitor_ Outside the burger QSR segment, Bertrand Franchise through Pitaya and Itsu competes in the chained Asian QSR market. The segment is much smaller than the Burger QSR segment, with an estimated €711 million market value 155 ----- in 2023. However, it has been growing rapidly in recent years and offers a substantial opportunity for franchise network operators going forward. As of December 31, 2023, Pitaya is the second largest player in France after Sushi Shop, with 138 restaurants in operation and approximately 31-33% of market share in the Asian QSR segment. _Source: Euromonitor_

The QSR segment comprises any type of restaurant serving “on-the-go” food such as hamburgers, sandwiches, kebabs, fried chicken, sushi, pizza and health-conscious quick service restaurants. According to Euromonitor, revenues in the QSR segment totaled €19.1 billion in 2023, recording an increase of approximately 5% CAGR between 2019 and 2023. This increase outpaced the overall French consumer foodservice market, which contracted at a rate of 2% over the same period. The recovery of the QSR segment has been robust, with its market value rebounding as early as 2021 and volumes returning to pre-pandemic levels in 2023. _Source: Euromonitor_ The relative resilience of the QSR segment during the pandemic primarily resulted from the ability of operators to transition their distribution model towards online revenues, drive-through, take-away and delivery services, effectively offsetting the decrease in on-premise consumption. The segment was quicker to adopt new technologies, such as the use of QR codes, digital menus and touchscreen ordering, which boosted efficiency and maintained increased profitability compared to other types of restaurants.

###### The full-service restaurant market in France is highly diversified, both in terms of pricing point and from a culinary experience perspective. As such, it is difficult to categorize full-service restaurants, which are typically regrouped based on the region or nationality of the food they provide. European food is the most represented in the French market, valued at €16.5 billion in 2023 and 156 ----- ###### representing approximately 71% of total revenues in this segment. The pizza sub-segment represents the second largest category, having consistently ranked as one of the favorite meals for people in France in recent years. _Source: Euromonitor_ The remainder of the full-service restaurant market is more fragmented, with the Asian and Middle-Eastern sub-segments representing 8% and 4% of the overall market value, respectively. Despite the increasing consumers’ demand for diversified cuisine, market segmentation has remained stable historically.

Subsubsection Title: Competitive landscape in the full-service restaurant segment
Subsubsection Text: The full-service restaurant market is primarily dominated by independent operators. The penetration of brands has remained stable between 12-14% historically, mostly due to the French gastronomic culture and the fact that consumers in French associate it with independent restaurants. _Source: Euromonitor_ Although brand penetration has remained limited overall, some brands have managed to emerge in specific market segments. For instance, in the grill sub-segment, Hippopotamus and Buffalo Grill have managed to establish nation-wide networks and strong brand awareness. In the fish and seafood sub-segment, Léon has developed well-recognized brand. The relative under penetration of brands in the full-service restaurant market represents a significant white-space opportunity for integrated operators such as Bertrand Franchise, offering proven concepts and brands, complete support, including training and procurement, and access to prime locations for entrepreneurs looking to launch or develop their operations.

The full-service restaurant segment includes establishments where waiting staff take orders and attend to customers by serving food and drinks directly at their tables. According to Euromonitor, the full-service restaurant segment was the largest contributor to the overall consumer foodservice market in France in 2023, valued at approximately €23.2 billion and representing 46% of the total market value and 21% of all transactions. Between 2019 and 2023, the full-service restaurant market contracted at a rate of approximately 6% in value, while the overall foodservice restaurant market decreased in value by approximately 2% CAGR over the same period. The relative underperformance of the full-service restaurant market is primarily linked to its contraction in 2020 as a result of COVID-19 related restrictions regarding on-premise dining. _Source: Euromonitor_ This segment has rebounded, recording an increase of approximately 18% CAGR during the period from 2020 to 2023, facilitated by consumers’ renewed willingness to gather in a convivial environment to interact and socialize as well as the recovery of the tourism industry post COVID-19. This return to growth was also fueled by adjustments to its business model undertaken by operators, including the increase in the proportion of digital revenues through the use of take-away and delivery services.

Subsubsection Title: Competitive landscape in the cafés / bars segment
Subsubsection Text: _Source: Euromonitor_ The cafés and bars segment includes a wide array of outlets including French cafés, pubs, specialty coffee and tea shops or juice and smoothie bars. The penetration of brands is relatively limited, mostly due to the historical characteristics of the French market. ###### With 195 points of sales and approximately 79- 81% market share in the bars and pubs segment in 2023, Au Bureau is the largest player in France, ahead of Le Comptoir du Malt. _Source: Euromonitor_ 158 -----

According to Euromonitor, the cafés and bars segment was the third largest addressable segment in the French consumer foodservice market in 2023, with total revenues of approximately €5.3 billion, or 9% of the total market value and 20% of transactions. Over the period from 2019 to 2023, the value of the cafés and bars segment decreased at a CAGR of approximately 2.2%, slightly higher than the 1.6% average decline for the overall consumer foodservice market over the same years. 157 ----- _Source: Euromonitor_ Since 2020, the segment has recorded the largest recovery in value across segments, displaying an increase of approximately 25% CAGR to 2023, notably supported by the relative importance of cafés and bars for social interactions as well as the return of the tourism industry after the lift of COVID-19 related restrictions.

We are France’s leading multi-brand food service franchising platform, renowned for our diverse and strategically curated portfolio of market-leading restaurant brands. Our portfolio encompasses a variety of eight wellpositioned distinct restaurant brands that cater to a wide range of attractive food service market segments, from QSR to casual dining formats, addressing all-day consumption occasions, as illustrated in the graphic below. We own six out of the eight restaurant brands in our portfolio (Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon, Volfoni, Pitaya and Jôyô), while we are the master franchisee in France for the remaining two brands (Burger King and Itsu). Our network spans over 1,000 restaurants across attractive locations throughout France, partnering with 423 franchisees, who together operated 83% of our restaurant network as of December 31, 2023. The remaining 17% of our restaurant network was comprised of directly-operated company restaurants (the “Company

Subsection Title: Restaurants”). For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated €1,016.8 million in Pro Forma Run-
Subsubsection Text: Rate franchise sales and revenues and €318.8 million of Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate Normalized EBITDA reflecting a 31.4% Pro Forma Adjusted Run-Rate EBITDA margin. Our portfolio is diversified across cuisine styles and occasions and is operated mostly under a highly attractive franchise model through an efficient and synergistic platform. Our strength in identifying and responding to consumer preferences for cuisine, price point, format and channel through our various restaurant brand concepts has established us as a dominant player in the French food service industry. We have successfully scaled and grown our presence exponentially from 116 points of sale in 2010 to over 1,000 points of sale in 2023. In line with our continued growth, we have increased our SWS by a 12% CAGR over the 2019 to March 31, 2024 period. Our pace of growth is consistent, with between approximately 80 to 110 new restaurant openings every year over the 2019 to 2023 period and a strong pipeline of additional restaurant openings in the future. In recent years, our growth has been driven by the rapid expansion of our franchisee network through the opening of new franchise restaurants under both existing and newly developed or acquired brand concepts. We have namely experienced continued and steady growth with Burger King France (excluding Quick), the second largest QSR chain in France and for which we are the exclusive French master franchisee, representing approximately 51% of our restaurant network.
