As a result, we increased our total points of sale from 708 as of December 31, 2019 to 1,059 as of March 31, 2024, a large proportion of which was driven by growth in our franchised restaurants, increasing the total franchised portion of our restaurant network from 71% in 2019 to 83% on March 31. 2024. This growth had a strong corresponding impact on our _Pro Forma SWS, which increased from €1.7 billion for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €2.8 billion for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our Pro Forma Adjusted Normalized EBITDA also increased from approximately €254 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, according to management estimates, to €307.4 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We believe our brand portfolio approach provides significant scale and synergies across brands, allowing us to capitalize on our market-leading capabilities, as illustrated by the successful roll-out of the Burger King brand in 159 ----- France to improve the performance of Bertrand Casual Foods’ current and future restaurant brands. Our operational model is well-established, historically successful and designed to be replicable across our existing and future restaurant brands. We facilitate a platform driven approach by leveraging our know-how and a synergistic approach to enhance brand operations and performance across all areas and stages of development. We have a historically proven ability to execute rapid roll-out and expansion through our in-house dedicated restaurant network development team, as well as to implement in-house processes for newcomer brands, which involves upgrading operations to meet our group-wide standards, transitioning into the franchised model, diversifying cuisine offerings and redefining brand concepts to resonate with current market preferences that we know well. These strategic initiatives were implemented to improve the financial performance and brand positioning of our existing brands allowing us to grow the proportion of franchised restaurants. This transition into our franchise operational model generates more profitability per restaurant, increasing the average restaurant sales (“ARS”) generated by each brand. For example, as part of Léon’s recent conversion into Léon Fish Brasserie, we redefined its concept and food offering to appeal to a younger and broader customer base, revamped its digital loyalty program to increase customer engagement, and accelerated restaurant openings under the franchise model. Together, these efforts contributed to an increase in ARS, evidenced by a 42% difference between the ARS of €1.2 million generated by Léon restaurants that are not yet converted and €1.7 million generated by the converted Léon Fish Brasserie restaurants, in each case for the year ended December 31, 2023. At the core of our success is our franchise model, which is strategically crafted to be both asset-light and cash generative. We have two principal types of franchise arrangements: Franchise with Lease Management, our franchise model through which we generate additional revenues from real estate lease fees from our franchisees, and Pure Franchise. By focusing the majority of our network on franchising rather than direct restaurant operations, we limit our exposure to the day-to-day fixed costs and investments typically associated with running food service establishments. Instead, these capital expenditure responsibilities are supported by our franchisees, who invest in the assets and infrastructure necessary to operate their locations. This approach allows us to concentrate on providing unparalleled franchisee support, brand stewardship and strategic growth initiatives. Our franchisees benefit from a proven business model that offers the potential for robust returns, while we capitalize on stable and predictable revenue streams through royalty fees, advertising fees and, in the case of Franchise with Lease Management, leasing fees. In turn, our franchisees are contractually required to adhere to the meticulously crafted brand standards for the restaurants they operate, the absence of which can result in termination of our contracts with them. Our model ensures a mutually beneficial partnership that drives collective success across our network of brands. We continue to strategically maintain and operate a limited number of selected directly-owned Company Restaurants, which represented 17% of our restaurant network as of the year ended December 31, 2023. This approach provides us with a platform to pilot new marketing, menu and omni-channel innovations before rolling them out across our franchise network. It also allows us to establish a benchmark of operational success through exemplary models for our franchisees to emulate, showcasing best practices in management, customer service and quality product. While operating a limited number of Company Restaurants will remain a key strategic part of our portfolio for these reasons, we expect the proportion of Company Restaurants in our restaurant network to decrease over time.

Our origins date back to 1997, with the launch of our first restaurant, Chesterfield Café. During the period between 1997 and 2010, we launched an additional restaurant concept, Bert’s, and acquired Angelina, a well-known tea salon in France, gaining the financial support of L Catterton along the way in 2006. In 2010, we acquired Au Bureau and Café Leffe, to expand our presence in the brewery space, of which Au Bureau remains an important legacy brand in our portfolio today. In 2013, we reintroduced the Burger King brand to the French market after a 15-year absence, by signing an exclusive master franchise agreement between Burger King France and BK Europe, the holder of the Burger King brand. In 2014, the Burger King App was first launched and in 2015, Burger King France’s first full year of activity, 16 Burger King restaurants were opened in France. Following the landmark agreement to operate Burger King in France, we acquired Financière Quick Group in 2015, an incumbent Burger QSR operator with nearly 400 prime restaurant locations in France as a means of accelerating our penetration of the French market through a process of converting Quick locations into Burger King locations. In the years to come, we demonstrated a successful track-record of expansion of our Burger King network in France, both through the conversion of Quick restaurants to the Burger King brand, as well as through new Burger 160 ----- King restaurant openings. This expansion achievement cemented our Group as a leader in the French restaurant industry, known for our ability to roll out and transform brand concepts. In July 2017, we acquired Groupe Flo, a restaurant group focused on casual and traditional dining, including the well-known French chain Hippopotamus. In July 2018, Bridgepoint became a financial partner to further support the development of our brands in France. We continued the growth of our restaurant brand portfolio in the coming years through the creation of the Volfoni restaurant chain in 2018, the acquisition of restaurant chain Léon de Bruxelles in 2019 (which we have transformed into the refined concept Léon) and the acquisition of restaurant chains Pitaya and Itsu in 2022. In addition, in furtherance of our investment in our omni-channel capabilities, in 2022 we acquired The Original Food Court, a proprietary technology that allows customers to order across all our restaurant brands. Prior to 2023, we operated our Burger King brand as a standalone group, separate from the remaining brands in our portfolio. As a result of the 2023 Reorganization, Bertrand Franchise acquired the brands currently in our portfolio, merging all of our existing brands within the same consolidated group. In 2024, we launched a new brand in our portfolio named Jôyô, which is a unique Asian Pub concept serving Japanese and American fusion food. In the course of over 26 years, we have become specialists of the restaurant industry in France, optimally operating several well-known restaurants throughout France and growing our network to address consumer needs across different market sectors.

Subsubsection Title: Attractive market in France with steady growth characteristics, under penetrated by brands and franchises
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the French food service market benefits from strong and sustainable growth characteristics, demonstrating resilience through business cycles and the COVID-19 pandemic. With a market size valued at €49.6 billion in 2023, the French food service market has historically experienced a steady growth rate, and we believe that it has significant untapped potential, particularly for restaurant chains and franchise businesses. Notably, the share of meals eaten outside the home in France remains significantly below that of more mature markets (such as the United Kingdom). With the growing shift in consumer preferences in France favoring more frequent outof-home meals, we believe this supports France’s market potential and room for growth. The French consumer food service market historically grew at a CAGR of approximately 2% per year in the pre-COVID era between the years 2016 and 2019, growing from approximately €50.3 billion in 2016 to approximately €52.9 billion in 2019. Following a brief decline in market growth in 2020, whereby the market briefly contracted to approximately €30.8 billion in 2020 due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the French food service market has since shown a strong recovery path, continuing to grow at an upward trajectory, reaching almost pre-COVID-19 levels. This recovery highlights the market’s resilience and the sector’s ability to adapt to changing market and consumer preferences, projecting a positive future growth trajectory. In the French food service industry, chains have historically been under-represented compared to independent establishments. However, this trend has accelerated in recent years, with the market share of foodservice chains increasing by over 9 percentage points, from 34% in 2019 to 43% in 2023. This evolution is driven by consumers’ growing preferences for the consistency, quality and diverse culinary experiences that chains are uniquely positioned to offer. The momentum behind chain restaurants is a reflection of deeper changes in consumer behavior and expectations, which we believe points towards continued growth and increased market penetration. Against this backdrop, we believe our food service franchising platform is uniquely positioned to capitalize on this momentum. Our business model, characterized by a diverse portfolio of well-established brands and a demonstrated operational framework that has historically expanded the brands that join our portfolio, positions us as a key player ready to seize the untapped potential within the evolving market. The demand for franchising, in particular, continues to grow, driven by entrepreneurs seeking to align with reputable brands that offer operational excellence, market agility, and strategic support. For example, the number of franchisees in France across various industries has grown by a CAGR of 5% from 1995 through 2023 to approximately 92,000 franchises overall. Further, we believe that there is room for growth in the number of franchisees in the food service sector, with 13% of the French food service sector represented by franchises as of 2023 (compared to 37% of the French grocery 161 ----- retail sector). We have already demonstrated our capacity to meet this demand, with an average annual growth of approximately 110 new franchise restaurants joining our network over the past three years. This significant growth potential for franchisors in the French food industry is underpinned by structural market trends and evolving consumer preferences, which we believe our portfolio brands effectively address. In particular, consumer trends have shown a shift in consumption habits, driven by a focus on convenient food options due to decreasing time available for cooking, a desire for new consumption occasions (from breakfast to dinner) across multiple channels (such as delivery), an increasing share of income allocated to out-of-home food purchases, and the generalization of company-subsidized lunch vouchers, which drive external food consumption. In addition, consumer tastes have evolved toward diverse and global cuisines, which include options for healthy food and gourmet products. Our portfolio responds to these evolving trends, encompassing a variety of eight wellpositioned distinct restaurant brands that cater to a wide range of attractive food service market segments, from QSR to casual dining eateries and addressing all-day consumption occasions across various channels. With the repositioning and modernizing of certain brands that joined our portfolio, such as Hippopotamus or Léon (see “— _Overview”), and the development of new products to meet consumer preference, such as the expanded veggie_ range of menu options for our Burger King brand, we have also demonstrated our ability to adapt our existing brands to evolving consumer needs.

Subsubsection Title: Leading multi-brand food service franchisor with a diverse portfolio of leading brands
Subsubsection Text: With 1,059 restaurants in our network as of March 31, 2024, we are the largest multi-brand restaurant franchising platform in France, with approximately twice the number of restaurants in our network as compared to our closest French multi-brand restaurant group competitor in 2023. We are distinguished not only by the number of restaurants in our network, but also by the unparalleled diversity of our portfolio. With eight distinct restaurant brands in our portfolio, each catering to different customer preferences and dining occasions, our platform offers a variety of culinary experiences that stands out in France. This diverse portfolio enables us to effectively address a broad spectrum of consumer preferences and dining needs, ranging from QSR to casual dining establishments. Anchoring our portfolio is the iconic global QSR brand, Burger King, which represents the largest restaurant brand within our network and the second-largest QSR player in France, with 18-20% market share in the chained burger QSR segment in 2023. We are Burger King’s master franchisee in France and are well positioned to leverage the scale and marketing of one of the most recognized brands in the restaurant industry worldwide. Our Burger King brand is the preferred QSR brand in the French market, with a market-leading net promoter score reflecting 96% brand awareness and digital presence. Since the reintroduction of Burger King in France in 2013, our outstanding performance has positioned France as the second-largest market for the Burger King brand globally, second only to the United States. This remarkable achievement was acknowledged with the “Franchisee of the Year” award at the Burger King World Convention in the fourth quarter of 2023. Our Burger King brand operations are best-in-class, with a robust franchising organization, local supply chain and omni-channel positioning. With a focus on building strong customer engagement through viral targeted marketing and a strong social media and mobile presence, we have significantly grown our presence in the digital market, and thus strengthened our market share, to include over 6 million Burger King active mobile app users globally as of March 31, 2024 and almost two million followers on social media across Instagram, TikTok, Facebook and X. The historical and continued success of Burger King within our portfolio underscores our significant presence in the competitive QSR market. Despite our current market leadership, there remains substantial whitespace for us to expand, particularly within the QSR segment. Compared to other countries, France remains a comparatively fragmented QSR market, with a lower number of QSR points of sale per 100,000 inhabitants as of 2023 compared, for example, to Spain, the United Kingdom and the United States, indicating a significant opportunity for growth for restaurant chains to further consolidate and grow their share of the market. We aim to capitalize on untapped market segments and further strengthen Burger King’s position in the French QSR landscape. Specifically, we believe we are well positioned to reduce the total network size gap between Burger King and its primary competitor, McDonald’s, which currently maintains a larger store network, thereby presenting compelling growth potential. Our strategic focus on expanding our footprint, coupled with the existing market dynamics, positions us favorably to capture a larger share of the market and drive sustained growth. 162 ----- Our robust portfolio includes seven other unique brands, presented below (see “—Highly-replicable business _model with proven capacity to integrate and develop acquired brands”), each with its own distinct concept,_ contributing to our overall market strength and diversity. Our strong brand portfolio includes Au Bureau, one of the largest brasserie/pub brands in France with 79-81% of market share in the branded café-bars market, Hippopotamus, one of the largest networks of steakhouses in prime locations, Léon, one of the leading fish and seafood brands in France and Pitaya, a fast-casual restaurant chain with a strong network with international presence and 31-33% of market share. We strive to operate with a mix of brands that include well-known historic brands, new organically developed brands and international well-known brands debuting in France. These complementary brands span a variety of food service segments, including Asian QSR, Italian casual dining, pubs and brasseries, and seafood restaurants, among others. This multiplicity of brands not only enriches our offering but also enhances our resilience by diversifying our revenue streams and reducing dependency on a single market segment. The success of these brands, alongside Burger King, exemplifies our proven ability to develop, manage, and grow a wide range of restaurant concepts. Together, they form a robust foundation for our continued expansion and reinforce our position as a leader in the French restaurant franchising industry.

Subsubsection Title: Best-in-class operations supported by proven synergistic operational platform
Subsubsection Text: We believe our brand portfolio approach provides significant scale and synergies across brands, allowing us to capitalize on our market-leading capabilities to improve the performance of our current and future restaurant brands. The collective strength of our brands, underpinned by a shared operational framework, ensures efficiency, consistency, and innovation at every level of the franchising experience. We provide our franchisees with food service industry expertise throughout their relationship with us to enhance their success, from site selection of a new restaurant through continued operational support. Our franchisees also benefit from the ability to diversity cuisine formats and models across our brand portfolio, with the ability to cover a specific geographical area with different brands. One of the cornerstone capabilities of our platform is our strategic approach to network roll-out and site sourcing. We boast an in-house dedicated market-leading property team, with over 20 years of experience and deep local knowledge of the areas in which we wish to grow our operations. Leveraging advanced proprietary sourcing and market insights, we identify prime locations that promise high foot traffic and optimal visibility for our franchisees. In partnership with prime institutional real estate investors and with a robust development team consisting of approximately 60 full-time employees with national coverage, we are able to access some of the most attractive locations as tenant of choice to quickly and efficiently open new restaurants for any of the brands in our portfolio. As a result of our efficient methodology, we have opened 103 new restaurants on average from 2016 through 2023, which we believe reflects one of the largest roll-out plans of other key food service peers in Europe. In the realm of brand management, our expertise ensures that each brand maintains its unique identity while benefiting from cross-brand strategies to increase customer brand awareness and engagement. With decades of expertise running restaurants driven by an entrepreneurial management team, we provide an innovative approach to brand management to sync the dining experience of each of our brands with the distinct customer preferences 163 ----- that each brand is tailored to. We aim to modernize the historic brands in our portfolio, with a focus on product and customer experience, to upgrade their brand image and sync the dining experience with our knowledge of what customers seek. In the context of a rapidly evolving food service landscape, we have strategically positioned our restaurant brand franchise network at the forefront of digital innovation and delivery partnerships. Recognizing the growing consumer demand for convenience and speed, we have invested heavily in developing a robust digital infrastructure that encompasses user-friendly online ordering platforms, mobile apps with intuitive interfaces, and integrated loyalty programs. In 2023, approximately 88% of our restaurants offered delivery services, with approximately €210 million in SWS generated across our portfolio over the same period from delivery sales. This digital ecosystem is designed to enhance the customer experience, making it seamless for patrons to engage with our brands, place orders, and receive their favorite meals wherever they are. Furthermore, our advanced delivery capabilities, supported by partnerships with leading delivery services, ensure that we can meet the high expectations for promptness and quality. This comprehensive approach to digital and delivery services not only drives additional revenue streams but also strengthens the competitive edge of our franchise network, ensuring that our brands remain relevant and preferred in a market that increasingly values digital convenience and reliable delivery options.

Subsubsection Title: Highly compelling proposition for strong pool of vetted franchisees
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, we partnered with over 420 franchisees across our restaurant brand network. Our franchise revenue model is based on the royalties and fees that we generate from our franchisees, which in turn are calculated on the basis of a percentage of their total SWS. As a result, our financial performance is inherently correlated to the sales performance of our franchisees and we engage in a meticulous new franchisee selection process to ensure that each franchisee in our network can uphold brand standards and deliver high-quality customer experience. For our Burger King brand, for example, we receive a high number of applications that we evaluate, with only about 7% of applications received ultimately approved to join our network. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 47% of our franchisee network operated more than one restaurant site. Based on precedent from our Burger King brand, we believe there is capacity to increase the number of restaurants per franchisee to more than 3 restaurants on average, providing growth potential for both new and existing franchisees. The largest franchisee within our network operates 12 restaurants, and we do not anticipate franchisees generally exceeding this level, ensuring a balanced and competitive franchise structure. Franchisees joining our network gain access to extensive benefits and expert support from a leading franchise system, positioning them for success from the outset of their franchise journey. At the core of these benefits is our commitment to providing best-in-class support, ensuring that every franchisee is well-equipped to thrive in the competitive food service industry. At the restaurant opening stage, franchisees benefit from up to six months of intensive training, laying a solid foundation for operational success. Our complete training support extends across each brand within the network, drawing on years of proven expertise in restaurant management. Additionally, 164 ----- franchisees gain access to financing partners with whom we have established historical relationships and are confident in our network’s robust operating track record. This comprehensive support system is designed to minimize the hurdles of starting a new business, ensuring franchisees are thoroughly equipped to meet market demands. Once operational, our restaurants have historically displayed attractive unit economics and rapid payback periods. Franchisees experience a rapid ramp-up on new openings (with a ramp-up period of less than a month for our Burger King brands and within three to six months for the other restaurant brands in our portfolio), thanks to our efficient operational model and the strong brand recognition of the brands in our portfolio. The network’s attractive cash management model enables franchisees to achieve rapid payback on their initial investment. Historically, franchisees have achieved payback for Burger King brand restaurants within three to four years, while franchisees for the rest of the brands in our portfolio (excluding Itsu and Pitaya) have achieved payback within four and a half to six years. Further, our Burger King brand restaurants typically generate approximately €3.8 million in ARS on average, while the other restaurants brands in our portfolio typically generate between approximately €0.8 million to €2.1 million in ARS, based on the same period. These attractive economics are bolstered by the attractive, adapted and flexible franchise terms that we offer franchisees under our different restaurant brands. We offer our franchisees two principal types of franchise arrangements: Franchise with Lease Management, our preferred franchise model for our Burger King brand, through which we generate additional revenues from real estate lease fees from our franchisees, and Pure Franchise, our preferred franchise model for the rest of the brands in our portfolio. Under the latter model, franchisees are able to own the business asset rights over the business. Each of our different brands also demand a different up-front equity investment, with Burger King brand requiring €250,000 up-front (of which €50,000 are entry fees) and the remainder of our brands requiring between €100,000 to €350,000 up-front, depending on the brand (of which €50,000 to €60,000 are entry fees). This flexibility allows franchisees to choose the brand and franchise model that best suits their business goals and financial abilities.

Subsubsection Title: Asset-light business model with high cash conversion and limited exposure to restaurant operations
Subsubsection Text: Our successful franchise-based business model, supported by a robust network of committed franchise partners, generates recurring and predictable revenues with high EBITDA margin, with 15% of revenues from franchisees as a percentage of SWS and 28% Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin for the year ended December 31, 2023. As of December 31, 2023, approximately 83% of our network was represented by Franchise Restaurants, while approximately 17% was represented by Company Restaurants. As a large majority of our restaurants are Franchise Restaurants, we operate with a strategic advantage by being largely insulated from the day-to-day operational costs associated with running a restaurant. This arrangement, where individual franchisees are responsible for the direct expenses of their establishments, allows us to focus on overarching brand development, marketing strategies, and network expansion without the financial burden and complexities of daily restaurant management. Consequently, our financial model is characterized by reduced operational risk and a streamlined cost structure, enhancing our ability to invest in long-term growth initiatives and support our franchisees from a strategic vantage point. The table below demonstrates the key features of each of our restaurant models: Company Restaurants, Franchise with Lease Management and Pure Franchise. 165 ----- (1) Advertising contribution from franchisees is entirely spent in marketing campaigns to promote the brands nationally. (2) Under Franchise with Lease Management contracts, we pay occupancy costs for the ownership of the business asset rights. (3) MFA royalties are paid for brands that we do not directly owned (i.e., between 3.5 and 4.5% of SWS for Burger King and approximately 3% of SWS for Itsu). Our focus on building and expanding our franchise network centers around an asset-light approach, pursuant to which we do not own the land, building or physical assets of the restaurants within our network. We derive the benefits of this asset-light model under both types of our franchise arrangements. This asset-light model allows for higher cash conversion and reduces or eliminates for locations with third-party landlord agreements our capital expenditures for such franchise openings. We have a strong cash conversion (measured as pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA minus our capital expenditures divided by pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA) of over 80%. In the case of Franchise with Lease Management restaurants, we partner with a diverse base of real estate investor partners who own the land and buildings where our restaurants operate. These properties are then leased to us, following which we sub-lease the land to our franchisees under our Franchise with Lease Management Model, allowing us to retain ownership of the business goodwill. As such, we are able to generate lease management fees while reducing our capital burden. Our franchisees are thereafter responsible for ongoing capital expenditures related to equipment, kitchen, furniture and fixtures. We generally incur no capital expenditure for two-thirds of our openings under the Lease Management Model. Indeed, in 2023, 30 out of 44 Burger King France openings were executed using the asset-light Pure Franchise model. Our franchisees under our Pure Franchise model lease their restaurant locations directly from third-party landlords. They directly invest in the physical assets required to establish and operate their individual locations, bearing responsibility for all capital expenditures, including building and development. We incur no opening capital expenditure under the Pure Franchise model. The table below demonstrates our enhanced cash conversion shown by the Burger King Group between 2019 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, as a result of the growth in our franchise network. The table below summarizes our asset-light network development model. 166 ----- In addition, our franchise-based model allows us to retain strong control over our network through our standard agreements with our franchisees, which govern various aspects of our relationship, including the royalties and fees due by them to us. We believe that our franchise model offers us favorable upsides as well as an attractive contractual protection and that our emphasis on growing this model in the future will continue to drive high cash conversion.

Subsubsection Title: Highly-replicable business model with proven capacity to integrate and develop acquired brands
Subsubsection Text: Our strategic growth lies in our highly replicable business franchise model, which has demonstrated a proven capacity for integrating and developing a diverse array of brands. Since 2010, we have successfully acquired, integrated and developed a number of successful brands, with demonstrated substantial performance improvement. This model is built on a foundation of meticulous sourcing of potential acquisitions. Our experienced in-house M&A team has a demonstrated capacity to identify some of the most compelling concepts for consumers and franchisees that show promise in terms of market fit and growth potential, backed by a privileged access to deal flow thanks to our market positioning and reputation as the “buyer of choice.” Once a brand is incorporated into our portfolio, we apply our playbook for successful integration by implementing our in-house best practices and processes. With over 20 years of experience in network development, we work with newly acquired restaurant brands to upgrade their operational processes, such as reporting and analytics. We also plug them into our network of resource pooling, leveraging on existing support functions. This ensures that each brand is seamlessly integrated into our network, benefiting from our wealth of experience and established systems for operational excellence. Our approach is also committed to redefining brand concepts to ensure they resonate with current market trends and consumer preferences. This involves a thorough analysis of the brand's core identity and offerings, followed by strategic adjustments that enhance its appeal without losing its unique character. Our goal is to elevate each brand to its fullest potential in alignment with our brand standards by updating menu items, revamping marketing strategies, redesigning the customer experience or enhancing the omni-channel distribution offering to customers. Developing the franchise network is the final piece of our model. With the brand concept refined and best practices in place, we focus on expanding the franchise network through targeted recruitment of franchisees in line with 167 ----- our recruitment criteria. Our support for franchisees is comprehensive, encompassing training, marketing, supply chain logistics, and ongoing operational guidance. This ensures not only the rapid expansion of the franchise network but also the sustainability of each franchise under our umbrella.

Subsubsection Title: Seasoned management team with a proven track-record supported by shareholders experienced in our industry
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from the experience and industry know-how of our senior management team, backed by our visionary founder, Olivier Bertrand. Olivier Bertrand, our board chairman, founded Groupe Bertrand in 1997 and has since been closely associated with our image, development and operations. Under his guidance, the Group has significantly transformed the franchise restaurant industry in France by developing existing brands and tremendously increasing their presence throughout the entire French territory. Our senior management team is led by our Chief Executive Officer, Christophe Gaschin, who joined the Group in 2016 and previously worked as a business lawyer with the Paris Bar for almost 17 years as a partner at major international law firms. Our Chief Financial Officer, Xavier Cottineau, joined the Group in September 2016 after serving as Chief Financial Officer at Financière Louis, as Finance Vice President at EuroDisney and senior financial auditor at PricewaterhouseCoopers. Our experienced management team has a long and successful history with a proven track record of developing, integrating and operating in the QSR and casual dining segment and has managed to lead our Group through evolutions to its business model, support our Group's growing network (including its franchise growth trajectory) and execute M&A transactions to further our business strategies. Our management team has also successfully managed our business through challenges that accompanied evolving government regulations and customer behavior in the face of the COVID-19 crisis, and guided the recovery of our operations to strong levels following the easing of COVID-19 related restaurant closure measures.
We believe that we benefit from the following key strengths:

Subsubsection Title: Expand our brand portfolio and franchise restaurant network to profitably increase our market share
Subsubsection Text: We believe there is significant untapped demand for franchised brands across France and internationally in Europe, supporting the potential to continue our successful expansion strategy. We plan to employ a dynamic strategy to expand the number of brands in our portfolio that can be franchised, leveraging both acquisitions and organic brand development as pivotal growth drivers. Through targeted M&A activities, we plan to strategically acquire brands that complement our existing portfolio, offering new concepts that respond to local consumer demand or enhancing our geographical footprint through increased network density. This approach allows us to rapidly scale our network, bringing in established brands with loyal customer bases and proven business models. Concurrently, we plan to continue to invest in the organic development of new brands, nurturing innovative concepts from the ground up to address emerging market trends and consumer demands. This dual strategy of external growth through acquisitions and internal growth through brand innovation ensures a continuous pipeline of fresh and diverse offerings within our franchise network. We also plan to further expand our restaurant network in collaboration with current and new franchisees to continue to increase our market share in France. We expect that a higher density of restaurants will further contribute to brand awareness, support customer loyalty and increase traffic in our existing restaurants, while our new restaurants will benefit from existing strong brands, reputation and know-how. We have a rigorous approach to expansion and expect to promote new restaurant growth primarily through opening Franchise with Lease Management restaurants for our Burger King brand, allowing us to maintain significant control over our network with limited capital expenditure. For the other brands in our network, we will focus on opening predominantly Pure Franchise restaurants, which further reduce our capital expenditures. With regard to Company Restaurants, these require significantly higher capital expenditures and introduces additional leases and personnel costs to our cost structure compared to franchise arrangements; consequently, we intend to limit the number of new Company Restaurants. 168 -----

Subsubsection Title: Continue to take advantage of attractive market fundamentals
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue leveraging our extensive and prime-location restaurant network and existing broad franchise network. We also seek to expand the product offerings in our existing restaurants to continue to tailor our offerings to evolving customer preferences by relying on our expertise in creating innovative, premium convenience food products that match customers’ demand, which we believe will be a key driver of our revenues. For example, we intend to continue to expand our healthy and nutritious product offering through the introduction of additional healthy options and preservative-free ingredients to further capture key markets, such as families, and anticipate market trends toward local sourcing, value-for-money products and healthy food options as well as meatless alternatives and products with no animal protein. We also plan to further strengthen our multi-channel approach through the enhancement of takeaway options and the development of new digital sales channels to further drive our growth. Finally, we intend to capitalize on increased consumption opportunities by the continued operation of our restaurants in the afternoon or late-night hours. We are also committed to continuing to capitalize on the inherent synergies within our diverse portfolio of brands. By leveraging shared resources, expertise, and operational efficiencies across our network, we aim to enhance the value proposition for our franchisees and deliver a superior experience to our customers. This includes optimizing our supply chain logistics, unifying marketing efforts to amplify brand visibility for each of the brands in our portfolio, and fostering innovation through the cross-pollination of ideas and best practices among our brands. Our commitment to harnessing these synergies not only drives operational excellence and cost savings but also positions us to respond more dynamically to market changes and consumer trends. We will remain focused on identifying and exploiting new opportunities for synergy, ensuring that our collective strength continues to be a cornerstone of our competitive advantage and growth strategy.

We intend to increase our market share of digital sales through the continued development and maintenance of our best-in-class multi-channel offering. We plan to continue to make improvements to our existing digital sales channels in order to maintain and increase our digital sales, while also developing additional innovative and convenient digital capabilities. While we have already successfully integrated the use of in-app orders and preorders, Click & Collect orders, in-store tablets that allow customers to skip the line and home delivery options with third-party aggregators for our Burger King brand, we also see opportunity in expanding our digital channels for the other brands in our network. Following the positive growth of these initiatives with the Burger King brand, we plan to replicate this model across our entire brand portfolio. Additionally, we have recently acquired The Original Food Court, a proprietary technology that enables customers to order seamlessly from all our brands, creating a “digital food court.” Our commitment to innovation in the omni-channel space positions our brands as industry leaders, providing convenience and accessibility to customers while promoting growth and profitability for our franchise partners. We believe that the current trends and growth observed in our digital sales, accelerated as a result of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, demonstrate a distribution channel that adapts to the changing preferences of our customers and is complementary to our in-restaurant dining channel. Further improving and increasing sales through our digital channel will enable us to capture an additional segment of the market by offering customers an easy and convenient dining option.

Subsubsection Title: Continue our commitment to sustainability and focus on improving our ESG performance
Subsubsection Text: Improving our ESG initiatives and growing our network while prioritizing sustainability initiatives is central to our business. Our key strategic ESG pillars include: (i) adapting our product offering to address future global challenges, (ii) promoting the well-being of our teams and (iii) limiting our environmental impact. With respect to our product offering, we intend to continue to promote local and quality product sourcing, innovate our offer to provide healthy and responsible food options (for example, for our Burger King brand, through a full permanent range of plant-based burgers, wraps, salads and sandwiches without animal protein) and apply stringent safety standards to our operations. In promoting the well-being of our teams, our goal is to create an inclusive workplace with frequent staff trainings and an emphasis on fighting against harassment. We are also focused on limiting our environmental impact through waste management initiatives, continued improvement of our logistics services and responsible growth of our business. 169 -----

Subsubsection Title: Focus on cost control and economies of scale
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to improve our gross margin and profitable expansion through leveraging our Bertrand Franchise platform to generate cost optimization, particularly for our supply chain and marketing. By streamlining these critical areas, we aim to achieve significant efficiencies and cost reductions that directly benefit our bottom line and enhance the profitability of our franchise network. While franchisees bear the food and logistic costs for their restaurants, we organize and negotiate the sourcing for both Company Restaurants and Franchise Restaurants through pre-approved suppliers and relationships with certain third-party logistics providers. Our food and logistics costs are significant, and we believe that we could drive restaurants’ gross margin through enhanced control of our logistics costs by exploiting economies of scale in line with the growth of our restaurant network, further developing local supplier networks and implementing cost control measures to reduce food waste. For example, we require all of our Burger King franchisees to source their raw materials from suppliers that BKC has previously approved and with whom we intend to continue to leverage our extensive restaurant network and economies of scale to obtain favorable commercial terms. In addition, suppliers have sought to invest in long-term partnerships with us, which has allowed us to reduce food costs and secure dedicated product lines to satisfy our needs. Apart from focusing on the optimization of our supply chain, we intend to further develop our communication and advertising campaigns to promote our brands, product offerings and commercial offers in order to reinforce awareness of our brands, build on their existing brand image and increase customer traffic, which we believe will also contribute to the improvement of our gross margin and profitable expansion. As a result of our continued growing network and presence in France, we believe we will have improved media buying conditions, allowing us to obtain a higher return on our marketing expenses.

Subsubsection Title: Drive EBITDA growth and cash generation to support deleveraging
Subsubsection Text: Our franchise model, combined with an asset-light approach for a significant share of new openings, is a pillar to our deleveraging strategy. We will continue to deploy this model through the continued expansion of Franchise Restaurants that permit us to actively manage our network, target specific whitespace and encourage the formation of denser clusters of restaurants, as well as to limit swings in our working capital. Where possible, in the case of Franchise with Lease Management restaurants, we will also favor third party landlord agreements allowing us to effectively reduce our new opening capex spend to nothing with new openings under the asset-light model lease management. In addition, we believe that tight cash control measures implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, coupled with the strong cash buffer built and maintained through the crisis, will allow us to continue focusing on deleveraging in the periods to come.
Our objective is to grow our business and increase profitability by implementing the following strategies:

Our Franchise Restaurants operate under two types of franchise arrangements: Franchise with Lease Management (used for approximately 47% of our Franchise Restaurants as of December 31, 2023, as compared to 53% of as of December 31, 2020) and Pure Franchise (used for approximately 53% of our Franchise Restaurants as of December 31, 2023 as compared to 47% as of December 31, 2020). While the obligations under our Franchise with Lease Management and Pure Franchise agreements are substantially similar, the main differences between the two arrangements concern the ownership of key rights pertinent to the operation of restaurants, including business assets rights (fonds de commerce), leasehold rights and ownership of business goodwill. The ownership 170 ----- of these rights in turn has an impact on the level of fees we collect from our franchisees, the distribution of capital expenditures as between us and our franchisees and the role we play in the construction and development of a new restaurant site. Notwithstanding these differences, both of these arrangements support our asset-light franchise model, as we do not directly own the restaurant real estate assets under any of our contractual relationships with franchisees. We have historically used both types of franchise arrangements and intend to continue to do so as our different brands tend to be better suited for one or the other. Our current focus is to prioritize our Franchise with Lease Management arrangement for the Burger King brand, while we plan to prioritize our Pure Franchise model for the remaining brands in our portfolio. _Franchise with Lease Management_ In a Franchise with Lease Management arrangement, we maintain ownership of the business assets rights (fonds _de commerce), leasehold rights and business goodwill. In general, we are the tenant of record with respect to the_ restaurant real estate which we typically lease from third party landlords (including, in certain cases, Foncière Bertrand, a Group affiliate which provides real estate services tailored for building restaurants) and we, in turn, sub-lease the restaurant real estate to the franchisee. As a result, the franchisee maintains contractual ties to us with both a franchise agreement to operate the restaurant under our brand and business asset rights in exchange for certain obligations and a tenancy agreement to rent the restaurant space at any specific location. Since the franchisee does not own the building or the business asset rights, this model encourages franchisee retention as franchisees who wish to keep operating their restaurant will need to renew their contract with us. Franchise with Lease Management is our core development model for future growth for the Burger King brand, providing network management, cost reduction and cash generation advantages. Of our 82 new franchise restaurant openings in the year ended December 31, 2023, 46% of them were opened under a Franchise with Lease Management arrangement. Under this arrangement, we are able to better direct network density by proposing new locations to new or existing franchisees. We take a more active role in site selection, development and construction under this arrangement through our existing real estate partners, which allows us to manage our expansion more strategically, rapidly and efficiently rolling out new restaurant sites with a consistent level of quality. Our franchisees who operate their restaurants under this arrangement pay us for the use of the real estate through a lease management fee based on a percentage of SWS, typically subject to a minimum yearly rent that coincides with our fixed costs under the relevant lease. In addition to these rent payments, the franchisee is also responsible for brand royalty payments and advertising contributions. These fees compensate us for the value of our business assets rights (fonds de commerce), which the franchisee operates, as well as for franchisee access to our knowhow and brand management services. While we retain some limited responsibility for building capital expenditures under this model, we are able to pass on most costs to our landlords, while our franchisees are responsible for other maintenance capital expenditures related to the kitchen, furniture and fixtures. _Pure Franchise_ In a Pure Franchise arrangement, the franchisee owns the business assets rights (fonds de commerce), leasehold rights and business goodwill and as such is fully responsible for the operation of the business and its relevant expenses, including all of the capital expenditures related to building, kitchen, furniture and fixtures. Our franchisees under our Pure Franchise arrangements are the tenants of record on the lease for the land on which the restaurant operates, paying rent directly to a third-party landlord. While we have ultimate decision power when choosing a new location for a restaurant, franchisees may propose a certain location that we may consider when deciding whether or not to open in a specific location. Our contractual ties under our Pure Franchise arrangements are limited to a franchise agreement, whereby franchisees contract to operate under our restaurant brand name. In a Pure Franchise arrangement, franchisor revenue is primarily generated from brand royalty and payments and advertising contributions as the lease revenue stream is not present in this arrangement. Pure Franchise is our core development model for future growth for most of the brands in our network. Of our 82 new franchise restaurant openings in the year ended December 31, 2023, 54% of them were opened under a Pure Franchise arrangement. While the Burger King brand primarily operates under a Franchise with Lease Management model (77%), in specific cases such as site concessions that preclude us from leasing the property directly, we also engage in Pure Franchise arrangements for this brand. Our Pure Franchise model is particularly attractive for franchisees seeking to leverage our established brands while maintaining a higher degree of autonomy. 171 ----- _Asset-Light Model_ Our Franchise Restaurant model centers around an asset-light approach, pursuant to which we do not own the land, building or physical assets of the restaurants within our network. We derive the benefits of this asset-light model under both types of our franchise arrangements. Under our Franchise with Lease Management Model, we partner with a diverse base of real estate investor partners who own the land and buildings where our restaurants operate. These properties are then leased to us, following which we sub-lease the land to our franchisees under our Franchise with Lease Management Model. As such, we are able to generate lease management fees while reducing our capital burden. Our franchisees are thereafter responsible for ongoing capital expenditures. Our franchisees under our Pure Franchise model lease their restaurant locations directly from third-party landlords and directly invest in the physical assets required to establish and operate their individual locations, bearing responsibility for all ongoing capital expenditures, including building and development. Real estate expenditures traditionally represent substantial fixed costs for food service operators, and this asset light model has allowed us to significantly improve our cash conversion and EBITDA margins. This approach also allows us to easily and rapidly replicate our franchising model to new restaurants and brands that join our network. We seek to uniformly implement this model across all of our restaurant brands by transitioning any preceding directly-owned ownership models to our asset-light model. _Royalties and Fees Paid by Franchisees_ We generate revenue from our Franchise Restaurants through a structured franchise royalty and fee system, designed to support the growth and maintenance of our network of brand restaurants. The ongoing royalties and fees we generate from our franchisees is generally fixed as a percentage of SWS, which level varies depending on the brand and type of franchise arrangement (either Franchise with Lease Management or Pure Franchise). This model ensures a consistent and predictable revenue stream, while also providing franchisees with the infrastructure support they require to maintain and grow their SWS. When a franchisee opens a Franchise Restaurant, we charge a new one-off franchise fee, which generally ranges between €40,000-€50,000. In connection with Burger King Franchise Restaurants, we transfer a portion of these new franchisee fees to BKC to cover entrance fees owed in connection with the opening of each new Burger King Franchise Restaurant and retain a portion as compensation for our role as master franchisee. See “— Burger King.” Subsequent to the initial investment, franchisees pay certain fees on an on-going basis that generally fall within three distinct categories: brand royalties, advertising fees and, in the case of our franchisees that operate under the Franchise with Lease Management model, lease management fees. Additionally, for many of our brands, we receive “commercial cooperations” which correspond to income derived from supplier rebates. The fixed percentage of brand royalties that we collect monthly from our franchisees ranges across our network and brands, generally from 5.0% to 9.0% of SWS. In the case of Burger King, for which franchisees pay monthly royalties of 9% of SWS, we pay, under the terms of the Master Franchise Agreement, one half of this amount to BK Europe, the affiliate of BKC, leaving us with a net amount of 4.5% of SWS in brand royalties. For most of our other brands, brand royalties range between 5.0% to 6.5% of SWS. Our Pitaya brand bears a slightly different structure where brand royalties paid to us by franchisees are slightly lower than other brands (2.0% of SWS). However, franchisees of our Pitaya brand also pay know-how fees and support fees, each representing 2.0% of SWS annually. In addition to brand royalties, we also expect our franchisees to actively participate in the development of the brands that they operate by contributing to our marketing and advertising campaign. Such advertising fees range across our network and brands from 1.0% to 4.0% of SWS annually. For our Franchises with Lease Management, our standard arrangement provides that franchises pay lease management fees equal to a percentage of their sales, ranging from 12.0% to 15.0% of SWS across our network and brands. As we are the tenant of record on the leases for Franchise Restaurants operated under Franchise with Lease Management arrangements, we generally pay on a quarterly basis the landlords for the use of these properties an amount between 5.5% and 6.5% of the franchisee SWS that we generate. In addition to royalties and fees paid by franchisees, we benefit from rebates granted by suppliers to our Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon and Volfoni brands. See “—Operational Synergies of our Multi-Brand Franchise _Model—Supply Chain & Procurement Platform.”_ 172 ----- _Franchisee Selection Criteria_ As of December 31, 2023, we partnered with over 420 franchisees across our restaurant brand network, of which 47% operated more than one restaurant and 8% operated more than five restaurants. Our franchisees operate, on average, two restaurants. Our largest franchisee operates 12 restaurants. We actively seek to expand our restaurant network by identifying strategic, high-caliber franchisee partners. Since our franchise revenue model is based on the royalties and fees that we generate from our franchisees, which in turn are calculated on the basis of a percentage of their total SWS, our financial performance is inherently correlated to the sales performance of our franchisees. As a result, it is imperative that we partner with franchisees that demonstrate the acumen to drive sales growth, uphold brand standards and deliver high-quality customer experience. Where possible, we seek to work with franchisees that have the willingness and capacity to operate within multiple restaurant brands within our portfolio. Their multi-brand operations enable them to leverage cross-brand knowhow, optimize market coverage and diversify their revenue streams, which in turn enhances the overall stability and resilience of our franchise network. These franchisees often have a deeper understanding of local market dynamics and consumer preferences, which in turn helps them better tailor the customer experience across different brands and formats. Before entering into a new agreement with a potential franchisee, we conduct rigorous due diligence procedures to ensure that they meet our strategic criteria. While we do not grant any of our franchisees for the Burger King network the right to an exclusive territory, we may grant such rights for other brands in our portfolio, such as Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Volfoni and Léon. Our franchise agreements are typically between nine and ten years in length. For our Burger King brand, our franchise agreements under our Franchise with Lease Management arrangements are generally valid for a period of nine years which can be automatically renewed only if certain cumulative conditions relating to the franchisee, its financial situation and its compliance with our operational standards are met. The agreement can be renewed only once. If prescribed renewal conditions are not met, the agreement terminates at the end of the first nine-year period. The renewal of our franchise agreements is generally contingent upon the fulfillment of several criteria, including that franchisees are up to date with all required payments to us and investments for their restaurants, that they are financially solvent, that they have historically maintained a level of performance in line with our standards (such as achieving minimum required scores in annual checks, covering key operational areas such as hygiene, safety, quality, and cleanliness, as well as adherence to other brand standards) and that the teams they have hired to operate restaurants are deemed sufficient in number. In addition, franchisees must demonstrate a commitment to the strategy of the brand they operate, and there must be no ongoing disputes (judicial or otherwise) between us and our franchisees. Our franchise agreements for Pure Franchises are generally entered into for a period of ten years and may continue up to a duration of twenty years. We may terminate our agreements with our franchisees for certain reasons, including failure to pay royalties and other fees and failure to operate restaurants in accordance with our standards. For our Burger King brand, BKC may also direct us to terminate any of our franchise agreements under certain circumstances to protect the integrity of the Burger King brand. Our franchise agreements also contain certain provisions that prohibit the franchisee from operating another restaurant business that would compete directly with our business, or in a location where the restaurant would compete with an existing restaurant of the same brand within our portfolio. In addition, our agreements impose certain non-compete restrictions on our employees. For example, for our Burger King brand, during the period of an employee’s employment contract and for six months after such contract has been terminated, an employee may not go and work in another Burger King restaurant.

In addition to Franchise Restaurants, we directly operate a limited number of Company Restaurants to anchor our network, both in respect of key flagship locations and supply chain management, to demonstrate the benefits of operating our restaurants, to pilot new concepts and menu innovation and to diffuse know-how to current and potential franchisees by providing a model for them to emulate. Company Restaurants can be operated temporarily or for the medium-term until future franchisees are chosen or a current franchisee is ready to start operating an additional Franchise Restaurant. As of December 31, 2023, we operated a total of 183 Company Restaurants, representing 17% of the total number of restaurants in our network, which collectively generated €515 million of _Pro Forma SWS. While our core 173 ----- business is represented by our franchisor activity, we foresee the continued operation of a limited number of Company Restaurants in the future to continue to derive the benefits they provide as models for the full network.
Certain of our Burger King brand restaurants are operated through our 50/50 joint ventures with the Auchan Group, Agaking and Agabk, which, together operate 26 restaurants.

Our primary operating model is to operate our restaurants through a franchisee (Franchise Restaurants), which represented 83% of our network as of December 31, 2023 (compared to 71% as of December 31, 2019). We also directly operate a limited number of restaurants (Company Restaurants), representing 17% of the total number of restaurants in our network, which we believe provide strategic advantages to help maintain our operational standards across our entire restaurant network.

Our success is driven by our ability to identify and grow a portfolio of brands that allow us to cater to a wide array of tastes and dining preferences while maintaining the authenticity and character of each brand. Each of the brands in our portfolio possess a distinct identity that resonates with its dedicated customer base. We are also focused on curating a portfolio of brands of high-growth brands that have the potential to lead their respective markets. As of December 31, 2023, we operated eight brands in our portfolio, as follows: _Our Main Brand, Burger King France_ Burger King stands as one of the largest global fast-food chains, positioned as a direct competitor to McDonald’s with a focus on offering a more premium, flame-grilled taste experience. Its marketing emphasizes customer choice and personalization under the slogan “Have it your way,” aiming to differentiate itself with the promise of higher-quality ingredients and a unique cooking method that sets its burgers apart from others in the QSR industry. We are the master franchisee for the Burger King brand in France. Burger King is an important strategic brand in our portfolio, with 544 restaurants (including one Quick restaurant under conversion) representing 51% of our total restaurant network as of March 31, 2024. Burger King generated €1,969 million in Pro Forma SWS and €244 million in Pro Forma EBITDA for the twelve months ended 31, 2024, representing 70% of our Pro Forma SWS and 84% of our Pro Forma EBITDA, respectively. Through our rigorous site selection, a commitment to high quality and a strong focus on innovation across product offerings and omni-channel capabilities, we were able to successfully increase our Burger King France SWS from €1,136 million as of December 31, 2019 to €1,969 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, with an increase in our points of sale from 384 to 544 (including one Quick restaurants under conversion) over the same periods. The average basket size (excluding VAT) of Burger King in France is €16. Burger King has played a pivotal role in our historical growth trajectory, demonstrating our capability to apply our deep knowledge of the food service industry and blueprint of key operational processes to develop the Burger King brand in France after a 15-year absence into a market-leading, high-quality brand tailored to the unique preferences of a French clientele. In 2013, our principal shareholder Groupe Bertrand reintroduced the Burger King brand to the French market by signing an exclusive master franchise agreement between Burger King France and BK Europe, the holder of the Burger King brand. Our network expansion plan was driven in part by a strategy to acquire an incumbent Burger QSR operator with nearly 400 restaurant locations in France in order to convert their existing restaurants, which we did in 2015, when we acquired Financière Quick Group. We demonstrated a successful track-record of expansion of our Burger King network in France, through our two-pronged strategy of converting Quick restaurants to the Burger King brand and opening new Burger King restaurant. Burger King also serves as a testament to the strength and resilience of the operational model that we have developed, as demonstrated through Burger King’s performance in France throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. To cope with external restrictions during this period, we further enhanced our multi-channel offerings, including through the expansion of our drive-through and takeaway services by using new Click & Collect channels, the development of our home delivery options and our integration with third-party delivery aggregators. The further enhancement of such offerings allowed us to protect our top line during the COVID-19 pandemic restrictions by offsetting the reduction in on-premise customer traffic and allowing customers to access our products through alternate channels. In addition, we were also focused on supporting our franchisees through the challenges of the pandemic, closely monitoring their financial health and adapting our support initiatives as the impact of the pandemic on our franchisees’ performance evolved. For example, during the period of the first lockdown in France, we implemented temporary royalty adjustments for our franchisees. We also temporarily waived the 174 ----- obligation of our franchisees under our Franchise with Lease Management arrangements to pay us a minimum lease management fee. As a result of such measures, none of our franchisees experienced a default of their payment obligations to third parties. Collectively, these measures allowed us to rapidly ramp up following each of the most severe COVID-19-related restrictive periods in France, with monthly sales immediately following each lockdown nearly recovering to prelockdown periods. For example, in June 2020, our SWS under the Burger King brand recovered to €73 million as compared to the €85 million pre-lockdown level in February 2020. Similarly, in December 2020, the month during which the second lockdown restrictions were lifted, our SWS reached €86 million as compared to the €94 million pre-lockdown SWS recorded in October 2020. Further, despite the implementation of a curfew in France ending in June 2021, we were able to achieve consistently increasing SWS levels from April 2021 through August 2021, which we believe emphasizes the resilience of our business model, further supported by the long-term integration of the measures we adopted in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. _The Burger King Master Franchise Agreement_ In November 2013, our subsidiary Burger King France entered into a master franchise and development agreement with BK Europe for a period of 20 years, the duration of which has since been amended in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic to extend for an additional year through December 31, 2034, with the option to extend the term for an additional 10 years at expiration, subject to certain conditions (such agreement, as amended from time to time, the “Master Franchise Agreement”). Pursuant to the terms of the Master Franchise Agreement, we have the exclusive right to develop the Burger King brand in France and may grant third parties the right to operate Burger King restaurants in exchange for the payment of royalties and license fees. Pursuant to the Master Franchise Agreement, we may enter into franchise agreements with third parties to operate and manage their own Burger King restaurants in France. As the master franchisee for France, we are responsible for the management and strategic development of the network’s brand development, promotion, execution of a marketing and advertising strategy and certain other services, for which we are remunerated by franchisees through fees and royalties. We are also entitled to use related trademarks, logos and trade names and receive access to BKC’s know-how and the processes that it has developed. The Master Franchise Agreement imposes certain obligations that we must respect in order to maintain the exclusive rights to develop the Burger King brand in France. Certain default provisions under the Master Franchise Agreement include, among others: (i) failure to pay BKC amounts we owe under the Master Franchise Agreement; (ii) transferring or assigning our rights under the Master Franchise Agreement; (iii) if we or any of our affiliates acquire an interest in a competitor; or (iv) if we enter into insolvency proceedings. If the Master Franchise Agreement is terminated for any reason, we do not lose the right to continue the operation of the Burger King restaurants that we have already established. However, we will lose our exclusivity right and be unable to further expand our presence and market share in France. The Master Franchise Agreement also contains certain covenants related to the expansion of Burger King in France that we must respect in order to maintain the exclusive development rights for the Burger King brand in France. _Our Other Brands_ - **_Au Bureau: Au Bureau is a pub and restaurant chain that offers a convivial atmosphere reminiscent of traditional British pubs, combined with a diverse menu that includes classic pub fare and French bistro favorites. Positioned as a casual dining brand, it caters to those looking for a relaxed environment to enjoy a meal, watch sports events and socialize, making it a popular choice for both after-work gatherings and family outings. With its distinctive pub ambiance and a commitment to a quality dining experience, Au Bureau has carved out a niche in the French hospitality market. The average basket size (excluding VAT) of Au Bureau is €25. - **_Hippopotamus: Hippopotamus is a French steakhouse chain known for its focus on high-quality grilled meats, particularly beef, offering a classic and contemporary dining experience. Positioned as a familyfriendly restaurant, it provides a warm and inviting atmosphere where customers can enjoy a variety of cuts prepared to their liking, along with a selection of traditional French sides and wines. With its commitment to serving quality steaks at accessible prices, Hippopotamus has established itself as a goto destination for meat lovers across France. The average basket size (excluding VAT) of Hippopotamus is €24. 175 ----- - **_Léon:_** Léon is a restaurant chain that specializes in traditional French and Belgian cuisine, with a particular emphasis on seafood, including its signature moules-frites. Positioned as a family-friendly bistro, Léon combines a cozy, inviting atmosphere with a menu that celebrates the simplicity and heartiness of classic European dishes, aiming to provide a consistently enjoyable dining experience at a moderate price point. This approach has allowed Léon to maintain a strong presence in the casual dining sector, appealing to a broad demographic seeking both quality and value. The average basket size (excluding VAT) of Léon is €24. - **_Pitaya: Pitaya is a fast-casual restaurant chain inspired by Thai street food, offering a vibrant array of authentic Thai dishes prepared quickly in an open kitchen setting. With its emphasis on fresh ingredients, bold flavors, and a lively atmosphere, Pitaya positions itself as a go-to destination for those seeking an exotic culinary experience without the need for formal dining. The brand capitalizes on the growing trend of health-conscious eating and global cuisine, attracting a diverse clientele looking for a fast, flavorful and healthy meal option. The average basket size (excluding VAT) of Pitaya is €13. - **_Volfoni: Volfoni is a contemporary Italian restaurant chain in France that offers a modern twist on classic Italian cuisine, with a menu that includes a variety of pizzas, pastas, and other traditional dishes. Positioned as a casual yet trendy dining option, Volfoni aims to provide a warm and inviting atmosphere for families, friends, and business associates alike, while emphasizing the authenticity and quality of its ingredients. The brand seeks to blend the charm of Italian gastronomy with a chic and comfortable setting, making it a popular choice for those who appreciate a refined yet relaxed dining experience. We created and developed the Volfoni brand concept and restaurant chain from scratch in 2018. The average basket size (excluding VAT) of Volfoni is €25. - **_Itsu: Itsu is a chain of East Asian-inspired fast-casual eateries, known for its health-conscious menu that includes sushi, salads, soups and rice bowls. With a focus on providing nutritious, low-calorie, and fresh meals quickly, Itsu positions itself as a contemporary and stylish choice for the health-savvy consumer on the go. The brand emphasizes sustainability and responsible sourcing, appealing to a demographic that values both wellness and environmental consciousness in their dining options. The average basket size (excluding VAT) of Itsu is €15. - **_Jôyô: Jôyô is a unique Asian Pub concept that offers Japanese and American fusion food; Positioned as a casual dining brand, with its distinctive ambiance, it caters to those looking for a relaxed environment for both after-work gatherings and family outings to enjoy a meal.

Our restaurant brands have a restaurant network through all regions of France, with 7% located in key major cities in strategic locations throughout Paris, Marseille and Lyon. 176 ----- The table below shows a breakdown of our network of restaurants in mainland France by brand and operating model as of March 31, 2024:

Subsection Title: Number of restaurants Burger King (excluding one Quick restaurant) ..................................** **543
Operational Synergies of our Multi-Brand Franchise Model
Subsubsection Text: Our portfolio encompasses a diverse array of restaurant brands, each carefully tailored to embody a unique identity and address customer appeal. We centralize our brand management to a dedicated internal team that seeks to reinforce brand differentiation by clearly defining brand concepts to allow for consistent messaging and quality across each of our brands, enhancing brand recognition and awareness. When we integrate a new restaurant brand in our portfolio, we focus on improving its brand concept by aligning its menu, products and pricing architecture to our assessment of its target market. This process has historically generated improvement in our newcomer brands. 177 ----- We take advantage of our knowledge across different food segments to centralize product development to ensure that the menus of our restaurant brands both correspond to their concept and adapt to evolving consumer preferences. This centralized approach also allows us to closely monitor our price positioning to maintain our competitive position in the market. Beyond the menu we offer our customers, we also seek to innovate on production processes and methods in our kitchens by monitoring and identifying the best equipment to optimize work organization to deliver the best dining experience to our customers.

Subsection Title: Operational Synergies of our Multi-Brand Franchise Model
Subsubsection Text: As part of our brand management activities, we are focused on marketing, advertising and promotion for each of our brands that reinforce their brand positioning. We believe that an effective marketing and advertising strategy is essential for the success of our brands as marketing and advertising programs are a key traffic driver and enable us to attract new customers to our restaurants and retain existing customers’ loyalty. In order to reinforce awareness of our brands, build on our image and generate footfall, we invest annually in innovative and creative multimedia advertising campaigns. Our advertising expenses are partly financed by our franchisees, who are required under the terms of their franchise agreements to contribute a percentage of sales (between 1.0% to 3.5% of SWS annually depending on the brand and franchise arrangement) as advertising fees, which we then use to market, advertise and promote initiatives and programs for the brands they are part of. Restaurants’ SWS and results of operations can be significantly affected by the frequency and effectiveness of our advertising and promotional programs. We use three levels of advertising: (i) system-wide advertising, which is coordinated and centralized in our headquarters outside of Paris; (ii) digital and social media advertising; and (iii) local advertising, which franchisees handle with materials we create or approve. Franchisees may not use their own advertising materials without our prior consent. In addition, in the case of Burger King, we must obtain BKC’s prior approval for all of our marketing, advertising and promotional programs and initiatives. As a result, our marketing efforts for the Burger King brand are often developed and rolled out in close coordination with BKC.
