DESCRIPTION OF THE GROUP AND BUSINESS Bertrand Franchise (the “Company”) is a simplified joint stock company under French law. Its registered office is located at 34 Rue Mozart, 92110 Clichy. The Company is registered in the Nanterre Trade and Companies Register under number 839 070 067. Bertrand Franchise is a platform for multisegment franchise restaurant brands, and is today positioned as the French leader in franchise restaurants. Diversified and multi-brand, this group manages brands with different positioning: - Burger King®, a fast food chain predominantly serving hamburgers, using its own “flame grilled” cooking know-how and techniques; - “Bertrand Casual Food” themed dining which includes: `o` Au Bureau®: an English pub and Brasserie-themed restaurant chain. `o` Hippopotamus®: a restaurant chain specialising in beef and grilled meat in the “Steakhouse” format; `o` Léon Fish Brasserie®: a restaurant chain specialising in seafood, fish and fresh mussels cooked on site; `o` Volfoni®: a fast food chain specialising in quality traditional Italian cuisine; `o` Pitaya®: a restaurant chain specialising in Thai street food; `o` Itsu®: a specialist in Asian-inspired cuisine. The interim consolidated financial statements summarised for the 3-month period ending 31 March 2024, present the accounting position of Bertrand Franchise S.A.S and its subsidiaries (the “Group”), as well as its holdings in joint ventures (see note 2.2 and 3.2). The Group’s financial year is from 1 January to 31 December. The comparability of interim and annual accounts is not particularly affected by the seasonal nature of operations. #### 2. SIGNIFICANT EVENTS OF THE PERIOD AND POST CLOSING EVENTS ###### 2.1. Significant events of the period The first quarter of 2024 was marked by the an increase of +5.7% over one year for the same following significant events: period in 2023. Over one year, food prices increased by +1.7% in Inflation of raw materials and energy costs** March 2024, after +3.6% in February. They have thus been slowing for the twelfth consecutive The first quarter of 2024 was marked by a month. marked slowdown in inflation with a price Over a year, energy prices rose by 3.4% in March increase of +2.3% over one year compared with 2024, after +4.3% in February. ----- This slowdown in energy prices over one year is explained by the fall in gas prices (-11.3% after ‐ 7.6%) and the slowdown in electricity prices (+20.4% after +23.1% - in March 2024, energy prices fell by -0.7% compared to February 2024). (Source INSEE (Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques [National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies]) [https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/8071596#](https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/8071596#titre-bloc-11) [titre-bloc-11](https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/8071596#titre-bloc-11) and [https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/7453512)](https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/7453512) In addition, in this context, the Group, thanks to its strategies of purchases made during the 2023 financial year, has managed to control the evolution of energy prices with the implementation of electricity forward purchasing contracts with its suppliers.

After opening 44 restaurants in 2023 under the Burger King® brand in mainland France, and acquiring a majority share in Burger King operations on the island of Réunion in the 2[nd] quarter of 2023 (ownership and direct operation of 17 restaurants on the island), the Group continued its development in the first quarter of 2024 with the opening of 9 new restaurants operated under the Burger King® brand. Following acquisitions and contributions of securities from Groupe Flo, United Lab, Miditsuco GB, Holdco GB and Bertrand Franchise Services, 519 new restaurants operated under the brands Au Bureau®, Hippopotamus®, Léon Fish Brasserie®, Léon de Bruxelles®, Volfoni®, Pitaya® and Itsu® joined the Bertrand Franchise scope in 2023. The Group also opened 10 new restaurants under these same brands between 31 October and 31 December 2023. In the first quarter of 2024, the Group opened 9 new restaurants operated under these same brands. Lastly, in February 2024, the Group acquired the Joyo brand, which is operating a restaurant as of 31 March 2024 through a franchise agreement These growth initiatives were supported by significant investments from the Group’s lessors and franchisees, thus limiting the Group’s remaining net investment and maintaining sustainable and profitable growth across all its brands.
Mr Christophe Gaschin was appointed Managing Director of the Company for an indefinite period as of 15 March 2024.

On 15 March 2024, the Shareholders authorised the Chairperson to award a maximum number of 13,699 ordinary shares as a bonus to corporate officers and employees of the Group. The Chairperson decided that same day to make use of this authorisation and proceeded with the bonus issue of 7,830 ordinary shares.

System-wide sales are sales to consumers of restaurants owned outright as well as those operated by our franchise partners under the brands Burger King®, Au Bureau®, Léon®, Volfoni®, Hippopotamus®, Pitaya®, Itsu® and Joyo®. As of 31 March 2024, Group system-wide sales amounted to €689.2 million compared to €431.7 million as of 31 March 2023. ###### 2.2. Reorganisation of Groupe Bertrand in 2023 In 2023, Groupe Bertrand wanted to enhance its autonomous divisions as of 3 July 2023 (see note growth by streamlining its various operations. To 1): do this, Groupe Bertrand reorganised its operations to distinguish two distinct and - Bertrand Hospitality, in particular for its operations in unique places with specific ----- know-how: breweries, concessions, tea   - Bertrand Franchise, for Bertrand Casual rooms, retail and hotels; Food and Burger King. Subsubsection Text: Post-reorganisation, after 31 October 2023, the simplified organisational chart of the Group is as follows: To do this, Groupe Bertrand carried out the following legal reorganisation: - On 3 July 2023, through transfers and contributions of securities, (i) Groupe Flo became the parent company of the entities under brand names Au Bureau®, Hippopotamus®, Léon® and Volfoni®, and (ii) Miditsuco GB became the parent company of the Bertrand Franchise entities under the brand name Itsu®.

Subsection Title: United JVCO BQ Participation** **(Alpinvest / Goldman Groupe Bertrand (Bridgepoint)** **Sachs Asset Management) Bertrand Franchise Bertrand Hospitality (formerly TopCo) Bertrand** **Miditsuco** **Holdco GB** **Bertrand** **United Groupe Flo** **MidCo GB Restauration Holding** **(Itsu)** **(Pitaya)** **Franchise Services** **Lab Au Other** **Hippo** **Léon** **Volfoni** **Burger King France Bureau  Percentage of holding** **Consolidated financial statements  Voting rights
Subsubsection Text: - On 31 October 2023, the company TopCo GB, parent company of the Burger King France group, 60% owned on this date by Groupe Bertrand and 40% by Bridgepoint, became Group Head of the Bertrand Franchise division through acquisitions and contributions of securities of Groupe Flo, United Lab, Miditsuco GB (parent company of the Itsu sub-group), Holdco GB (parent company of the Pitaya sub-group) and ----- Bertrand Franchise Services (parent company of Bertrand Franchise Logistics), with a view to bringing together all franchise operations under one entity (see note 1). At the same time TopCo GB became Bertrand Franchise (see note 1), a platform of multisegment franchise restaurant brands. Bertrand Franchise thus increased its equity by €368.0 million by issuing 380,730 ordinary shares and 19,783 preference A shares to Bertrand Franchise Corp. as compensation for said contributions of securities (see note 12). All of these entities and operations were and remain controlled by Groupe Bertrand, led by the group head company BH. Equity investment by United JVCO Limited and repayment of Bertrand Franchise convertible bonds Concomitantly with the contributions made by Groupe Bertrand on 31 October, United JVCO Ltd (a joint venture owned 50/50 by Alpinvest and Vintage) made an equity investment in the Group by subscribing to Bertrand Franchise’s preference shares for an amount of €458 million, which resulted in the issuance of 302,052 preference B shares (see note 12). With regard to IFRS standards, these preference shares are analysed as equity instruments, which do not confer on the new shareholder a contractual commitment to receive any remuneration whatsoever in the form of cash or other financial assets. At the end of this capital increase, the Group repaid in advance its convertible bonds subscribed by Bridgepoint for a residual amount of €297.6 million in principal and €22.6 million in accrued interest (corresponding to 400,000 convertible bonds). At the end of all these operations, as of 31 October 2023, Bertrand Franchise is 60.75% owned by Bertrand Franchise Corp (for voting rights of 74.29%), 21.25% by BQ Participations (for voting rights of 74.29%) and 18% by United JVCO (for null voting rights). ###### 2.3. Subsubsection Text: ----- ###### 6.1.1. Sales to consumers Sales to consumers amounted to €121.1 million in the first quarter of 2024, compared to €61.2 million in the first quarter of 2023, an increase of €59.9 million. The increase in sales to the Group’s consumers is explained in particular by: - The opening of a new restaurant under the Burger King® brand in mainland France during the first quarter of 2024, operated directly by the Group; - The contribution of the 17 restaurants Bertrand Casual Food scope. Of these restaurants, 91 were contributed following the contributions of Groupe Flo and other subsidiaries on 31 October 2023 (see note 2.2). This increase was partially offset by: - 3 permanent closures of restaurants operated by Bertrand Casual Food under the Pitaya brand during the first quarter of 2024; - The transfer to franchised partners, acquired on Reunion Island during the during the first quarter of 2024, of the second quarter of 2023 and operated operation of 4 restaurants belonging to under the Burger King® brand; the Burger King Group scope, and 2 - The contribution of 92 new restaurants restaurants belonging to the Bertrand operated by the Group as of 31 March Casual Food scope, all five previously 2024, under brands belonging to the operated directly by the Group. ###### 6.1.2. Fees and other invoices to franchisees As of 31 March 2024, the Burger King® brand is operated through 461 franchised restaurants (compared to 422 restaurants under the Burger King® brand and 5 restaurants under the Quick® brand as of 31 March 2023). For Bertrand Casual Food, 423 franchised restaurants were operated by the Group as of 31 March 2024, including 183 under the Au Bureau® brand, 17 under the Volfoni® brand, 125 under the Pitaya® brand, 68 under the Hippopotamus® brand, 26 under the Léon Fish Brasserie® brand, 3 under the Léon de Bruxelles® brand and one under the Joyo® brand. Fees to franchisees amounted to €100.3 million for the first quarter of 2024, compared to €81.5 million for the first quarter of 2023, an increase of €18.8 million. This increase compared to the first quarter of 2023 is mainly related to the increase in sales to the Burger King Group brand as well as the Group’s reorganisation and acquisitions at the end of 2023 (see note 2.1). As of 31 March 2024, the fees to franchisees include, in particular, the lease-management fees, including €17.8 million in rent (compared to €16.9 million as of 31 March 2023). Subsubsection Text: Income from consumer sales include that from food products sold in restaurants owned and directly operated by the Group as well as the related restaurant service. Income from sales is accounted for at the time the control of the goods is transferred to the customer, i.e. at the time of cash payment for consumer sales in directly operated restaurants. Income is measured net of returns, rebates, and commercial discounts. Royalties, fees, and other billings to franchisees There are different types of franchise agreements (total franchise, shared franchise, management lease, management lease with investments). The percentage of royalties and fees received depends on the type of the agreement. Royalties, fees, and other billings to franchisees (excluding rents) include: - Trademark royalties collected in connection with the usage rights of the Burger King®, Au Bureau®, Volfoni®, Pitaya®, Itsu®, Hippopotamus®, and Léon® brands granted to franchisees; - National advertising fees collected for the participation of franchisees in the national advertising budget; - Management-lease fees collected in respect of the lease of the business that the Group owns.

Trademark royalties are billed monthly to franchisees and correspond, contractually, to a percentage of franchise sales and income generated by the franchisees. They are recorded as the sales are made to consumers in accordance with the exemption for royalties provided for under IFRS 15.

Franchisees’ participation in the national advertising budget is billed monthly to franchisees and corresponds to a percentage of sales generated by the franchisees. It is recorded as sales are made insofar as it is believed that the national advertising activities do not pay for services separate from the licence to use the trademark and know-how.

As a lessor, the Group has concluded real estate lease agreements and management-lease agreements (with or without investments) with its franchisees. The management-lease agreements have an initial term of 9 years. In all cases, the fees correspond, contractually, to a percentage of the sales that is billed to each franchisee for the use of the business, the occupation of premises, and the leasehold rights. The rents received are recorded in income on a straight-line basis over the rental period. These agreements correspond to operating lease agreements on the lessor’s side in accordance with IFRS 16. Sales of goods and materials to franchises Income from sales of goods and materials to franchisees are accounted for at the time the control of the goods is transferred to the franchisees, which corresponds to the billing date. Following the acquisitions and contributions of securities of Flo Group, United Lab, Miditsuco GB, Holdco GB, and Bertrand Franchise Services in 2023, the Group, for its Pitaya brand, runs a central purchasing and sales operation on behalf of its franchisees operating restaurants under this brand. In 2022, such an activity did not exist. ----- ###### 6.1.4. Entry fees and other sales

Subsection Title: Network access fees and entry fees
Subsubsection Text: Network access fees and entry fees are billed to franchisees in return for the transfer of know-how, use of the trademark, territorial exclusivity, and assistance in opening the restaurant. They are billed on the start date of the agreement. They are considered payment for the licence to use the trademark and know-how, like trademark royalties, and not payment for separate services. As this is an evolving licence within the meaning of IFRS 15, this income is to be recorded over the duration of the franchise agreement in a straight-line manner insofar as it is believed that the Group’s performance as franchisor occurs uniformly over the duration of the contract. The fees billed at the beginning of the agreement that have not yet been recorded in “franchise sales and income” are recorded in current and non-current deferred revenue.

Other sales mainly consist of income related to real estate development transactions recognised as a percentage of completion of the work, and related to the referencing services of suppliers. “Other sales” over the 2023 financial year mainly consist of the revenue generated on real estate development agreements (i.e. €61.0 million for the 2023 financial year compared to €55.1 million for the 2022 financial year). These agreements are concluded with external lessors as part of the development of the restaurant network owned by Bertrand Franchise for the creation of new restaurants. Revenue relating to real estate development agreements is recorded based on the percentage of completion. The balance of other sales consists of billings to franchised partners and other non-Group thirdparty partners. The costs relating to these “other sales” are mainly found in the “total cost of sales” under “supply and merchandise costs” (see note 6.2). The evolution of other sales between the 2023 and 2022 financial years is mainly due to the number of Burger King® restaurants finalised or under construction via real estate development agreements and, to a lesser extent, due to the contribution over 2 months of the Bertrand Casual Food operation contributed on 31 October 2023. Deferred income relating to network access fees and entry fees is included in “other non-current liabilities” (see note 6.8) and “other current ----- liabilities” (see note 6.5.5). The change is explained by the new franchise agreements billed _In millions of euros_ ``` Non-current deferred incom e (lease liabilities) Current deferred incom e (lease liabilities) Total ###### 6.1.5. Loyalty programmes ``` during the period as well as the related entry fees. They are presented as follows:

The Group’s brands can offer their consumers loyalty programmes. They assign loyalty points to consumers in proportion to purchases made in restaurants. To date, only Burger King restaurants offer a loyalty programme system. The sale of a good or service accompanied by the provision of loyalty points constitutes a contract with two separate “performance obligations”: - On the one hand, a good or service delivered immediately; and - On the other hand, a right to receive goods or services at a reduced price or for free at a later date. These points are recognised in revenue as they are used or as they expire. And when they are allocated, it is assumed that they will be redeemed. The amount received for the sale is divided between the two “performance obligations” in proportion to their respective specific sale prices. ###### 6.2. Gross and operational margin The cost of sales consists of the cost of supplies and goods, the cost of restaurant staff, and the costs related to other sales to non-franchised partners outside the Group. - The cost of supplies and goods consists of the cost of raw materials and goods necessary for the creation of finished products sold to consumers (see note 6.1.1), the cost of raw materials, goods, and materials sold by the Group to franchisees (see note 6.1.2), the incurred cost of materials and services necessary for the performance of services sold to non-franchised partners outside the Group (see note 6.1.3), and other costs corresponding mainly to real estate development agreements (see note 6.1.4); - The cost of restaurant staff corresponds to the salary costs, employer expenses, and benefits paid to employees of the Group’s establishments contributing to the sale to consumers (see note 6.1.1). The costs of occupation and operation mainly include energy costs, maintenance and monitoring contracts, and taxes (business, land, etc.). ----- Depreciation corresponds to depreciation of fixed assets related to restaurants operated directly by the Group as well as usage rights of the operational leases for which the Group is a lessee (see note 8.3). The change in the “supply and merchandise costs” between the 2023 and 2022 financial years is mainly due to: - the activity of restaurants operated directly by the Group and in connection with sales to consumers; - the inflation of raw material costs during 2023; ###### 6.3. Current operating income - the increase in the costs of real estate development agreements compared to the level of revenue achieved on real estate development agreements (see note 6.1.4) in 2023 versus 2022 (€61.6 million in the 2023 financial year versus €52.5 million in the 2022 financial year). The current operating income consists of the following elements: - Operating margin (see note 6.2); - Commercial costs consisting of advertising and marketing costs incurred by the Group for the establishments it operates directly as well as for the contribution of establishments operated via a franchise agreement through national advertising fees (see note 6.1.2); - Burger King® trademark royalties paid to Burger King Corporation, as well as Itsu® trademark royalties paid to Itsu Limited; - The costs of opening restaurants, consisting of all the costs incurred prior to the opening of an establishment and necessary for its opening, such as the staff expenses during their training period, the recruitment costs of said staff, any rents paid to the lessors, the advertising costs incurred for the opening of the establishment, the initial allocation of small non-depreciable materials necessary for the proper operation of the establishment, etc.; - Other current operating income and expenses mainly consist of: `o` Gains or losses on disposals of fixed assets carried out as part of franchising or real estate transactions; `o` Write-downs/reversals of expected impairment of trade receivables; - General and administrative costs (excluding depreciation and amortisation) consisting of all support costs incurred by the Group for its proper operation; - Depreciation and amortisation of the headquarters; - Other income and expenses of the headquarters. ----- Other current operating income and expenses are broken down as follows: Other income and other expenses for the 2023 financial year are mainly related to gains related to the restaurant network’s management operations. In 2022, they are mainly related to real estate gains realised during the transfer of operations of previously directly operated restaurants to franchisees. ###### 6.4. Other non-current income and expenses Other non-current income and expenses consist of unusual, abnormal, and infrequent items in the event that a major event occurring during the period is likely to distort the reading of performance. They may include, for example, restructuring costs, acquisition costs, charges to provisions in the context of lawsuits other than commercial and labour disputes, net income or losses on the disposal of intangible and tangible fixed assets related to the closure of restaurants, and impairment tests. Trade receivables Customer receivables are non-derivative fixed-payment or determinable financial assets that are not listed on an active market. They are included in current assets. Customer receivables are recorded at their transaction price within the meaning of IFRS 15 on the date of initial recognition. Other operating receivables are initially recorded at fair value. Subsequently, customer receivables and other operating receivables are measured by way of the amortised cost method, which generally corresponds to their nominal value. No trade receivable are pledged or covered by insurance. In accordance with IFRS 9, the Group applies the simplified method in the measurement of trade receivables and recognises expected impairment over the life of these receivables. Expected impairments are estimated through the use of a provisioning matrix based on a history of impairments, adjusted for specific factors related to creditors, current general economic conditions, and forecasts of future economic conditions that can be obtained on the closing date without having to incur excessive costs or efforts. Information on the write-downs of trade receivables and the Group’s exposure to credit risk can be found in note 10.4.4. _In millions of euros_ Other tax liabilities Employee and social liabilities Deferred income Other ``` Total ``` Deferred income includes in particular the shortterm share of entry fees collected by the Group and spread over the term of the franchise agreements, as well as the deferred income from property development transactions (see note 6.1.4). ###### 6.5.6. Change in working capital requirement The change in working capital requirement is broken down as follows: ----- The change in working capital requirement of €29.3 million observed in the 2023 financial year is mainly related to: - repayments of current accounts vis-à-vis the Bertrand Group, ###### 6.6. Non-current financial assets The change in working capital requirement of €5.3 million observed in the 2022 financial year is mainly related to: - increased activity, - the increase in receivables related to the property development activity at the Burger King France subgroup. Loans and guarantees are mainly related to security deposits paid under the lease agreements entered into by the Group as lessee. At their initial recording, they are measured at their fair value and then measured at their amortised cost. The Group also uses caps and tunnels to cover the share of its variable-rate bond debt. These derivative instruments are measured at their fair value. The method of accounting for their change in fair value depends on whether or not a documented hedging relationship exists within the meaning of IFRS 9: - In the absence of a hedging relationship, changes in fair values are recorded in the income statement; - If a cash flow hedging relationship is documented, the change in fair value of the hedging derivative is initially recorded in other items of comprehensive income for the effective portion and directly in the income statement for the ineffective portion of the change. However, the time value of options is accounted for separately as a hedging cost. It is recorded in other items of comprehensive income. It is recycled to profit and loss over the duration of the hedging. ----- The change in the fair value of derivative financial instruments corresponds to the mark-to-market value of hedging financial instruments as of 31 ###### 6.7. This is spread over the term of the master franchise agreement. ----- Trade payables are initially recorded at their fair value and then at their amortised cost, which generally correspond to their nominal value. ###### 6.5.5. Other current liabilities

###### 6.5. Working capital requirement 6.5.1. Inventories Other non-current expenses primarily consist of costs related to the acquisition by the Group of the Burger King operations on the Island of Réunion in 2023 (see note 2). The costs of closing restaurants mainly consist of scrapping and disposals of tangible and intangible fixed assets of closed or sold restaurants. During the 2022 financial year, the Villeneuve d’Ascq and Marseille Grand Littoral restaurants were closed. Inventories are measured at the lower of their cost or net realisable value. The Group’s inventories consist of supplies, materials, and food products. Their cost includes the purchase price plus customs duties and other non-recoverable taxes, and transportation and handling costs incurred to bring the inventories to where they are. Material inventories are measured by way of the weighted-average cost method. Food product inventories are measured by way of the FIFO (First in, First Out) method, taking into account the rules for managing these food products and the context of rapid rotation of this inventory category.

In the 2023 financial year, the Group’s average headcount in full-time equivalents was 3,698 people, including Bertrand Casual Food brands for 2 months (November and December 2023). These figures are based on fixed-term and indefinite contracts. ----- The number of physical staff in full-time equivalents as of 31 December 2023 is 5,973. In the 2022 financial year, the average headcount of the Burger King France subgroup in full-time equivalents was 2,702 people compared to 2,754 people at the end of 2021 for the continuous scope. These figures are based on fixed-term and indefinite contracts. The number of physical staff in full-time equivalents as of 31 December 2023 was 2,685 people compared to 2,741 as of 31 December 2021. The commitments recorded on the balance sheet are as follows (see note 9): In France, the retirement benefits plan provides for the payment of lump-sum compensation calculated on the basis of the seniority of employees within the Group and their salary at the time of retirement. The Group’s obligation under this plan is assessed annually by an independent actuary using the projected unit credit method. The cost of the services is recorded as general and administrative expenses under operating expenses while the interest expense is recorded as a financial expense. The amounts of future payments corresponding to the benefits granted to employees are measured on the basis of assumptions regarding changes in salary, starting age, and mortality. They are then discounted to their present value on the basis of interest rates of long-term bonds of first-class issuers. Actuarial differences relating to obligations arising from defined-benefit plans are recorded directly in other items of comprehensive income. -----

Other intangible assets ``` Intangible fixed assets with an indefinite useful life, acquired separately, are initially recorded at their acquisition cost, and intangible assets acquired as part of a business combination are recorded at their fair value on the acquisition date. This is particularly the case for trademarks for which there is no foreseeable limit to the period in which the asset is expected to generate net cash inflows. After the initial recognition, intangible assets are not subject to remeasurement. Intangible fixed assets with a fixed useful life are amortised via the straight-line method over their useful life; the useful life is reviewed at each closing. Intangible fixed assets with an indefinite useful life are not amortised but are subject to an impairment test annually or more frequently if there is an indication of impairment in accordance with IAS 36 (see note 8.5). Other intangible fixed assets with a fixed useful life consist mainly of franchise agreements, software, patents, licences, and concessions. Subsection Title: Statutory Auditors’ Review Report on the quarterly consolidated financial information
Subsubsection Text: For the period from January 1 to March 31, 2024 To the President, In our quality of statutory auditors of BERTRAND FRANCHISE S.A.S. and in answer to your request, we have reviewed the accompanying quarterly condensed consolidated financial statements, for the period from January 1 to March 31, 2024, as they are attached to this report. We highlight that BERTRAND FRANCHISE for which the quarterly consolidated financial statements are subject to our review has prepared its first set of consolidated financial statements as at December 31, 2023 in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union, consequently we have not audited nor reviewed the corresponding figures relating to the period from January 1 to March 31, 2023 and prepared under the same principles. These quarterly consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the President. Our role is to express a conclusion on these quarterly financial statements based on our review. We conducted our review in accordance with professional standards applicable in France and the professional doctrine of the French national auditing body (Compagnie nationale des commissaires aux comptes) related to this engagement. A review of interim financial information consists of making inquiries, primarily of persons responsible for financial and accounting matters, and applying analytical procedures. A review is substantially less in scope than an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France and consequently does not enable us to obtain assurance that we would become aware of all significant matters that might be identified in an audit. Accordingly, we do not express an audit opinion. Based on our review, nothing has come to our attention that causes us to believe that the accompanying quarterly consolidated financial statements are not prepared in conformity with IAS 34 - International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union related to financial statements presented for an interim period. This report is governed by French law. The Courts of France shall have exclusive jurisdiction in relation to any claim, dispute or difference concerning the engagement letter or this report, and any ----- matter arising from them. Every part irrevocably waives any right it may have to object to an action being brought in any of those Courts, to claim that the action has been brought in an inconvenient forum or to claim that those Courts do not have jurisdiction. French original signed at Paris La Défense, on May 21, 2024 by The Statutory Auditors KPMG S.A. Mazars & Associés S.A.S. Eric ROPERT Simon BEILLEVAIRE     Charles GUILBERT Partner Partner Partner

Subsection Title: Statutory auditors’ report on the consolidated financial statements
Subsubsection Text: For the year ended December 31, 2023 To the shareholders of BERTRAND FRANCHISE S.A.S., ###### Opinion In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us by your annual general meeting, we have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of BERTRAND FRANCHISE S.A.S. for the year ended December 31, 2023. In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Group as at December 31, 2023 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union. We highlight that the first set of consolidated financial statements have been prepared as at December 31, 2023 in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union, consequently we have not audited nor reviewed the corresponding figures relating to the period from January 1 to December 31, 2022. ###### Basis for Opinion

We conducted our audit in accordance with professional standards applicable in France. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Statutory _Auditors’ _Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements section of our report._ -----

We conducted our audit engagement in compliance with independence requirements of the french Commercial Code (code de commerce) and the French Code of Ethics (code de déontologie) for statutory auditors’ rules applicable to us, for the period from January 1, 2023 to the date of our report. ###### Justification of Assessments In accordance with the requirements of Articles L.821-53 and R.821-180 of the French Commercial Code (code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the matters that, in our professional judgment, were of most significance in our audit of the consolidated financial statements of the current period. These matters were addressed in the context of our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole, and in forming our opinion thereon, and we do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the consolidated financial statements. In the context of the creation of Bertrand Franchise Group, the Group acquired several companies, as stated in note 4.2.1. to the consolidated financial statements, which details the transactions that took place on October 31, 2023. With our valuation specialists, we have reviewed the valuation methods used to value the contributed assets and the assumptions used for the provisional allocation of the purchase price at the date of acquisition. We have also verified that note 4.2.1 to the consolidated financial statements provides appropriate disclosures. ###### Specific Verifications We have also performed, in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the specific verifications required by laws and regulations of the Group information given in the management report of the President. We have no matters to report as to its fair presentation and its consistency with the consolidated financial statements. ###### Responsibilities of Management and Those Charged with Governance for the Consolidated Financial Statements Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union and for such internal control as management determines is necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless it is expected to liquidate the Company or to cease operations. The consolidated financial statements were approved by the President.

The Bertrand Group wanted to strengthen its growth momentum by improving the clarity of its various operations. To do this, the Bertrand Group reorganised its operations into two distinct and autonomous divisions as of 3 July 2023 (see note 1): - Bertrand Hospitality, particularly for its operations in exceptional places with unique expertise: brasseries, concessions, tearooms, retail, and hotels; - Bertrand Franchise, for Bertrand Casual Food and Burger King. Before the reorganisation, the Group’s simplified organisational chart was as follows:

Subsubsection Text: To do this, the Bertrand Group has carried out the following legal reorganisation: - On 3 July 2023, through disposals and contributions of securities, (i) Groupe Flo became the parent company of the entities that carry the brands Au Bureau®, Hippopotamus®, Léon® and Volfoni®, and (ii) Miditsuco GB became the parent company of the Bertrand Franchise entities that carry the brand Itsu®. - On 31 October 2023, the company TopCo GB, parent company of the Burger King France Group, 60% owned by the Bertrand Group and 40% by Bridgepoint on that date, became group head of the Bertrand Franchise division through acquisitions and contributions of securities of Flo Group, United Lab, Miditsuco GB (parent company of the Itsu subgroup), Holdco GB (parent company of the Pitaya subgroup), and Bertrand Franchise Services (parent company of Bertrand Franchise Logistics), with a view to bringing all franchise activities under one entity (see note 4.2). - At the same time, TopCo GB becomes Bertrand Franchise (see note 1), a platform of multi-segment franchise restaurant brands. Bertrand Franchise thus increased its equity by an amount of €368.0 million by issuing 380,730 ordinary shares and 19,783 series A preferred shares in favour of Bertrand Franchise Corp. as compensation for said contributions of securities (see note 12). All of these entities and activities were and remain controlled by the Bertrand Group, held by the BH Group head company. Entry into the capital of United JVCO Limited and repayment of the convertible bonds of Bertrand Franchise In conjunction with the contributions made by the Bertrand Group on 31 October, United JVCO Ltd (a joint venture owned at 50/50 by Alpinvest and Vintage) took an equity interest in the Group by subscribing for preferred shares of Bertrand Franchise for an amount of €458 million, which resulted in the issuance of 302,052 series B preferred shares (see note 12). With regard to IFRS standards, these preferred shares are analysed as equity instruments that do not confer on the new contractual commitment shareholder to receive any remuneration whatsoever in the form of cash or other financial assets. At the end of this capital increase, the Group repaid in advance its convertible bonds subscribed for by Bridgepoint for a residual amount of €297.6 million in principal and €22.6 million in accrued interest (corresponding to 400,000 convertible bonds). ----- At the end of all these transactions, as of 31 October 2023, Bertrand Franchise is 60.75% owned by Bertrand Franchise Corp (for voting rights of 74.29%), 21.25% by BQ Participations (for voting rights of 74.29%), and 18% by United JVCO (for zero voting rights).

Subsection Title: Inflation of raw materials and energy costs
Subsubsection Text: In 2023, after 2022 saw a sharp increase in inflation (+5.9% vs 2021), price movements slowed slightly. Average annual inflation thus stands at +4.9%. The increase in prices was notably supported by the acceleration of inflation with respect to food (+11.8% in 2023 vs 2022 after +6.8% in 2022 vs 2021) (Source: _INSEE _[https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/7750173).](https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/7750173)_ Oil prices stabilised, while electricity prices continued to fuel inflation, with an 18.9% increase over the year. As in 2022, the Group, thanks to its purchasing strategies, managed to control this inflation in 2023 for its own restaurants and for its franchised Burger King partners by implementing several renegotiation measures with its food and non-food suppliers and through an energy savings plan (both within its own restaurants and within its headquarters in Clichy), which reduced energy consumption by about 5% compared to 2022. However, this decrease in restaurant energy consumption was not sufficient to offset the increase in electricity purchase prices, which almost doubled in 2023 compared to 2022. In this context, a prudent strategy of increasing restaurant sales prices has made it possible to preserve restaurant margins while remaining attractive to the end consumer.

After opening 44 new restaurants under the Burger King® brand in metropolitan France in 2022, the Group continued its development with the opening, once again, of 44 restaurants operated under the Burger King® brand in metropolitan France. In 2023, the Group purchased a majority share in the Burger King operations on the Island of Réunion carried out by the companies S2FOI (which directly owns and operates 17 restaurants on the island) and DISTRIFOOD (which manages a dedicated purchasing and logistics centre). Following the purchases and contributions of securities of Flo Group, United Lab, Miditsuco GB, Holdco GB and Bertrand Franchise Services (see note 4.2), 519 new restaurants (191 operated under the Au Bureau® brand; 102 under the Hippopotamus® brand; 36 operated under the Léon Fish Brasserie® brand; 27 under the Léon de Bruxelles® brand, intended to be converted to the Léon Fish Brasserie® brand; 18 under the Volfoni® brand; 144 under the Pitaya® brand; and one under the Itsu® brand) joined the Bertrand Franchise scope of consolidation, including 104 operated directly by the Group and 415 operated by franchised partners through a franchise agreement. In addition to the 519 restaurants that joined the Bertrand Franchise scope of consolidation following purchases and contributions of securities from Flo Group, United Lab, Miditsuco GB, and Holdco GB as described above, the Group has opened five new restaurants under the Au Bureau® brand, one under the Hippopotamus® brand, one under the Léon Fish Brasserie® brand, one under the Volfoni® brand, and two under the Pitaya® brand. These growth initiatives have been supported by significant investments from the Group’s lessors and franchisees, thus limiting the Group’s remaining net investment and maintaining sustainable and profitable growth across all its brands. In 2022, the Group opened 44 restaurants under the Burger King® brand.

System-wide sales are sales to consumers of directly operated restaurants as well as those operated by our franchise partners under the ----- brands Burger King®, Au Bureau®, Léon®, Volfoni®, Hippopotamus®, Pitaya®, and Itsu®. As of 31 December 2023, Group system-wide sales amounted to €2,053.2 million (including 2 months of brands contributed on 31 October 2023), i.e. an increase of €471.7 million for continuing operations compared to the same period of the previous year. The increase in the Group’s system-wide sales is explained in particular by: - The increase in system-wide sales achieved by Burger King Group in metropolitan France of €300.7 million, resulting from (i) the opening of 44 restaurants during 2023, partially offset by the permanent closure of one restaurant during 2023; (ii) innovations with the launch of new products; and (iii) moderate and targeted increases in consumer sales prices; ###### 2.2. Significant events of 2022 In 2022, system-wide sales are sales to consumers of directly operated restaurants as well as those operated by franchise partners under the brands Burger King® and Quick® brands. As of 31 December 2022, Group system-wide sales amounted to €1,581 million, i.e. an increase of €365 million for continuing operations compared to the same period of the previous year. The increase in the Group’s system-wide sales is explained in particular by: ###### 2.3. Events after closing On 15 March 2024, the shareholders authorised the president to allocate a maximum number of 13,699 ordinary shares free of charge for the benefit of corporate officers and employees of the Group. Declaration of conformity The consolidated financial statements for the 2023 financial year of the Bertrand Franchise Group were prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRSs) published by the IASB, as adopted in the European Union and mandatory as of 31 December 2023, as well as their interpretations (SIC and IFRIC). - The negative impact of the Covid-19 health crisis during the first half of 2021; - The opening of 44 new restaurants under the Burger King® brand completed during the 2022 financial year (including 20 during the first half of 2022 and 24 during the second half of 2022); - Product innovations, notably through the development of the premium offer and the expansion of the “veggie” range; - Increasing prices throughout all distribution channels. However, this increase has been partially offset by: - The geopolitical context and the increase in tensions in Ukraine since the end of February 2022, which have increased inflationary pressures in Europe. The Group remains attentive to the progression of this conflict and the possible effects it could have on its operations, particularly due to inflation; - The permanent closure of three restaurants under the Burger King® brand in the 2022 financial year. make use of this authorisation and allocated 7,830 ordinary shares free of charge. In 2022, the geopolitical context linked to the Ukrainian crisis led to a tension in the markets, particularly the energy, agricultural and nonagricultural raw material, and food product markets, which resulted in a sharp increase in inflation, reaching +5.9% compared to 2021 according to INSEE (Institut National de la _Statistique et des Études Économiques [French_ National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies]) data. (Source: _INSEE _[https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6688389#tit](https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6688389#titre-bloc-6) [re-bloc-6)](https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6688389#titre-bloc-6)_ With respect to energy in particular, inflation reached +15.1% in 2022, including +14.3% for petroleum products, +7.3% for electricity, and +29.3% for gas prices. (Source: _INSEE _[https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6688389#tit](https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6688389#titre-bloc-6) [re-bloc-6)](https://www.insee.fr/fr/statistiques/6688389#titre-bloc-6)_ With respect to the markets for agricultural raw materials and food products, given the - The decrease in system-wide sales by €0.8 million realised by Burger King Group under the Quick® brand in metropolitan France, resulting from the permanent closure of six restaurants and the temporary closure of two restaurants in 2023; the two temporarily closed restaurants will be converted to the Burger King® brand during 2024; - €28.3 million generated under the Burger King® brand on the Island of Réunion following purchase; - €143.6 million generated by Bertrand Casual Food under the brands Au Bureau®, Hippopotamus®, Léon Fish Brasserie®, Léon de Bruxelles®, Volfoni®, Pitaya®, and Itsu® following the purchase and contribution transactions and the ten openings completed in November and December 2023 under these brands. geopolitical context (resulting in a drop in supply sources and inflated energy costs that impact the entire food value chain), which was amplified by poor harvests for potatoes, 2022 experienced high levels of inflation, particularly with respect to meat products (beef and poultry), grains, oilseeds, potatoes, and packaging. The impact of this inflation on the cost of sales was estimated by the Group to be slightly below 20% at the end of 2022 over one year compared to the end of 2021. In order to protect its margins, the Group has implemented several measures, including renegotiation with its food suppliers, process optimisations to limit losses, and product range optimisations, and has had to increase its sales prices to consumers beyond what was initially planned. ----- The Group has also initiated an energy savings plan to reduce consumption in anticipation of future increases for 2023.

SEGMENT INFORMATION According to IFRS 8, an operating segment is a component of an entity: - that engages in business activities from which it may earn revenues and incur expenses; - whose operating results are regularly reviewed by the entity’s chief operating decision-maker; - for which discrete financial information is available. The Group’s chief operating decision-maker is the Board of Directors. As of 31 December 2023, the Group’s activity is concentrated exclusively in France and consists of the development and operation of restaurants owned and directly operated by the Group or managed by third parties via franchise or management-lease agreements. Until October 2023, the Group operated within a single segment, mainly focused on Burger King® operations. ----- However, following the acquisitions and contributions of securities of Flo Group, United Lab, Miditsuco GB, Holdco GB, and Bertrand Franchise Services (see note 4.2) as of 31 October 2023, Bertrand Franchise reorganised the Group’s structure, which now consists of two distinct segments: - Burger King Group: this first segment encompasses the Burger King® brand operations;

A subsidiary is an entity controlled by the Group. The Group controls a subsidiary when it is exposed or is entitled to variable returns due to its links with the entity and has the ability to influence these returns due to its power over it. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are included in the consolidated financial statements from the date on which control is gained until the date on which the control ceases. The Group has entered into brand licensing and substantive concerning the purchase, the rental franchise agreements with a number of partners, of premises, the setting of sales prices, the allowing them to operate restaurants under the management of staff, and the renewal of the Burger King®, Au Bureau®, Volfoni®, Léon®, licence and franchise agreement. In addition, the Hippopotamus®, Itsu®, and Pitaya® brands. The Group does not hold a stake in the partners Group believed it did not have control of the except in temporary special cases, and the Group companies managing the restaurants in question does not grant any loan or current account to the insofar as the partners have rights deemed partners. ----- ###### 4.2. Company acquisition and takeover Business combinations are accounted for by applying the acquisition method when they give control to the Group. Thus, the identifiable assets and liabilities of the acquired company are generally accounted for at fair value on the date of acquisition when a business combination complies with the definition of IFRS 3. In accordance with IFRS 3, a transaction under common control should be taken into account as soon as all the entities being combined are ultimately controlled by the same party, both before and after the combination and without the control being only temporary. Since IFRS 3 does not have any specific application or directive for this purpose, this type of combination is outside its scope. In the absence of standards governing the accounting treatment of business combinations between entities under common control, management must establish an accounting method in accordance with IAS 8 – Accounting Methods, Changes in Accounting Estimates, and Errors. The Group has therefore chosen to account for combinations under common control according to the acquisition method, applying IFRS 3 – Business Combinations in its consolidated financial statements by analogy. Goodwill is calculated as the total of the fair value of the transferred consideration (including the fair value of any previously held interest in the acquired company) plus the amount recorded for any noncontrolling interest in the acquired company, minus the net amount recorded (usually at fair value) for identifiable assets and liabilities taken over. Non-controlling interests are measured, optionally at each takeover, either up to the share of identifiable net assets or at fair value. When the difference determined in this way is negative, and after reassessment of the different components of the equation, the gain resulting from an acquisition made under advantageous conditions is immediately recognised in profit or loss in “other non-current income and expenses”. Subsequently, goodwill is assessed at its cost less any write-downs representative of impairment. Writedowns are immediately recorded in profit or loss and are irreversible in accordance with IAS 36. ###### 4.2.1. Acquisitions related to the establishment of Bertrand Franchise As part of the reorganisation of the Bertrand Group (see note 2.1 in the “reorganisation” section), the Bertrand Franchise Group received the contributions of 100% of the shares in the capital of Flo Group, United Lab, Miditsuco GB (parent company of the Itsu subgroup), Holdco GB (parent company of the Pitaya subgroup), and Bertrand Franchise Services (parent company of Bertrand Franchise Logistics) on 31 October 2023, paid for via a capital increase. All of these entities and activities were and remain controlled by the Bertrand Group, held by the BH Group head company. In this case, the shareholding of all the parties falling within the scope of the transaction remains under the ultimate control of the BH entity. In addition, the operations making up these consolidated financial statements remain under the direct management of the historical management of Bertrand Franchise, characterising the transaction as under common control. The Group, historically TopCo GB and including historical operational entities (mainly Burger King), is considered the acquirer of these ----- operations for accounting purposes in accordance with IFRS 3. The provisional allocation of the purchase price on the takeover date, for a 100% share acquired, can be summarised as follows: ----- The work in valuing assets and liabilities and the allocation of the purchase price, as required by IFRS 3, were assessed by an independent expert. This assessment work is still ongoing and will be finalised within 12 months of the acquisition date in accordance with the provisions of IFRS 3. If, within this period, new information is obtained regarding events and circumstances that prevailed on the date of acquisition and would lead to the adjustment of the amounts below, the accounting for the acquisition will be adjusted retrospectively. The contributed companies have cumulative tax loss carryovers of €230.6 million, of which €182.4 million (i.e. €47.1 million of deferred tax assets) was capitalised up to the amount of the taxable temporary differences recognised in provisional net assets, taking into account a cap on the shortfall allocable annually to taxable profits up to 50% and taking into account the tax provisions applicable in France. This capitalisation takes into account the tax consolidations recorded prior to the acquisition, and which will take effect in 2024. Given the uncertainty regarding future earnings forecasts, residual tax losses were not capitalised. Subsection Title: Statutory auditors’ report on the consolidated financial statements
Subsubsection Text: For the year ended December 31, 2022 To the annual general meeting of Burger King France S.A.S., ###### Opinion In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us by your annual general meeting, we have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Burger King France S.A.S. for the year ended December 31, 2022. In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Group as at December 31, 2022 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union. ###### Basis for Opinion

We conducted our audit in accordance with professional standards applicable in France. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Statutory _Auditors’ _Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements section of our report._

We conducted our audit engagement in compliance with independence requirements of the French Commercial Code (code de commerce) and the French Code of Ethics (code de déontologie) for statutory auditors’ rules applicable to us, for the period from January 1, 2022 to the date of our report. ----- ###### Justification of Assessments In accordance with the requirements of Articles L.823-9 and R.823-7 of the French Commercial Code (code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the matters that, in our professional judgment, were of most significance in our audit of the consolidated financial statements of the current period. These matters were addressed in the context of our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole, and in forming our opinion thereon, and we do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the consolidated financial statements. As stated in Note 8.5 to the consolidated financial statements, “Impairment”, goodwill, intangible and tangible assets are subject to impairment tests. We have analyzed the methods of implementation of the impairment tests, as well as the cash flow forecasts and assumptions used to perform impairment tests, and we have assessed the appropriateness of the disclosures in Note 8.5. ###### Specific Verifications We have also performed, in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the specific verifications required by laws and regulations of the Group’s information given in the management report of the President. We have no matters to report as to its fair presentation and its consistency with the consolidated financial statements. ###### Responsibilities of Management and Those Charged with Governance for the Consolidated Financial Statements Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union and for such internal control as management determines is necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless it is expected to liquidate the Company or to cease operations. The consolidated financial statements were approved by the President.

Subsection Title: Burger King France S A S
Subsubsection Text: ----- ###### Statutory Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements Our role is to issue a report on the consolidated financial statements. Our objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated financial statements. As specified in Article L.823-10-1 of the French Commercial Code (code de commerce), our statutory audit does not include assurance on the viability of the Company or the quality of management of the affairs of the Company. As part of an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the statutory auditor exercises professional judgment throughout the audit and furthermore: ###### • Identifies and assesses the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, designs and performs audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtains audit evidence considered to be sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for his opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. ###### • Obtains an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control. ###### • Evaluates the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by management in the consolidated financial statements. ###### • Assesses the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern. This assessment is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of his audit report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Company to cease to continue as a going concern. If the statutory auditor concludes that a material uncertainty exists, there is a requirement to draw attention in the audit report to the related disclosures in the consolidated financial statements or, if such disclosures are not provided or inadequate, to modify the opinion expressed therein. ###### • Evaluates the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements and assesses whether these statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation. ----- ###### • Obtains sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated financial statements. The statutory auditor is responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the audit of the consolidated financial statements and for the opinion expressed on these consolidated financial statements. French original signed at Paris La Défense, on March 30, 2023 by The statutory auditors KPMG Audit S.A. Mazars & Associés S.A.S. Subsubsection Text: 34, rue Mozart – Immeuble Le Cassiopée 92110 Clichy France

Lessees are required to recognise all contracts (with some exceptions) by recognising as an asset a right of use representing the right to use the underlying leased asset and a rental liability representing the obligation to pay rent over the term of the contract. However, the standard provides exemptions for short-term contracts (duration less than or equal to 12 months) or those for low-value assets. The Group used these two exemptions. According to IFRS 16, a contract or part of a contract is or contains a lease if it grants the right to control the use of an identified asset for a certain period, in exchange for a consideration. The terms of the leases used to determine the rights of use were determined in accordance with the IFRS IC decision published on 16 December, 2019 and the statement of conclusions of the Accounting Standards Authority (ANC) of 3 July, 2020, which cancels and replaces the one dated 16 February, 2018, to determine the IFRS 16 terms of the French leases “3/6/9” in particular being in a tacit renewal position. The Group shows the “rights to use” asset on a line dedicated to the balance sheet asset and shows the rent debts on lines separate from the “current/non-current financial debts”, entitled “current/noncurrent rent debts” of the statement of the financial situation. ----- The Group accounts for a “rights of use” asset and rent debt on the start date of the lease agreement. The “rights-of-use” asset is initially valued at cost, then, at cost less any amortisation and accumulated impairment losses, with the amount subject to adjustment based on certain revaluations of the rent liability. The lease debt is initially valued at the present value of the rents due but not yet paid at the contract start date. The discount rate used corresponds to the implicit interest rate of the contract or, if it cannot be easily determined, to the marginal borrowing rates (based on duration and not maturity) per lessee. These latter rates are used by the Group as discount rates. The rent debt is then increased by the interest expense and reduced by the amount of rent paid. It is revalued in the event of a revision of future rents following a change in index or rate, a new estimate of the amount expected to be paid under a residual value guarantee or, where applicable, a revaluation, the exercise of a purchase or extension option or the non-exercise of a termination option (which then become reasonably certain). Deferred taxes assets and liabilities are recognised in respect of rights of use and rent debts, on the basis that the tax deductions from the rents are attributable to the liability, and then offset.

Contingent liabilities are potential obligations arising from past events, the existence of which will be confirmed only by the occurrence of uncertain future events not under the control of the entity, or present obligations for which an outflow of resources is not likely. No significant potential liabilities are to be reported as at 31 December, 2023 and 31 December, 2022. #### 10. Financing and financial instruments ###### 10.1. Financial income The cost of gross financial debt is essentially made up of interest on bond debts, financial costs related to the RCF line (non-use commission), interest on other bank debts and on PGEs including guarantee commission. Other financial income and expenses consist mainly of: - Interest on rent debt; - Bond refinancing costs; - Changes in the fair value of derivative instruments (caps); - Pro rata-temporal spreading of cap bonuses ; - Various bank commissions; - Interest on liabilities in respect of post-employment plans. Interest is calculated using the effective interest rate method. ----- The Group's financial income breaks down as follows:

As at 31 December 2023, the main changes in net place on 31 October as part of the Bertrand financial income were due to: Franchise reorganisation; - The additional bond loan issued on 17 May, - Interest on bond and bank debts of the Flo 2023 by Burger King France for €45 million, and Pitaya group of companies as of 31 generating an increase in interest on bond October, 2023 (see note 4.2); debt during the 2023 financial year. This   - The increase in interest on IFRS16 debt due increase was not hedged by interest rate to the business combinations between instruments. Currency risk The Group’s exposure to foreign exchange risk is severely limited because the Group’s activity is carried out in France and has very little exposure to flows outside the European Union As at 31 December 2023 and 31 December 2022, there were no currency hedging commitments. - In addition, the Group's cash surpluses bear interest at a rate of 1.00% + 3month Euribor. These cash surpluses are liquid and available immediately. With interest rates expected to rise again in the 2023 financial year, the Group and its shareholders are closely monitoring interest rate risk. As such, during the 2023 financial year, the Group purchased 2.5% rate CAPs (E3M) to cover a notional amount of €242.5 million from 1 February, 2024 to 1 February, 2026. On 21 July 2023, the Group also purchased a rate hedging financial instrument (tunnel) consisting of a rate CAP at 3.5% as well as a floor at 2.5%, covering a nominal amount of €142.4 million, from 29 December 2023 to 31 December 2025. Given the limited exposure to foreign exchange risk, this exposure did not have a significant impact on the income statement for the financial year. ----- ###### 10.4.4. Credit risk Credit risk hedges all forms of counterparty default. Credit risk is closely monitored by the Group.

Subsection Title: Initial accounting of financial assets and liabilities
Initial accounting of financial assets and liabilities
Initial accounting of financial assets and liabilities
Subsubsection Text: On the date of entry on the balance sheet, the instrument is initially recognised at the fair value of the consideration given (for assets) or received (for liabilities). Fair value is determined by reference to the price agreed at the time of the transaction or by reference to market prices for comparable transactions. In the absence of market prices, the fair value is calculated by discounting the future flows of the transaction or by a model. Discounting is not necessary if its impact is negligible. Short-term receivables and debts arising from the operating cycle are not discounted. Costs directly related to the transaction (fees, commissions, fees, taxes, etc.) are added to the entry value of the assets and deducted from that of the liabilities. Fair value and book value of financial assets and liabilities - the main valuation methods used are as follows: - Level 1: fair value based on prices quoted on an active market; - Level 2: fair value assessed using observable market data (other than the quoted prices included in Level 1); - Level 3: fair value determined according to valuation techniques based on non-observable market data. -----

Trade receivables consist mainly of receivables from franchisees. Receivables must be depreciated due to expected credit losses. As at 31 December, 2023, the amount of this depreciation is €3.4 million, compared to €2.8 million as at 31 December, 2022. Receivables not depreciated due to expected credit losses are subject to a statistical provision. This statistical provision is based on historical credit losses over the last ten financial years. As at 31 December, 2023, the amount of this provision is €0.1 million, compared to €0.1 million as at 31 December, 2022. In addition, given the large number of customers, there is no risk of concentration of trade receivables. ###### 10.4.5. Analysis of net tax expenses

The difference between the current tax rate in France and the effective tax rate is broken down as follows: ----- (1) As at 31 December, 2023, this item mainly corresponds to non-deductible financial expenses. ###### 11.2. Deferred tax assets and liabilities Deferred taxes are recognised using the balance sheet liability method, in respect of all temporal differences existing at the balance sheet date between the tax base of assets and liabilities and their carrying amount in the balance sheet. Deferred tax liabilities are recognised for all taxable temporal differences except : `-` When the deferred tax liability results from the initial recognition of goodwill or the initial recognition of an asset or liability in a transaction that is not a business combination and that, at the time of its occurrence, does not affect the accounting profit, profit or taxable loss, and does not give rise, at the time of the transaction, to a taxable temporal difference and a deductible temporal difference of an equal amount ; and `-` For taxable temporal differences related to interests in subsidiaries, associated companies, when the date on which the temporal difference may reverse is controlled and it is likely that the temporal difference will not reverse in the foreseeable future. Deferred tax assets are recognised for all deductible temporal differences, carry forwards of unused tax losses and tax credits, to the extent that it is likely that a taxable profit will be available on which these deductible temporal differences, carry forwards of unused tax losses and tax credits may be charged: `-` Except when the deferred tax asset relating to the deductible temporal difference arises from the initial recognition of an asset or liability in a transaction that is not a business combination and which, at the date of the transaction, affects neither accounting profit nor taxable profit or tax loss and does not give rise, at the time of the transaction, to a taxable temporal difference and a deductible temporal difference of equal amount; and `-` For deductible temporal differences related to interest in subsidiaries, associated companies, deferred tax assets are only accounted for insofar as it is likely that the temporal difference will reverse in the foreseeable future and that there will be a taxable profit on which the temporal difference can be attributed. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are valued at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the financial year when the asset is realised or the liability is settled, based on tax rates (and tax rules) that have been enacted or quasi adopted by the balance sheet date. Deferred taxes relating to items recognised outside income are recognised outside income. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to offset the tax assets and liabilities payable, and these deferred taxes concern the same taxable entity and the same tax authority. ----- _As at 31 December, 2023_ ``` As at 31 Change in In m illions of euros Decem ber, 2022 statem ent ``` Deferred tax assets relating to loss carryforwards 10.2 Spread of entry rights (IFRS 15) 1.8 Spread of loan issue costs (3.2) `Tem poral differences` 1.1 Fixed assets (harmonisation of amortisation periods, (12.7) valuation differences, etc.) Recognition of financial instruments (6.4) Post-employment benefits 0.0 Provisions (excluding post-employment benefits) 0.0 IFRS 16 lease agreements 9.5 Assets and liabilities offset  Other 0.7 ``` TOTAL DEFERRED TAXES 1.0 ``` _As at 31 December, 2022_ ``` As at 31 Change in In m illions of euros Decem ber, 2021 statem ent ``` Deferred tax assets relating to loss carryforwards 4.5 Spread of entry rights (IFRS 15) 2.0 Spread of loan issue costs (4.3) Temporal differences 1.5 Fixed assets (harmonisation of amortisation periods, (14.1) valuation differences, etc.) Recognition of financial instruments (0.0) Post-employment benefits 0.0 Provisions (excluding post-employment benefits) 0.0 IFRS 16 lease agreements 7.4 Assets and liabilities offset Other 2.4 ``` TOTAL DEFERRED TAXES (0.6) ``` The Group has analysed the potential use of tax loss carryforwards, based on estimates of taxable income where these exist. The right to the lease is inseparable from the leasing contract itself insofar as the new lessee could not have accessed the leasing contract without incurring the cost relating to the right to the lease and would not have incurred this cost if it had not accessed the leasing contract. Consequently, the right to the lease constitutes an initial direct cost to the Group as lessee, which is taken into account in the initial valuation of the rights of use of the asset. It was considered that the right of use consists of two distinct significant components, having different consumption rates of their future economic benefits, and must be amortised separately: - The “right to lease”; - The other elements constituting the right of use. For the “right to lease” component, an analysis of the sites concerned showed that in the vast majority of cases the premium nature and location guaranteed a residual value at the end of the lease at least equal to the current value. As a result, no amortisation of this component is recognised. The other elements constituting the right of use are amortised over the useful life of the right of use, i.e. the term of the lease agreement. The rights of use are broken down as follows:
